QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES POLICE TRIBUNAL INQUIRY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a non-party political question, hoping for a non-party political answer, concerning the Allen affair. By way of preamble I mention that I have a great deal of respect for Mr Anderson, the New South Wales Minister for Police, for the speed and the courage with which he acted in appointing the inquiry to inquire into Mr Allen's activities. Surely it would represent a travesty of justice if the tip of the iceberg of corruption and the links with organised crime which were partially uncovered by the inquiry were left to rest because of the lack of constitutional power in Mr Anderson or his State ministerial colleagues. Does the Federal Government, which originally alerted the New South Wales Government to the visits of Mr Allen to Las Vegas, anticipate that the forwarding of documents to the Australian Federal Police, to its credit, by the New South Wales Government, will uncover any remaining areas of corruption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Chipp raises is a very important one indeed. The Commonwealth Government, as honourable senators know, has been concerned for a considerable time about the extent of organised crime in Australia. The Commonwealth Government, of course, has a responsibility for criminal actions which cross State boundaries or which have international implications.
—That is an unfortunate choice of words.

—I repeat that the Commonwealth has responsibility. We will leave it to the nitpicking lawyers to find some joy in that. I thought this was a serious question which required a serious answer. I did not except to find the normal nitpicking on the sidelines. The fact is that the Commonwealth Government has been concerned for a very considerable time at what might be the extent of organised crime in Australia which might exceed State boundaries and which might have Commonwealth implications. The Commonwealth Government has taken steps therefore, such as the establishment of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the establishment of the various task forces with the State. Indeed, a number of royal commissions have been established throughout Australia at both Commonwealth and State levels. Some of those royal commissions , both Commonwealth and State, had drug implications such as the Moffat, the Woodward and the Williams royal commissions. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union is showing wide interstate and even international implications. The Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking has also had these implications and implications of Nugan Hand.

ANSWER.PARA: Only yesterday, in the painters and dockers inquiry, evidence was given that a person described as a crime figure in New South Wales, Mr Abe Saffron, had links through Ward, Knight and Dunn Pty Ltd in what were called Slutzkin-type activities. There is some evidence that there may be a link between Saffron and Nugan Hand. If that is so then one has some worries because, in the Allen affair , links were shown between the previous deputy-commissioner and Mr Saffron. So a pattern of circumstances emerge which could suggest that there is a network of activities of crime in Australia. Accordingly, the Commonwealth Government has invited the State Government to provide it initially with the transcript of evidence and the findings of the inquiry. The Allen inquiry by a police tribunal was a very narrow inquiry which, as Senator Chipp remarked, originated from information provided by the Commonwealth to the State. Other suggestions have been made arising out of that inquiry. For example, Sergeant Molloy had indicated subsequently that he had been offered a bribe of the order of $42,000. Quite clearly a number of implications need to be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Mr Mason's allegations.

—Yes, a number of allegations need to be pursued. The Commonwealth, therefore, is seeking the information that has come from that inquiry. When it studies it, and looks at the overall scene, it will look to how the Commonwealth for the future should comport itself to tackle the obvious Commonwealth responsibilities that exceed State boundaries and may have international implications.

ANSWER.PARA: It is extremely worrying that evidence is emerging of what is now called the ' laundering' of very large sums of money from criminal activities. That laundering can come from gambling, drugs, prostitution and all sorts of activities. It is now emerging that crime in Australia is of a magnitude which was perhaps not realised before. It is a sad reflection that we have needed something in the order of half a dozen royal commissions in Australia in recent times in their own episodic ways to start putting together a pattern which suggests that there have been very serious criminal activities and, indeed, evidence of some police corruption. I say that choosing my words because I do not want to reflect upon the police forces at all. Where some evidence of individual police corruption emerges, one worries about how effective a police force can be in its general functions in this regard. The Commonwealth is treating this matter with great seriousness. It will study the matter and will look towards any future steps that might be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have any detailed information on the matter raised by Senator Sibraa. I will seek that from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Perhaps it is sufficient to say at this stage that it is always our aim that where food aid is given it reaches those who are in need of it and that it is not diverted to other purposes or for other use. I think all I can suggest is that I will seek information. If I get an early response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs I will advise the Senate accordingly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MORATORIUM ON OIL AND MINING EXPLORATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is a recent report correct that the National Aboriginal Conference at a recent meeting called for a moratorium on all oil and gas mining searches on Aboriginal land in Australia? Having in mind that responsibility for oil and mining exploration with its inherent responsibilities is handled by other Aboriginal organisations with considerable expertise, can the Minister comment on the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Press reports that a motion was adopted by the meeting of the National Aboriginal Conference last week on that matter as well as on a number of other matters. But I have not yet been informed of the content of the motion. I think Senator Kilgariff is correct to ask what implications that would have and to ask for some comments on it. The fact is that on Aboriginal land-certainly Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory-it is not possible for mining to proceed or for exploration to proceed without the consent of Aboriginal owners. There is no intention that that situation should change. It is scarcely necessary that the NAC should call for a moratorium on what is already Aboriginal land. The capacity to introduce such a moratorium is in the hands of the traditional owners and through the traditional owners in the hands of the appropriate land council which represents them in negotiations. The administration of mining and exploration matters in respect of land other than Aboriginal land is the responsibility of the various State governments and the Territory Government. The Commonwealth has always urged the States to consider the need to take account of the legitimate interests of Aboriginal people and communities in any arrangements which are made and to take into account the rights of any Aboriginals who would be affected by exploration activities.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the observation that recently some guidelines have been produced by two bodies-the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd and the Australian Mining Industry Council-as a first offer. These have been distributed for comment by Aboriginal groups. They have been considered recently by the Aboriginal affairs Ministers. I understand that they are under consideration by Ministers who are responsible for mining. I know that my colleague Mr Anthony will be discussing these guidelines with other Ministers. If these guidelines can be developed and can be agreed upon between Aboriginal and mining interests they should represent a very major step forward and should help us to achieve agreed and negotiated positions whenever mining or exploration is planned which will affect Aboriginal communities or Aboriginal land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to a Press release from the Reverend Father Kevin Mogg of 22 April? Is Father Mogg correct when he states that families which depend on widows and invalid pensions or unemployment, sickness or supporting parents benefits have suffered a 14.5 per cent drop in their income relative to average weekly earning since 1976? Is the assertion correct that family allowances have declined by 24 per cent in real terms since they were introduced in 1976? Is the Government proposing to act in the way which Father Mogg suggests is troubling Victoria's religious welfare agencies, namely, to finance tax cuts by cutting welfare expenditure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some sleight of hand is involved in examining this question of cuts in welfare expenditure. Various figures are used on various occasions to produce effects. I can only say, without wishing to increase the confusion in this area, that the total expenditure of the Commonwealth Government through the Department of Social Security increased this year by somewhere between 14 per cent and 15 per cent. I think the figure is much closer to 15 per cent. When one looks at the rate of inflation one can see that clearly that is an increase in real terms. It remains true, however, that there are significantly increased numbers of beneficiaries, that not all benefits are indexed and that therefore, with respect to some areas of benefit, there has been an effective real reduction. But the substantial portion of benefits paid through the Department of Social Security is indexed and is adjusted twice a year to take into account changes in the cost of living.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot confirm or deny whether the figure of 14.5 per cent cited, apparently, by Father Mogg, in a Press release which I have not seen as the decline relative to the proportion of average weekly earnings of specific beneficiaries is correct. But I can remind the Senate that, at the request of Senator Colston, some figures were incorporated in Hansard some weeks ago which showed the age pension as a proportion of average weekly earnings and which showed the figure as it had run from about the mid-1970's. The figures showed that there was a period in which the percentage of average weekly earnings increased. Over the last couple of years it has declined. The explanation of that is quite simple.

Pensions and benefits are in the main indexed against changes in the cost of living. In other words, they are adjusted as the cost of living changes. On the other hand, average weekly earnings are, of course, a function of the rate at which average wages are increasing. When average wages increase faster than the cost of living clearly pensions and benefits which are indexed to the cost of living will be a declining proportion of average weekly earnings. The reverse is true when average weekly earnings are rising slower than the cost of living. So it is true that over the last couple of years, as average weekly earnings have increased faster than the cost of living-in other words, wage and salary earners have been taking home real increases in their pay-the percentage of a number of benefits has declined as a percentage of average weekly earnings. I do not challenge the figure of 14.5 per cent. It is not a figure that I can simply confirm or deny.

Family allowances were instituted in 1976. They have not been adjusted, except in the last Budget when payments for children in families of three or more children were increased 50 per cent. That means that in real terms there has been a decline in the value of family allowances since 1976. What action will be taken in the Budget is, of course, a matter for Budget and Cabinet consideration . I would certainly put aside, however, any suggestion that cuts in taxes will be financed by cuts in welfare. I suggest to the Senate that history indicates that there is likely to be a continuing high and increasing requirement for welfare benefits in this country. Ten years ago we had one million people on income support. Today we have two million people on income support. Naturally that has changed very considerably the demands which are made upon the Australian Budget by the welfare sector. I do not see any change in that. At the same time, it is quite clear that the Government could not meet many of the requests made upon it for greatly increased assistance, if there is to be any hope of maintaining even a reasonable consistency of taxation, let alone reductions in taxation. I point to the single demand which many honourable senators have made in this chamber in the presentation of petitions that we increase pensions and benefits to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings. That has been costed by my Department at something like $2.7 billion a quarter, a real increase in the welfare expenditure of the Goverment. This is not the time to make a general statement. I am trying to respond to a question of considerable ambit put to me by the honourable senator. If he wants a more detailed reply he can let me know and I will get any further facts and figures he seeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. What has been the outcome of the recent discussions between the Federal and Tasmanian governments in relation to the scallop fisheries dispute adjacent to Flinders Island? What progress has been made with a total package of off-shore legislation proposals? Can the Minister give any indication of how it is proposed to handle the implementation of the off-shore fisheries legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated in Senator Archer's question, there have been discussions between officials of the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments on the scallop fisheries at Flinders Island. The present position is that the Commonwealth is waiting for Tasmania to submit a detailed management proposal for consideration in consultation with the State of Victoria which also has an interest in the fisheries in Bass Strait.

ANSWER.PARA: In accordance with the agreed arrangement between the Commonwealth and the States, the implementation of the legislation covering the off-shore constitutional settlement is to proceed as a package. This means that the proclamation of the legislation cannot be carried out until all of the complementary legislation has been passed by the States. In respect of fisheries , all but one of the States have enacted uniform laws to complement the relevant provisions of the Commonwealth Fisheries Act and in the State where enactment is not completed the Bill has been passed by the lower House and is scheduled to be dealt with by the upper House in its next sittings in June. Progress has been made with other aspects of the off-shore constitutional settlement. This matter is within the jurisdiction of my colleague, the Attorney-General, and questions about it should be directed to him.

With respect to the last part of the honourable senator's question, at the last meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council it was agreed that Commonwealth and State fisheries officials should commence discussions about which single law should apply to a particular fishery and the exercise of executive functions under that law. In preparation for those discussions, the Commonwealth has been examining the guidelines it would follow in the exercise and the views of the States are being sought on the implementation of the legislation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MARALINGA TESTS: EFFECTS ON ABORIGINAL HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of a report in the Western Mail on 24 April that 20 Aborigines now in the eastern goldfields of Western Australia are suffering from an unusually high rate of blood, skin, kidney, eye and nervous disorders? It is claimed that these Aborigines were exposed to high levels of radiation, having been near the Maralinga area in South Australia when Britain tested atomic bombs there in 1956 and that their chronic health problems are attributable to radiation rather than to alcohol abuse, lack of hygiene and poor diets. In view of the fact that this matter is currently being raised by a widely respected and prominent adviser to the State government departments on Aboriginal matters, will the Minister undertake to initiate a thorough investigation of all the circumstances of the alleged exposure to radiation and also take steps to ensure that the sick Aborigines are given every medical and social assistance?

—I am aware that the question of the health of people who claim to have been exposed to radiation at the time of the Maralinga tests is one that has been raised intermittently. I know that my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick has had an interest in some of the claims that have been made, certainly over the last two or three years. I am not aware of the article in the Western Mail. I would be grateful if Senator Giles would make it available to me -I am sure that she would do that-so that I can examine it. It would be helpful if we could get the details from anyone who claims that his or her health was affected by that testing. I know that is the request that Senator Sir John Carrick has made of individuals and groups over a considerable period. The Government's view is that it will examine such information, but until we have the information we cannot promise what kinds of results may flow from it. Therefore, I think the step to be taken now is to get from Senator Giles or from informants that she can find the basic information, the basic data, on which the claims are made. We will undertake to investigate those.
—Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to an article in the Port Augusta Transcontinental--
—I am sure it has. It is something to bet on.

—It is almost as famous as the Gawler Bunyip. The article reports comments of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, on the topic of uranium mining and the Olympic Dam project at Roxby Downs. Is the Minister aware that Mr Hayden is reported to have told a civic reception in Port Augusta that countries wanting Australian uranium will buy only on condition that the waste is buried in Australia? Can the Minister say whether this is in fact a condition placed upon overseas countries by the Government? Did the Minister note that Mr Hayden commented that the Australian Labor Party is not opposed to uranium mining provided safeguards could be guaranteed? Does the Minister agree that this apparent change of view, along with the views of the Australian Workers Union, will assist in the development of the Olympic Dam project which will be of tremendous economic significance to South Australia and will contribute significantly to Australia's export income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ordinarily my attention would not be drawn to such a newspaper, as Senator Chipp perhaps suggested. But the fact that it purported to report a statement by the Leader of the Federal Opposition and several statements that would be regarded as controversial resulted in the fact that I happen to have a copy of that article. So the first answer is that my attention has been drawn to the article. Assuming that the report is correct, the article states:

ANSWER.PARA: One of the conditions being laid down by countries which wanted our uranium was that the waste must be buried in Australia and it was this which was one of the main worries.
That purports to be a statement by Mr Hayden.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you vouch for it?

—No, I do not; I make it perfectly clear that I have no way of knowing whether it is. That is why I refer to a purported statement. If it is such a statement, then it is incorrect. Secondly, I refer to a matter which is strictly under my portfolio, that is, the newspaper report that countries wishing to purchase our uranium were demanding that the waste products be buried in Australia. I say emphatically that that is nonsense. There is no truth in that report at all. If a country buys uranium from Australia, it is true that the Australian Safeguards Office and the International Atomic Energy Agency track the quantity of the radioactive material through all its stages, but the final disposal of the waste is up to the country concerned with, of course, the auditing being a responsibility for Australia. It would be utterly wrong to suggest that Australia is to be the burying ground for wastes.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true also that the article stated that Mr Hayden emphasised that Labor is not opposed to uranium mining provided the safeguards could be guaranteed, and indicated that that may be so. If that is a correct report it is heartening because the development of Olympic Dam-indeed, the development of Roxby Downs-is a significant undertaking for all Australians. The development of uranium mining to provide essential electric power generation material to people overseas is of great importance. The people of South Australia would welcome a bipartisan approach to the development of an important mineral and employment creating opportunity in their State.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Is it a fact that the Australian Statistician's report released today indicates an annual employment growth rate of 1.2 per cent compared with the 2.2 per cent growth rate that applied last September? Is this rate of growth consistent with that which was predicted in last year's Budget Papers? Will the Government respond to the declining rate of growth in employment by adopting measures that will create jobs in both the private and public sectors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have the figures that were mentioned by Senator Ray. I will check them through with the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and see whether the statements contained in the question reflect the latest figures in employment growth. The job creation and other matters that were raised in the question will be subjected to examination at the time of the Budget. I have nothing further to comment on them at this stage.

—I have a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It is about Bass Strait oil rig platforms. I refer to the recent intrusion of foreign merchant ships into the restricted zone around the Bass Strait oil rig platforms and to the vulnerability of those platforms to terrorist attack and the recent tragic loss of life of a young Perth soldier from the Special Air Service Regiment in an exercise conducted in the area. I ask: In view of their strategic and economic importance to Australia, is the Minister satisfied that adequate measures have been and are being taken to protect these off-shore oil rigs against collision or other damage? Can the Minister say whether any unreported intrusions into the restriced area have taken place and whether any prosecutions have been launched?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three types of incidents are of main interest in protecting the platforms in Bass Strait. They are the damage that occurs by the elements, that is, weather; the damage that could occur by accident or misadventure; and the damage that could occur by terrorism or, at the least, vandalism. Because of the risks to life and also to the supply of fuel to this country, very considerable steps have been taken. The first is that over the last year or so a great deal of strengthening of the platforms has taken place. Although the legs are pinned down through the centre 250 feet, I think, into the seabed-unlike the floating rigs on the North Sea-nevertheless, extra protection has been provided to make them stand up to what is called the 100-year wave- something of some dimensions. Secondly, a great deal of worry has occurred about the danger of collision by vessels-particularly larger vessels-in Bass Strait. Under international law a vessel is prohibited only from going within 500 metres of such an installation. Honourable senators will realise that a large vessel under way, or losing its steerage way, would find itself unable to dodge within 500 metres. So, steps have been taken through my Department and through the Government to get an international agreement that there be at least five miles clearance by sea-going vessels--
—It is about 8 1/2 kilometres.

—Senator Lewis is right. Even five miles allows only a reasonable safety margin for a very big ore carrier or container vessel. We hope that that requirement will be put fully in position soon. It is being largely observed now. I stress 'largely observed' because there were some breaches. There were two reported breaches recently. Neither case put at risk the platforms. It may well be that, had the visibility and the weather been different, there may have been some degree of risk. Both those incidents are being pursued. I have indicated to my own Department and, through it, to the Department of Transport-I know my colleague the Transport Minister holds the same view-that we should take the sternest view of any breaches by vessels. There is also now a prohibited area for smaller vessels under 200 tonnes so that there is an area around the platform that is to be free of all vessels. That, of course, has some difficulties because it is a fishing area. Radar and other surveillance equipment has been fitted. As to terrorism, the honourable senator will appreciate that I will not go into details in this matter.
—Because you cannot, that is why. That is the irritating part of it. You create situations of terrorism where no such situations exist.

—Senator Georges says: 'Because you cannot'. I will say what I can without breaching security. As Senator Georges may know, or ought to know, there has been regular Royal Australian Air Force surveillance over the rigs. Because we cannot, Senator Georges? Senator Georges must also know that, tragically, a young life was lost the other day because Special Air Service personnel were undergoing training to save those rigs from terrorism, not because we cannot but because we have taken steps to safeguard these rigs. I will not go into the details of the surveillance schemes, including naval vessels and other surveillance schemes. Suffice to say that the various defence services and intelligence services, as well as the civil police, have been consulted, and surveillance and defensive methods have been set up which the Government believes would be effective weapons in the case of aggression. One has to say that one would hope that that would not be so. It is the height of stupidity for someone to ask me to state what are the preventive methods. Anybody who knows these matters knows that it invites the unintelligent in this community to test them, and that is a provocation on its own. As to the strengthening of the platforms, the attempt to avoid collision and the prevention of terrorism, a very great deal has been done indeed and more will be done if there is evidence that it should be done.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport.

—It will be beyond Senator Georges's notice, too. Could the Minister advise the Senate on the progress made by the committee appointed to explore the future of Trans Australia Airlines with reference to its sale or reconstitution as a public company? When is the final report expected?

—The Government is, of course, preparing for the implementation of the Australian National Airlines Repeal Act 1981. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. What data is currently available on the unemployment rate and the vacancy rate in particular occupations? Is there any regular data series for this purpose? Will the changeover to the Job Bond computerised system in the Commonwealth Employment Service make it possible to extract data on the number of unemployed persons and vacancies in particular occupations at regular intervals? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

As far as the availability of data is concerned, many honourable senators would be aware of the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which are released by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and which give some details of the number of persons who look for full time work or part time work and of the seasonally adjusted figures that he provides when he makes such a statement. As far as some of the other things that have been requested by Senator Foreman are concerned, I could see whether there is available further detailed information that is not always immediately released, as are the Australian Bureau of Statistics unemployment figures. If some information is available, perhaps I could treat the honourable senator's question as being a question on notice and provide an answer in that form.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, follows a question asked by Senator Button earlier today relating to the sale of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. In view of the fact that the principal recommendation of the majority report of the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories-the committee appointed to inquire into the future of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory-was for the sale of that Factory as a going concern, can the Minister advise the Senate whether the considerable delay in such a sale caused by the appointment and inquiry of the Senate Select Committee has resulted in any difficulties for the Government in its ongoing negotiations with potential buyers?

I understand that this was a matter that may have been seen as rather discouraging by some potential purchasers. The Senate's intervention certainly has not advanced the matter. Clearly it has held it up. As I said earlier in Question Time, I will be interested to see what progress has been made in my absence from this place in terms of responding to the suggestions of the Senate Committee. —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, follows the question just asked by Senator Crichton-Browne. —I do not recollect the precise details of the vote but, as I recall it, it was settled that the Senate would refer the matter to a committee and there was little point in opposing the inevitable.
—We didn't have the numbers.
—Come on.

—The Australian Labor Party seems to think it is quite irrelevant whether we have the numbers. I can assure it that any time it would like to offer me a majority I will promise to take advantage of it in the fullest way. I am not aware of what Sir Phillip Lynch wrote at the time. I will make some inquiry of him to see whether the point made by the honourable senator is correct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

—I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: Is it a fact that the Northern Territory Department of Health plans to withdraw the services of European sisters from Aboriginal communities and to leave the provision of health services in the hands of Aboriginal health workers? If this is a fact, would the Minister not agree that this practice might be premature at this stage ? What steps will he take to ensure that adequate health care is available in Aboriginal communities for both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people who live there?

—One of the difficulties in implementing a health policy for Aboriginal people is to work out the proper rate at which these should be Aboriginalised and at which Aboriginal people should be able to take control of the services in their communities. I know that the Northern Territory Government has been anxious to try to increase Aboriginal control as well as Aboriginal participation. Not only has it a training program for Aboriginal health workers but also it has consulted with a number of communities and is prepared to agree to those communities taking full control in different areas as a result of consultation between the Northern Territory Government and the communities. Senator Robertson's concern is that the rate of that transfer may be inappropriate. I think that is the kind of question which the Northern Territory Government is trying to address with the communities involved. If the honourable senator could indicate particular communities where he thinks an inappropriate decision may be imminent or where one may have been taken, I would be happy to pass the information on to Mr Tuxworth. I know it is Mr Tuxworth's great concern that there should be a smooth transition, that it should not proceed at a rate which is inappropriate for the communities and that it should be directed towards obtaining the best health care and the best standard for the Aboriginals .

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I will provide the Minister with some information. Would he, as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, see whether there are at least one or two persons of sufficient level to take over the services rather than just four health workers? I do not think I have to elaborate on the grade structure that he knows exists within the health workers' scheme.

—It may be appropriate for me to take up that matter with Mr Tuxworth and to explore with him the situation that does exist, and the possibilities, with a view to getting the best result for the communities.
—Can the Minister for National Development and Energy say whether the $1 levy, introduced on the export of steaming coal, has indeed affected the exports of that product?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some comments by the coal producers that the levy has reduced the profitability of their enterprise. But there is no suggestion that it has reduced the output. The output of steaming coal has increased perceptibly. Its limitations at this moment are not so much the profitability as the ability to get the coal through the ports, particularly in New South Wales. As honourable senators know, there is, in fact, a quota system on ships, particularly in New South Wales at this moment, so that what is now known as 'Wran's navy' is standing off-shore. Ships are quotarised to come in- shore as the availability to load occurs. This, of course, is costing an enormous amount-something in the order of $1.5m and $2m a day in demurrage costs alone. It is costing an enormous amount in the loss of export income. But whilst there has been some slowing down in the world demand for steaming coal, there will be projected a steady increase in that demand in the years ahead. Australia has great opportunities provided that it has the capacity through its ports to export that coal. One hopes that these bottlenecks which are now, perhaps, one of our most serious export limitations will be removed in quick time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRE-FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF A URANIUM ENRICHMENT INDUSTRY IN AUSTRALIA
PRE-FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF A URANIUM ENRICHMENT INDUSTRY IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 February this year, during the resumption of debate on a paper by the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia entitled 'Pre-feasibility Study for Establishment of a Uranium Enrichment Industry in Australia', I undertook to have a paper prepared and incorporated in Hansard on the substance of an article in the National Times which was referred to by Senator Chipp. The paper is fairly lengthy. Therefore, I do not seek to read it. But since it relates to an answer to a question, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
—Has it been shown to the Opposition for approval for incorporation?
—There is no necessity for answers to questions to be shown.
—It is not an answer to a question; it is information being supplied.
—The answer is no, it has not been shown.
—I see. We will remember that when the same comment comes from your side.

—Mr President, as I understand it, quite clearly the Opposition has said that it wants two things. INTRODUCTORY NOTE

This paper deals with the United States research and development program in laser isotope separation technology for plutonium and suggestions that civil plutonium might be used for nuclear weapons. The paper demonstrates how the provisions of the Australia/United States Agreement on the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy signed on 5 July 1979 protect Australia's interest in ensuring that any nuclear material we supply to the United States under the Agreement is not diverted to military or explosive purposes.
A. BACKGROUND

Official references in the United States: 2. The United States Department of Energy (DOE) is responsible for both peaceful uses of nuclear energy and production of nuclear material for defence purposes. On 4 March 1981, in testimony in closed session before the Procurement and Military Nuclear Systems Sub-Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Armed Services, Dr F. Charles Gilbert, Acting Deputy Assistant Secretary for Nuclear Materials, U.S. Department of Energy, revealed that the United States had a research and development program for laser isotope separation of plutonium to remove isotopes higher than plutonium-239 from reactor-grade plutonium so that weapon-grade plutonium could be produced. This testimony did not become available in the United States until about July 1981, when an edited transcript was released. The testimony was given in support of a general 1982 fiscal year Budget request for continuation of the existing U.S. special isotope separation research and development program at the level of the 1981 fiscal year. The matter became the subject of press attention in August 1981.

3. A hearing by the Oversight and Investigations Sub-Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs was held on 1 October 1981, to consider public comments about the possible use of spent reactor fuel as a source of weapons-grade plutonium. Dr Thomas B. Cochran ( Natural Resources Defence Council, Inc) made a statement at the hearing. He testified that he was a member of the Energy Research Advisory Board of the U.S. Department of Energy and his statement included the following paragraph:

'On September 3, 1981, the Secretary of Energy endorsed the use of commercial spent fuel as a source of plutonium for the weapons program in a speech before the DOE Energy Research Advisory Board. Secretary Edwards stated that such a move would provide the plutonium needed for both the weapons program and the breeder reactor program. He also claimed that it would solve the nuclear industry's waste disposal problem.'
Congressman Edward J. Markey, the Chairman of the Sub-Committee, corroborated at this hearing Dr Cochran's remarks about the suggestion made by Dr Edwards:

'Energy Secretary James Edwards suggested on September 3, 1981, to the Energy Research Advisory Board that we could solve our alleged plutonium shortfall for bombs, as well as our growing nuclear waste disposal problem, in one fell swoop. What Secretary Edwards meant was that we could take nuclear spent fuel from commercial power plants and chemically reprocess that nuclear waste to separate out the uranium and plutonium. Then, late in the 1980s, we can utilise a new laser isotope separation technology-now in R & D study at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory-to upgrade reactor-grade plutonium to weapons-grade plutonium. By DOE alchemy, nuclear waste would supply plutonium for the weapons program'. Mr Markey also stated: 'If the DOE is permitted by Congress and the American people to take the crucial step of mining nuclear spent fuel for bombs, we will reforge overnight the links between civil and military nuclear activities that U.S. policy has laboured hard to sever for the past 20 years . . . I believe that so perilous a policy will be decisively repudiated by Congress. It will meet a bipartisan buzzsaw of opposition on Capitol Hill.'

4. Since the press reports of August 1981, United States officials have stated publicly that no decision has been taken on this matter and that the idea floated by Secretary Edwards is only one of a number of possibilities under consideration as a solution to a potential shortfall later this decade of plutonium for the U.S. nuclear weapons program.

5. At a press briefing on 8 October 1981, the following exchange took place with the U.S. Secretary of Energy, Dr Edwards, after he had made some remarks about reprocessing spent nuclear fuel to obtain plutonium for breeder reactors:
Q. Do you anticipate using any of that plutonium in the nuclear weapons program ?
SECRETARY EDWARDS: Not at this stage, no.
Q. When do you expect to make that decision?
SECRETARY EDWARDS: That would be a decision that would have to be debated extensively and would have to be decided at a higher level than even the Secretary of Energy.
Q. How are you inclined on that question?
SECRETARY EDWARDS: I have no inclination at this stage. I haven't studied it enough.
Q. You said it's a very good idea, Mr Secretary. You're all for it, it sounds like.
SECRETARY EDWARDS: I didn't say it was a very good idea, I think . . .
Q. You said it's the best way to proceed.
SECRETARY EDWARDS: It is a way to proceed, I think it . . . I'm not sure of the verbage (sic), but it is a good way to proceed. There's no question about that.

You have to upgrade the plutonium, of course. The plutonium you get out of reprocessing spent fuel rods is a poor quality plutonium. You'd have to upgrade it and the technologies for that aren't very well developed yet, so it's a long way off.'
6. At a hearing on 19 November 1981, before the Sub-Committee on Energy, Nuclear Proliferation and Government Processes of the U.S. Senate Government Affairs Committee:

Mr James Malone (Assistant Secretary of State for Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs) stated in relation to the possibility of use of commercial spent power reactor fuel in nuclear weapons that the United States ''Administration has made no decision on the feasibility or desirability of using plutonium from such fuel for military purposes; nor are any recommendations for decision pending before us.''
Dr F. Charles Gilbert (Acting Deputy Assistant Secretary for Nuclear Materials, Defence Programs, U.S. Department of Energy) stated, inter alia:
'At this time, plutonium isotope separation technology has not been demonstrated on a practical scale.'

'In summary, I want to emphasise that we are evaluating many possible options for nuclear materials productions to assure that the needs of the United States, both in the governmental and industrial sectors, are considered in the most cost beneficial ways within an appropriate schedule. Any options, which might be recommended by the Department of Energy in the future would be considered at the highest governmental levels before being forwarded to Congress by the Administration. Such determinations would consider domestic institutional issues , foreign policy implications, including appropriate provisions of applicable international agreements and our non-proliferation objectives, as well as technical, cost and schedule factors.'
'No decision has been proposed to utilise the plutonium from commercial reactor fuels in nuclear weapons.'

7. The New York Times of 28 February 1982, quoted Dr Gilbert as saying that the U.S. Administration 'would not require' and 'has no intention of using' fuel from commercial nuclear reactors in the U.S. nuclear weapons program. It also reported that Dr Gilbert said that the Department of Energy 'was exploring the acceleration of a program designed to use lasers to separate plutonium from nuclear fuel. But he stressed that this controversial technique, if accelerated, would not be used to separate plutonium from commercial reactor fuel, only from military supplies.'

8. There has been a number of legislative proposals in the United States Congress designed to prohibit the U.S. Department of Energy from obtaining plutonium for nuclear weapons purposes from spent nuclear fuel from commercial nuclear power reactors. An example is Bill S.1812, introduced on 4 November 1981 , by Senator Percy, which was intended to prevent the transfer of irradiated fuel and special nuclear material from any reactor licensed by the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission for use in a nuclear explosive device unless the President makes certain determinations and the Congress acts favourably to approve such action.
9. In the Congressional testimony of 19 November 1981, referred to in paragraph 6 above, Dr Gilbert of the U.S. Department of Energy said in relation to S.1812:
'We believe this bill would, in effect, unilaterally constrain future U.S. defence options. For this and other reasons . . . we consider its enactment inadvisable.'

10. In summary, laser isotope separation technology for plutonium is understood to be still in the early stages of development in the United States. It is understood that the United States Government has made no decision to make nuclear weapons with plutonium obtained from civilian power plants nor is any recommendation to do so at present before it.
B. AUSTRALIAN ATTITUDE

11. The Government has been closely following this matter since the edited transcript of the Congressional testimony of March 1981 referred to in paragraph 2 became publicly available. A copy of the Congressional transcript was secured and studied in Canberra.

12. On 28 October 1981, the Australian Embassy in Washington, on instructions, discussed the issues raised in the transcript with the United States authorities . The Embassy referred to the importance of maintaining a clear distinction between the peaceful and military uses of nuclear energy in the interests of upholding the international nuclear non-proliferation regime. It also drew the attention of US officials to the fact that all uranium supplied to the United States by Australia under the Agreement between Australia and the United States of America Concerning Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy, signed on 5 July 1979, is subject to a peaceful, non-explosive use pledge. The Embassy also informed the United States authorities of the Australian Government's concern about any possibility of plutonium separated from spent nuclear fuel from civil nuclear power stations being used for nuclear weapons.

13. On 18 February 1982, the Minister for Foreign Affairs provided answers to House of Representatives Questions No. 3672 ('Use of Civil Plutonium for Nuclear Weapons') and No. 3674 ('Laser Isotope Separation of Plutonium')-see House of Representatives Hansard, 18 February 1982, page 411. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has also answered two further questions of relevance: House of Representatives Question No. 4030 ('Australia/United States Nuclear Safeguards Agreement') and Senate Question No. 1853 ('Nuclear Safeguards Policy').
14. These replies indicated that:
the United States Government had made no decision to use for military purposes plutonium obtained from civilian power plants;
the Australian Government understands from official United States testimony that plutonium isotope separation technology has not been demonstrated on a practical scale in the United States;
the Australian Government considered that it is important to maintain a clear distinction between the peaceful and military use of nuclear energy;
in October 1981, the Australian Government had expressed to the United States Administration its concern about any possibility of civil plutonium being used for nuclear weapons; and

the Australian Government would not be prepared to approve such use of plutonium derived from Australian uranium, as all uranium supplied to the United States under the agreement of 5 July 1979, is subject to a peaceful, non- explosive use pledge.
C. 'NATIONAL TIMES' ARTICLE OF10-16 JANUARY 1982

15. This section addresses the article with particular reference to points raised by Senators Chipp and Mason in the Senate on 18 February 1982, during the debate on tabling of a paper by the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia entitled 'Pre-Feasibility Study for the Establishment of a Uranium Enrichment Industry in Australia'.

16. Senator Chipp referred to the article in the National Times of 10-16 January 1982. Senator Chipp said 'that the uranium that Australia is selling to the United States now has been reported as being used in the nuclear weapons program of the United States.'

17. In his statement of 24 May 1977, on the Government's nuclear safeguards policy, the Prime Minister said that Australia wanted assurance from nuclear- weapon States that nuclear material Australia may supply to them for peaceful purposes is not diverted to military or explosive purposes and that IAEA safeguards will be applied to the nuclear material. The Australia/US nuclear safeguards agreement of 5 July 1979, incorporates the basic undertaking-common to all Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements-that Australian uranium supplied for peaceful purposes will not be diverted to military or explosive purposes. The agreement provides that Australian-origin nuclear material cannot be reprocessed without Australian prior consent or transferred from the United States without Australia's prior consent. Furthermore, it provides for the application of IAEA safeguards to all Australian-origin nuclear material in the United States, and for an effective mechanism for verifying these commitments through the accounting of all Australian-origin nuclear material in the United States. The text of the agreement was presented in the Parliament on 23 August 1979.
18. It is therefore not correct to say, as the article does:

'But if the Reagan Administration goes ahead with its proposal, a key element of Australia's safeguards agreement with the US on nuclear energy would be nullified because the by-products of Australian uranium could be used to produce weapons-grade plutonium without Australia being informed.'

19. The United States is bound by its bilateral agreement with Australia to the peaceful, non-explosive use of nuclear material subject to it. The United States would also need Australia's prior consent before spent nuclear fuel subject to the agreement could be reprocessed. Because of the substantial resources expended on its production, the only logical use of significant amounts of weapons-grade plutonium (that is, plutonium consisting of about 94% or greater of the isotope plutonium-239) made by laser isotope separation of plutonium separated from nuclear power reactor fuel is the military one of construction of nuclear explosive devices. By contrast, reactor-grade plutonium (in which plutonium-239 is contaminated by higher plutonium isotopes) can be used directly for peaceful purposes in energy production without the need for isotope separation, whether by lasers or otherwise. The Minister for Foreign Affairs stated on 18 February 1982 in reply to a question on notice, that the Australian Government would not be prepared to approve the extraction of plutonium from Australian-origin nuclear material on behalf of the United States Government for use in United States nuclear weapons (House of Representatives Hansard, 18 February 1982, p. 411).
20. Senator Chipp quoted the following sentence from the National Times article :
'A move by the Reagan Administration to make nuclear weapons with plutonium from civilian power plants threatens to seriously embarrass the Fraser Government over its uranium export policy.'
The terms of the nuclear safeguards agreement between Australia and the United States as explained above demonstrate that this statement is without foundation.
21. Senator Chipp said that the gist of what worried him in the article was the section saying:

'The idea that plutonium from commercial nuclear reactors should be used in nuclear warheads comes from the US Energy Secretary, James Edwards. In a speech late last year to a research board of the Department of Energy in Washington he proposed that spent nuclear fuel from nuclear reactors be reprocessed and the plutonium extracted and used for both nuclear weapons and the proposed new fast- breeder reactors.

'The Edwards proposal came soon after disclosures that research on the use of lasers to enrich uranium was also being directed towards extracting bomb-quality plutonium from waste in commercial reactors.
'The revelations have sparked a furore in the US. One Democratic Senator, Gary Hart, who is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, wrote to Edwards warning:

'The very consideration of such a plan undermines the historic basic assumptions of the Atoms for Peace program: that a clear distinction exists between the military and commercial applications of nuclear technology.'

22. The possibility of use for nuclear weapons of plutonium produced in civil nuclear reactors has given rise to spirited opposition in the United States. Some of the Congressional opposition has been referred to in paragraphs 3 and 8 above. The New York Times commented in part in an editorial on 30 September 1981 :

'Most of all, there is no good reason to use civilian reactor waste as the raw material. Even if there is a shortage ahead of weapons-grade plutonium-and that' s not certain-it could be solved faster by taking military reactors out of mothballs, or building a new one. More expensive, perhaps: but that is an issue of dollars, not defence.'

23. As is clear from the background given in paragraphs 2-10 above, no decision has been made by the United States Administration to use for military purposes plutonium produced in civil nuclear power stations, nor is any recommendation for decision pending before it. The Australian Government understands from official United States testimony that plutonium isotope separation technology has not been demonstrated on a practical scale.
Canberra,
23 March 1982

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a latter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to achieve and sustain annual growth rates of 4 per cent or above in order to reduce unemployment.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless real gross domestic product-that is, the volume, the heap of goods and services in total-rises by around 4 per cent each year unemployment will rise. That statement is a truism. It is a truism because, firstly, the population of working age-that is, between 15 and 65-increases by around 2 per cent each year and will continue to do so into the mid-1980s; and secondly, because productivity-that is the amount produced for any given unit of working time-also increases by around 2 per cent each year. Therefore, unless growth rises by 4 per cent the number of unemployed must increase. In only one of the last six years of the Fraser Government has growth reached that 4 per cent minimum level-I am talking here of calendar years. I will be making comparisons later with other Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries. That level was reached in 1976 when the economy was still under the influence of the 1975 Hayden Budget which was a Budget of economic recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: Given those facts it is inevitable that recorded unemployment will increase as it has done from 4.8 per cent to 6.2 per cent in 1981. Real unemployment, that is, recorded and unrecorded, is now of course, much higher than 6.2 per cent. I will explain the reasons for the discrepancy at a later stage if I have time. The response of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the empirical record of his failure in government-most recently expressed in his 14 March electorate broadcast-is an amalgam of bluster and falsification of history. I quote from that broadcast. The Prime Minister stated:

That our policies were right, that the right policies and attitudes can enable us to succeed against world trends, is convincingly demonstrated by Australia's economic performance in recent years. For we have had economic growth at twice the average of other major industrialised countries in recent years . . .
That assertion is false. The more precise assertion contained in the OECD economic survey of Australia released in January 1982 states:
Since 1978, real GDP has increased at more than twice the average rate for the OECD area as a whole . . .
That statement is also false, a fact grudingly conceded by the Secretary to the Treasury, John Stone, in his 1 April letter to me. Mr Stone's letter stated:
. . . my very quick examination of the facts suggests that there is substance in your opinion as to its inaccuracy . . .

In conceding the falsity of the OECD claim the Secretary to the Treasury implicitly repudiated the Prime Minister's less precise regurgitation of that claim in his 14 March electorate broadcast. It raises many questions, one of which I will now put. If the Australian Labor Party, with the limited resources of Opposition, can detect errors in the January publication about Australia which are subsequently acknowledged by the OECD, why does the Prime Minister, with all the resources and expertise of the Treasury and other departments of government, regurgitate a false assertion nearly two months after it is published?

Since 1976 Australia has not, as the Goebbels clones of this Government assert ad nauseam, had a good economic record relative to other comparable countries. Australia's record from 1974 to 1976 inclusive, relative to the rest of the OECD countries, was good. Since 1976 real growth-that is, real increase in gross domestic product-relative to the rest of the OECD countries has been poor. Compared with individual countries in the OECD, such as Japan, Austria, West Germany, the Netherlands, Norway and others, not only has it been poor but also it has been miserable, especially when considered in association with the relative unemployment rates of Australia and those other countries. At this stage, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which I have prepared from OECD publications showing the real increase in gross domestic product and the unemployment rate in Australia, the OECD as a whole and certain OECD countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —That table shows that, relative to the OECD countries as a whole and, in particular, to a few individual OECD countries, Australia's record of real economic growth and of unemployment has been poor to miserable. Its record of real growth per capita-a slightly different concept which is to some degree normally related to the level of unemployment-is even worse but that is not shown in the table. From the Cabinet and from the Prime Minister in particular we have had newspeak ad nauseam. From that table we get the empirical facts. The stated intention of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) a fortnight ago to come clean with the Australian people about the state of the economy is certainly a worthy intention. As a first step towards that commendable objective, I suggest that the Prime Minister should desist from mouthing the type of newspeak he mouthed on 14 March.

SPEECH.PARA: The corollary of our miserable level of economic growth is rising unemployment and/or a relative decline in real incomes. Both of these things have happened in Australia. The magnitude of our fall from affluence was shown in some detail in the National Times of 11 April to 17 April. That newspaper published a table showing relative changes in the per capita income of Australia and 13 other rich countries. By 1979-the last year shown in that table-Australia had fallen to fourth last in that group of 14 countries. Since then Japan's real per capita income has passed Australia's and we are now third last. Only the United Kingdom and Italy, of those 13 other relatively weathy industrialised countries, have lower real per capita incomes than does Australia. Compare that with the prime ministerial assertions of six weeks ago that our policies are right, our policies are working and so on.

Even if we do not value the higher real incomes which come from higher real economic growth-I add as an aside that such sentiments are expressed normally by the already affluent and particularly by the already affluent in the non-market sector of the economy where their incomes are protected regardless of whether we can sustain economic growth, at least in the short term-surely nobody, surely not even this Government, actually wants higher unemployment. Unless we can achieve that 4 per cent growth rate unemployment will go up. It is technically feasible to argue to the contrary; that is, that a growth rate of less than 4 per cent or even no growth rate at all will not result in higher unemployment if the same amount of work is spread over more people, which inevitably entails lower real incomes for those who are employed. But that will not happen, so that can be disregarded.

What can be done? The common denominator in those countries which have had throughout the late 1960s and right up to the latest available statistics a satisfactory record of growth, unemployment and, I might add, low inflation- countries such as Japan, West Germany, Austria, the Netherlands and Norway-is an effective prices and incomes policy regardless of whether it is called that. This Government, of course, is opposed to prices and incomes policies on purely doctrinal grounds. Some call its policy mon- grelised monetarism. It probably would be more accurate to describe it as Fraser's eccentricity and political cynicism along with assorted Country Party villanies superimposed on a foundation of stone age economics. The Prime Minister says in other context-even in this context he once said this-that the runs are on the board. In this instance the runs are clearly not on the board. We are steadily sliding down the batting average, to continue the Prime Minister's analogy. We are third last of a group of 14 wealthy industrialised countries and we are still slipping down. We have been passed by Japan. If present trends continue, we are about to be passed by a number of other South East Asian countries. Surely with that sort of record anyone must ask whether the batting techniques should be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the captain should be dropped.

—Perhaps the captain should be dropped, and he will be. Even if the Fraser Government was not doctrinally opposed to prices and incomes policies , it probably could not succeed in implementing a prices and incomes policy because, by the nature of our Constitution, Federal governments have little coercive power in this respect. A social concensus has to be achieved and for that a government must have moral authority. This Government does not have and cannot have moral authority, for a multiplicity of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, there are its own origins. There has been a string of broken promises. The Prime Minister promised growth at the rate of 5 per cent to 7 per cent a year. The highest he has achieved in any year is 4.6 per cent and the average since 1976 is 2.1 per cent. He promised to maintain Medibank. He promised to introduce tax indexation. He promised lower taxes. He promised ministerial propriety. Instead of that he has given us 20 resignations, sackings or induced removals, nearly all of them under a cloud of impropriety. He continues to give us such senior Ministers as Mr Lynch and Mr Sinclair and a Deputy Prime Minister who continues to squat on a 4 3/4 per cent housing loan secured from public funds, while everyone else in the community pays 15 per cent or thereabouts. The Prime Minister's wife and her relatives, apparently in defiance of the law of Victoria, secured a $50,000 loan at 4 1/2 per cent four years ago. Presumably, that loan has not been repaid. This Government has a record of treachery without parallel in Australian history or possibly in the history of any twentieth century democracy.

This Government has neither the will to do what must be done nor the moral authority to succeed even if it had the will. If acceptable rates of growth and acceptable rates of unemployment are to be reattained, this Government must go, and it will go. High economic growth, which I repeat is a pre-requisite for the restoration of full employment, can be sustained in authoritarian countries, as Professor Gruen pointed out a couple of weeks ago. It can also be sustained-and it has been sustained-in industrialised democracies, in countries such as the Netherlands, Japan, Austria and West Germany. In those countries, through the latter half of the 1970s and the early part of the 1980s, that has actually been achieved. Surely there are lessons for Australia to learn from that empirical fact. A not exhaustive list of those lessons includes the necessity to maintain aggregate demand at full employment levels and the necessity to achieve a social consensus. In present conditions, full employment demands entail a danger of fuelling higher and rising inflation. A prices and incomes policy will contain inflation. It has contained inflation in other countries which have maintained full employment levels of aggregate demand.

A social consensus is a prerequisite for a prices and incomes policy. It is also an aid to growth-an end in itself. A social consensus cannot be achieved unless a government has moral authority. I do not pretend that it will be easy to achieve a social consensus or the prices and incomes policy which could flow from it and which, in turn, could at least restore the rates of economic growth which Australia experienced in the 1960s and the rates of economic growth which are esential if real income is to continue to rise at the levels desired by most Australians and if unemployment is to be reduced to a level which is acceptable to most Australians. The pre-requisite to that happier state of affairs being achieved is the removal from office of a dogma-bound government which has no remaining credibility and can never gain any moral authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are indebted to Senator Walsh and the Opposition for proposing for discussion today this matter of public importance so that we can put on record and make perfectly clear what have been the outstanding successes of this Government since it came to office in 1975. Senator Lajovic will address himself to the problems relating to the industrial scene, and, on a later occasion, Senator Hamer will be discussing the huge potential for investment in this country and the opportunities that abound for us if we are prepared to grasp that potential. I wish to deal with some of the points made a few minutes ago by Senator Walsh and to demonstrate some of the great weaknesses not only in his arguments, but also in those of the Australian Labor Party, which seeks to represent the people in the national Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the first point which Senator Walsh made, that is, that the so- called 4 per cent rate of growth-which seems to have some magic attached to it- is the level which will deliver us from all kinds of evil in terms of unemployment. He claims that that is some mere truism. He has not told us in the terms of the matter of public importance that he proposed in his letter to the President whether he was speaking of growth in domestic product, job growth or of any other kind of growth. I take it from the general run of his argument that he was speaking of monetary growth and, consequently, of a 4 per cent growth in real terms in the money supply. That, of course, is substantially greater than the Government has seen fit to aim for in the past few years as it has been trying to contain the pressures in this economy which cause inflation. He well knows that that growth rate has been maintained by purposeful control by this Government at a level of approximately one per cent in real terms in order to bear down on inflation, which is the utter curse of this economy and the source of difficulty which led Senator Walsh's Government into economic disgrace when it was in power between 1972 and 1975. I will return to that question a little later.

It is perfectly clear from all the information that is available that in the last three years of this Government the number of jobs that have been created in this economy has risen by more than 300,000. During that period we have seen the maintenance of a generally flat level of unemployment with an inclination for that level to decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—Over the last three years. Senator Walsh is interested in the figures. In the year ended 1978-79, the level of unemployment was of the order of 6.3 per cent whereas the given figure for the year ending 1980-81 was 5.8 per cent. That represents a decline of some one half of one per cent. One might not make too much out of that point, but it certainly flies in the face of the argument which Senator Walsh seeks to make, namely, that unemployment has not been addressed by the kinds of policies employed by this Government over the last five years. If we look a little further at the rates of growth in gross domestic product in this country compared with those in member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-certainly Senator Walsh made a great deal of this-we find that in the last three years Australia's rate of growth has ranged between 3 per cent and 3.5 per cent, being 2.5 per cent in 1980. This compares with a growth rate in the United States over a period of 10 years of 3 per cent. In 1980 there was an actual negative growth rate of 0.2 per cent. In 1981, the latest year, for which we have figures, there was an indicative rate in that country of 1.75 per cent. That compares with the figure of 3 per cent applying in the Australian economy.

—Yes, it is an estimate. In 1980 West Germany had a rate of growth of 1.8 per cent. It had a negative growth rate of one per cent in 1981. I acknowledge that that figure is again an estimate but when we compare it with the 3 per cent growth rate that has occurred in the Australian economy in the 1981 financial year, can we assume that the kind of argument which Senator Walsh seeks to put forward has any validity whatsoever? We could continue with that kind of analysis in detail. I cite the example of France which elected a socialist government half-way through 1981. In 1980 France had a moderate growth rate of 1.2 per cent, but in the last year in which, apparently, stimulative socialist policies were employed by the new Mitterrand Government in Paris, there was a growth rate of a mere 0.5 per cent.
—They were Walsh policies.

—They were Walsh policies, consistent with the kinds of policies which the Australian Labor Party has been advocating, if one is ever able to sort out the mumbo-jumbo that emanates from various spokesmen on the other side. I suppose that I should also cite the example of the United Kingdom where there have been negative growth rates of the order of 2 per cent in each of the last two years. Again, I make the point that the growth in the Australian economy during the last year has been 3 per cent. Where is the evidence for Senator Walsh's remarks that the Australian economy is slipping into disaster as a result of the kind of policies which the Fraser Government has been employing?
—He has a fevered imagination.
—Of course. I might say that not even the prestigious Canberra Times newspaper agrees with the points made by Senator Walsh. Its editorial of 16 April 1982 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There are good reasons for remaining composed, quietly spoken, and steady of eye.

I claim that that particular viewpoint is the solid one, the one which we in this nation should be proposing at this time. We should not be listening to the kind of claptrap that emanates from the Labor Party which seeks mere political advancement of its policies to the detriment of the Australian people. It plays on the fears of people who are uninformed generally about the general trend of events not only in this country but also in the world scene. Consequently, it misleads people by its continued reiteration of these kinds of arguments.

The elements of the Australian economy about which we have been speaking are not the only ones with which we should concern ourselves. I have demonstrated in the last few minutes that the rate of growth in our gross domestic product has been very comparable with those of overseas nations-quite the opposite to the kind of argument which has been put forward by Senator Walsh. I come to the major thrust of what he has been saying. I take it that he was talking about-he has not contradicted me-a growth rate in the money supply in real terms of 4 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, real GDP. I said it at least twice.

—Having received that correction, I take it that Senator Walsh was envisaging a money supply growth rate that was prepared to encompass that kind of growth in this economy. If that is so, it is a policy which has not been implemented by this Government in the last few years. I reiterate that the rate of money supply growth in this country has been controlled at a rate of approximately one per cent in real terms over the last few years. What would be the consequences? The evidence is before us. I hesitate to say it again, but it has to be said time and again. There are messages in that period of Labor Government between 1972 and 1975 which show the effects on the economy of the policies which the Opposition seeks to employ. The difficulty that we have at this time--
—Wage rises had something to do with that.

—We will come to that in a moment because it is the main point that I seek to make. Due to wage rises and the unfortunate wage demands that are being imposed upon the economy by the trade union movement, the rate of inflation is higher at the moment that that which is applying in the economies of some of our major trading parteners. Current rates of inflation appear to be 7.7 per cent in the United States, 5.9 per cent in West Germany and 3.1 per cent in Japan. Our inflation rate currently appears to be around 11 per cent. That is not withstanding the very good result for the March quarter which was announced only the other day. I do not wish to lay too much emphaisis on a short term figure such as that; rather I will take the broader view. Our economy is inflating more greatly than the economies of our trading partners. That represents the major danger to our economy at this time. Inflation is growing whereas the inflation rates of our trading partners are declining. We see fewer opportunities for trade, less potential for our export development and, consequently, less opportunity to develop new jobs in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: That is fundamental to an understanding of the economic situation that we face at the moment. Without appreciating that and without, applying the right policies now, we see rocky roads ahead in terms of the rate of inflation and the dangers that has for job creation, which is what this Government's policy is all about. Job destruction will occur with the kinds of policies proposed by the Labor Party because it fails to understand the fundamental considerations relating to inflation, and the effect upon this economy of overseas transactions , and the need for us to take account of overseas cost pressures and the demands that that imposes upon us in so many ways. It leads to more imports flowing into this country and the displacement of workers as a result. It leads to lower exports. Other countries find it easier to sell into our markets because we have a higher cost structure than they have. Those things are fundamental. They are the issues that we have to address and which this Government, by its policies as demonstrated in recent times, continues to address. TALK.START.PARA: —Why haven't you been able to do it so far?
