Certainly my colleague Senator Hamer will be dealing with a few of those points at a later time.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the point that the fundamental issue which we face is that of containing our cost pressures in this economy. They stem very largely from the manner in which we are able to keep our labour costs under control. In recent times we have seen developments in the wage settlement arena which do unnerve us substantially. There has been substantial growth of costs in the building trade, in the metal trades and in public service areas, relating not only to wages and direct remuneration of that kind but also to shorter working hours, as have been negotiated in the metal trades award and in the building trades. These things are important to recognise. Not only could they lead, of course, to greater leisure time for Australians-and in that sense they have their virtue-but also we have to recognise that they must be paid for out of the pockets of the consumers and wage earners who are not getting those benefits and who have to pay the prices in the supermarkets-if we like, the transport costs, the price of gas and power and everything else that they need to consume. This is what the Australian Labor Party fails to understand. Indeed, if we review the history of its three years in government between 1972 and 1975 we can see examples of that quite clearly.

As for the period ahead, this Government remains confident in the basic future of Australia. We know of our huge resources in this country. We know of the need to develop those resources. We know how to do it. The ALP has never been able to demonstrate that it knows how to do it. In fact, that is the very point of this debate. Indeed, the Labor Party has come forward with some airy-fairy figure of 4 per cent which has no relation to anybody else or anything else and which appears to have been thought up as some kind of figment of the imagination of Senator Walsh who has not properly explained whether he speaks of money supply growth, of gross domestic product growth, of job growth or of any other growth. The fact is that it is a vague matter of abolutely no interest to the Senate; nor should it be seriously listened to by the public as meaning anything in particular. It typifies the kind of loose thinking that occurs on the other side of this Senate chamber.

We on this side stand for the development of Australia. We know that it is possible. We know how to do it. We need to ensure lower rates of inflation. We need to ensure that the population of this country is suitably motivated by adequate remuneration but not by disproportionate remuneration which leads to the kinds of inflationary pressures which will destroy our job markets by destroying the markets for our products overseas, particularly those natural resource products which are, of course, turned into consumer products in such countries as Korea and Japan.

I make just one other point because it reinforces my argument. It is something which Senator Walsh mentioned at the close of his speech. He recalled that Japan and South East Asian countries are in fact passing Australia in terms of growth rate. He did not define the kind of growth rate. I assume he means gross domestic product. In that event, that only serves to demonstrate the very point I am making, that those countries, with lower costs and lower inflation, are in fact doing better than countries which have lesser concerns about those matters. It only serves to make the point that Australia, if it continues to grow-and it will grow-must have regard to those fundamental concerns in the economy. This Government is dedicated to that proposition.

The Minister tells us that the situation is not all that bad, that there has been job creation in Australia over the last three years and that we are now much better off than we were three years ago. The fact is that Australia now finds itself with a government which is stagnating both economically and morally. In six years we have had a government blindly pursuing economic theories and strategies which have been proven to have failed throughout the world. They have failed here, they have failed in the United Kingdom and they have failed in the United States of America. In the United Kingdom Thatcherism now stands in tatters. In the United States the third rate cowboy now stands economically exposed by his own strategists. Even they have admitted defeat. Yet in Australia we have a continuation of the performance we saw this afternoon. We have Government spokesmen time and again adhering to the blind philosophy of Fraserism, of the supply side economists. The Government not only does not recognise the deficiencies of its policies, but also is not competent enough to understand them. It has been advocating contractionary monetary policies for seven years. We, as Australians, have experienced the results of these policies. At the end of this period we have little to show for the pursuit of those policies except the following: World-wide we have 30 million people unemployed as a consequence of similar policies and inflation rates are still rampant.

Let us look at the Australian position. What have such policies produced here? As I said, unemployment has increased to over 437,000. As a direct consequence of the Government's open-door policy, interest rates now stand at the highest level in the world. We have the highest real interest rates in the world, and they are rising. Taxation, as it affects wage and salary earners, has more than doubled under this Government and prices are rising at a faster rate this year than they have in any of the last seven years. The anticipated inflation rate is higher than that anticipated in the last Labor Budget. We have a government incompetent enough to assert to us only eight months ago that it had the deficit under control and that there would be a surplus. Eight months later we have a deficit overblown by $1,000m. Not only can the Government not understand the problem, but also it is incompetent in handling it.

The real situation has been expressed not only by Opposition spokesmen but also by members of the Government. In terms of growth Sir William McMahon, a former Liberal Party Prime Minister, said in September 1981:
Non-farm growth slackened to a mere 1.6 per cent in the second half of the year of June 1981 and has shown no signs of recovery since then.
On 26 January 1982 Dr Peter Sheehan of the University of Melbourne said:
The economy is moving to recession with accelerating inflation.
W. D. Scott's journal Economic Advice to Business, once again in January 1982, stated:
The Australian economy is slowing down.

Maybe the Minister is an adherent of the policies of the Premier of South Australia who asserts that South Australia is not going too badly. He stated: South Australia is going backwards at a slower rate and, as a consequence, we are recovering. That is the type of philosophy and logic propounded by Government spokesmen. Under Fraserism, under the policy of cutting back essential Commonwealth Government expenditure, of reducing funds available to the States, of reducing funds available to public instrumentalities and of raising taxes, the economy is contracting. Fraser's monetarism masquerades public sector cutbacks as being economically responsible. Not only are they self -defeating, but also they are economically self-defeating. Tight credit policies increase the price of money and, as a consequence, increase prices generally. As a consequence of monetarism we have high interest rates and rising inflation.

What was the cost to retail sales? Wran's navy is waiting and waiting outside Newcastle. Employment and unemployment were discussed. I wonder what would be an acceptable percentage of members of the work force out of work in today's world, particularly in Australia? The situation is certainly different from what it was 10 to 15 years ago. Even the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations in the other place mentioned somewhere that we will never again achieve the kind of level of employment that we have been used to.

What is the socialist idea of full employment? Is full employment when people are sent to concentration camps or slave labour camps, where they have to perform work which they do not want to perform? Is that the kind of full employment that they want? I wonder how many young people today in Australia who reckon that they are unemployed would prefer to be fully employed in a slave labour camp? The only way that Australia can continue to grow and to have a high standard of living is to continue to present policies of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The average annual rate of growth in Australian gross domestic product declined from 4.9 per cent, during the decade 1963-1964 to 1973-74 to only 2.3 per cent during the period 1973-74 to 1978-79. The rate of growth for the 1981 financial year was 2.9 per cent. So, in recent years we have seen a decline to virtually half of the growth rate of the boom days. It is true that this decline in the rate of growth of the Australian economy has been accompanied by an increase in the level of unemployment, reduced investment and profitability and higher levels of inflation. This has been a world trend. These facts can provide a convenient backdrop to this discussion but what might seem obvious conclusions ought not necessarily be drawn from them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats feel that the Australian Labor Party is attempting to present a rather mechanistic view, one which I think was criticised with some justice by Senator Messner in his comments. We cannot take a simple proposition such as this and present it as a palliative or panacea to even part of the problem of unemployment. However, most matters of public importance that we debate from time to time in this place on the subject of unemployment boil down to a series of pious platitudes about how bad employment is and how something ought to be done about it. I get heartily sick of these flows of words about unemployment and the lack of effective action about it. I suspect so do other honourable senators and I am absolutely convinced that members of the public certainly do. We appear to have a problem here which we are now being told in so many words that it is something we cannot do anything about but wring our hands. Of course that is not good enough.
The topic of this matter of public importance today at least does take the matter to a slightly more definite stage. It is:
The need to achieve and sustain annual growth rates of 4 per cent or above in order to reduce unemployment.

It surprises me, and it surprises the Australian Democrats, that such a naive proposition should be advanced on behalf of the Australian Labor Party by a man as knowledgable and intelligent as Senator Walsh. I wonder whether he seriously believes what he is putting forward. I think he should know that there is no way , on a global basis, that we can go on year after year increasing growth rates for the simple reason that the resources of the planet are finite and rapidly diminishing. Sooner or later this is a problem that will have to be faced and the sooner it is faced the more effective the attitude will be. If it is allowed simply to go on decade after decade we will reach a situation in which there is a planetary crisis of massive proportions. I think this is a matter which cannot be disputed although it is one which is frequently ignored. There is no way the rest of the world can share, even now, anything approaching the standard of living that we have in Australia, without a disastrously rapid running down of resources combined with an increase in pollution and environmental disturbance of ruinous proportions.

I would have thought also that Senator Walsh had observed that an increase in the growth rate, however he measures that, by no means guarantees increased employment. Indeed there is abundant evidence that by automating and robotising industrial processes, which is happening all over the world and increasingly in this country now, we can certainly achieve productivity growth within those industries which we treat that way. However at the same time we will also cause major drops of employment or at the best marginal increases. I will give some examples of what I mean. A few years ago, the Philips organisation, then employing about 425,000 people world-wide, estimated that, even with a 3 per cent real increase in turnover, it would still become 56 per cent over manned. In 1972, 9,051 people-nearly 10,000-were on the manufacturing staff at Hitachi's colour television plants. In 1976, this figure had been reduced to 4,299, less than half the earlier figure. The ironical thing, of course, is that during that time productivity was raised by 25 per cent.

Volkswagen designs its own robots for spot welding and panel handling. It also sells the robots to other manufacturing industries. The robots can be reprogrammed. Three robots can replace 10 men, I am advised, on a two shift system. VW produces twice British Leyland's declared target with 80 per cent of British Leyland's labour force. Australia's largest insurance company, the AMP Society, introduced its first computer in 1959 and has since introduced new technology rapidly. The company's administrative staff increased by only 2.17 per cent. During the same period the number of policies handled increased by 50 per cent and the company's annual premium income grew by 300 per cent. So I think we have some lessons in explicit terms which illustrate that merely to take the simplistic view that by increasing productivity we will solve or even help unemployment is not the case.

There is no need for us to be neo-Luddites, to take the view of the Luddite movement that the only way to answer these things is to smash all the machines. Of course, that was ridiculous at the time and it would be ridiculous now. The problem has to be coped with in other ways because it is good that boring and repetitive work should be done by machines rather than by human beings. It is something we have to accept as an advance in the conditions of life of human beings rather than the reverse.

I am disappointed and the Australian Democrats are disappointed at what would appear to be the view of the Australian Labor Party if this topic is at all representative of its thinking. At best, to promote the proposition to the Australian people that an annual growth rate in productivity of 4 per cent or more will automatically solve or help to solve the unemployment problem, is, I think, nor worthy of a great political party that is offering itself to the electorate as a government. Here again I agree with Senator Messner who touched on this point. He said that there could be tremendous trouble in the economy, perhaps masive inflation, if we attempt to adopt this as a serious policy. If the Labor Party became the government and seriously said that it would insist and somehow devise, if it could, every year, a growth in productivity of 4 per cent or better, I suggest it would create problems worse than we have now. I think it ought to be axiomatic that under present conditions of the world economy and, indeed, the Australian economy, growth in productivity is a difficult enough proposition even it it were possible. Any sort of attempt to say merely that we can get this sort of growth in productivity through some magical means is whistling in the dark.

It would be difficult enough to promote expansion in existing industries and areas of effort. That, of course, is the key to the whole point. If there is a situation in which there are large numbers of unemployed schoolteachers or doctors or technicians, it is rather silly to try to promote employment in those areas. We have to look for new areas. This should mean that the Government ought to be looking at something new-not only one new thing but also a number of new departures, not to be introduced quickly over a year or two, but to be introduced over time as a result of proper examination and planning. Yet, at the same time, as I said earlier, any political movement which will not recognise that we should, even now, be planning for an economy that this planet can sustain is less than responsible. This is a constraint that we all must accept. The Australian Democrats do accept it. We do not pretend, by any means, to have the answers to the total problem. I do not think anybody has. All we are saying is that we should, certainly as a nation, be addressing our minds to it as a matter of urgency with an eye to future planning direction so that we know what we are going to do as this revolution in automation and robotism overwhelms us, as indeed it will do unless we do something about it.

One basic point is, I think, again that if there is overcrowding in most occupations then the only way to increase employment is to look at other things and to try to develop useful areas that are not fully exploited at present. We can gain some lessons in this, wisely, from overseas countries where the trend has been to look at labour-intensive areas of employment, particularly in the energy field. I mentioned in the Senate some years ago, but it is perhaps worth mentioning again now, the Californian experience with what is called Solarcal which is a commission or instrumentality which is designed to do two things: To encourage, in every possible way, the development of solar energy in the State of California in the United States; and, recognising the fact that the manufacture and installation of solar devices is labour-intensive, to increase employment. In the number of years that that program has been going it has been enormously successful. In some places in California now it is illegal to build a new house without putting proper solar installations into it. Also, of course, there is an enormously large program of tax concessions, which I think is the key point because this is the way it is being done.

At the moment the cost of a solar heater is so great that the average young family in Australia will say that it cannot justify the interest on that money in the savings that it will get in electric power. While that situation continues, of course, we will not have these installations in sufficient numbers in Australia. Of course, they have a very important bearing on our energy requirements into the future. They are conservational. That is, or should be, a national intention. In California and in a number of other American States, the subsidy on State and Federal income tax is 55 per cent of the cost of that installation. If that subsidy is not obtained in one year it is obtained in a successive year. It is a direct rebate from one's income tax. This is found to be economical for a number of reasons. One is that it is cheaper to have people provide these installations than to build enormously expensive new thermal or hydro-electric power plants-conservation is the answer. Another is that by employing people-there has been an enormous increase in employment in California because of this-the tax concessions that are given are repaid by the new employment, by the fact that the people who are newly employed are paying tax and that they are not being paid the dole. Documents would be available to this Government from the Californian Energy Commission which would prove this beyond doubt. I have copies of them if the Government wants them. That Commission has done its homework and it knows this works.

I ask and the Australian Democrats ask: Why are we not doing something like that here? There are other areas of the same type. As I mentioned before, we should be looking at fuel cropping. Fuel cropping can be justified as being uneconomic now in terms of the cost of petrol. But it has a certain strategic importance and a certain development importance. It is a new agricultural crop. It would encourage our regional centres. It would provide something which would bolster us against the unmitigated disaster that could be brought to this country if a few shots were fired today or tomorrow in the Saudi Arabian capital of Riyadh. That would be all that would be needed. Within weeks this country would be in sore need of liquid fuel. Our present difficulties would be gravely compounded. And, of course, as our supplies of Bass Strait crude run down over the next 10 years, as we know they will, that risk becomes greater and greater. We could be then engaging people in employment in that respect. We should be doing that sort of thing instead of spending money on useless, expensive military hardware like the billion dollar aircraft carrier Invincible which we are now told will be useless if it does not have further extremely expensive aircraft on it. I tend to agree with that. It would be of limited use even with those aircraft. But without them, of course, it has no practical uses whatsoever other than to fly a flag and to have parties on the quarterdeck. I suspect that is its fundamental purpose.

We should be spending money on major and forward-looking development projects. I respect Sir Mark Oliphant for his grand concept of a pipeline that might bring North West Shelf gas across to the eastern States. Plants to make fuel ethanol from natural gas could be established. There is a five-year lead time. If we had done it five years ago we would have had it on stream this year. These things are possible with established technology. I spoke to a gifted friend of mine today. He mentioned a canal from Port Augusta to Lake Eyre. When one looks at the topography of that area it is a smaller project than many that have been successfully completed elsewhere in the world. I do not say these things should be done; I say they should be explored. A government with vision and forward- looking initiative would be looking boldly and with courage towards development projects that would make this a better country. We should give our priority to spending in that area. By adopting these new areas of work we will provide employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a matter of public importance raised by Senator Walsh, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to achieve and sustain annual growth rates of 4 per cent or above in order to reduce unemployment.

I am pleased that Senator Walsh has raised this issue. The importance of economic growth has been a central part of the policy of the Liberal Party for many years. In fact, for 20 years before 1972 we managed to achieve a balance of low unemployment, low inflation and reasonable growth probably better than any other country. As we all know, and to our intense regret, all that was thrown away in the three years of the Whitlam Government. Economic growth is essential to the achievement of any government's social and other objectives. There is a great deal of evidence that in a democracy the so-called zero sum economy-the no -growth society-is unworkable. In such a society if one wishes to give something to a particular group one has to take it away from another. That group normally resists and resists successfully. The result of that is endemic inflation. If we want to achieve social objectives in a democracy, in my view it is essential that there should be a growing economy.

I am delighted to see the Australian Labor Party converts-admittedly very late converts-to the necessity for economic growth. In the past they would have been anything but that. They would have been influenced by trendy pressure groups of various types and would have appeared to be aiming for a no growth economy. I hope Senator Walsh represents the true opinion of the Labor Party. I must say that I doubt it. The question we must face is not whether growth is desirable; nearly all of us here believe that it is. What we have to look at is how to achieve that. The first thing we must do is control inflation. Senator Messner dealt with that at some length. I will not repeat what he said. Without control of inflation we will not have sustained growth in the economy. Secondly, we must aim for long term growth. This has been one of the successes of this Government. We have laid the foundation for long term growth. It is not good enough to have short term spurts in economic growth. It must be sustained if we are to achieve our objectives in all areas of political activity.

Our approach has been successful. In general, growth-that is non-farm gross domestic product-has accelerated. The growth was 0.8 per cent in 1977-78. It rose to over 2 1/2 per cent in the two following years and to 4 per cent last year. Regrettably-this is the cause of great concern-it has fallen back to 2 1/2 per cent this year, but it is still better than most other countries with similar economies to ours. Because of that growth in GDP in our economy, the rate of unemployment fell throughout 1980 and 1981. The reason that decline has not continued this year is that the growth in the economy resulted in increased wage demands and acceleration in the growth of average weekly earnings. Average weekly earnings rose by 7.2 per cent in 1978-79; 9.4 per cent the next year; 12. 5 per cent in 1980-81 and this year they are expected to rise by 13 1/2 per cent . This means that we are experiencing a sharp acceleration in labour costs at a time when these costs are decelerating in overseas countries-our main competitors. We are thereby losing competitiveness in a world where growth is generally very subdued and where competition is, therefore, very intense. We must tackle this problem of excess wage demands.

Senator Walsh advanced the idea-this does not originate from him-of a social contract on wages. Two points must be made about that. Firstly, no such contract is possible unless there is a broad social consensus throughout the community to make that policy work. Secondly, it is peculiarly difficult in this country because the Federal Government has no power over wages, no power to set a wage structure. Therefore, this type of consensus is particularly important if we wish to have an effective and agreed system of wage fixation. The trouble has been that nearly all the activities of the Labor Party have attempted to destroy this consensus, encouraging people to be selfish, to go it alone and grab what they can while they can. The whole approach has been the very opposite of consensus and it is the most nauseating hypocrisy for members of the Labor Party in the Senate to advocate a social consensus in this direction. We welcome their assistance here and now to achieve such a consensus. If they really believe what they say, that is what they should do.

I will give an example of the sort of activity which has gone on and which has been encouraged by the Opposition. In the United States of America and Great Britain the motor car industry is under considerable threat and pressure. In both those countries-Britain might surprise some people-the management and unions have managed to get together to show restraint in claims for improved wages and conditions. What happened here in the motor car industry when it was under similar pressure? The unions immediately negotiated a shorter working week -down to 38 hours-for the same pay and then looked to the Government to protect their members' jobs. We have to develop this social consensus, but the Labor Party must stop destroying the atmosphere in which such a social consensus is possible. The remark of a former Labor Treasurer, Mr Crean, has been quoted many times in this place. It is worth quoting again because it is a fundamental truth . He said that one man's pay rise costs another man his job. Over recent years the unions have spent the benefits of the resources boom before we have even got it. Even if the resources boom had taken off in the way one hoped it would, it is still five or 10 years down the track before we start getting the benefits. The unions are spending the benefits now in the form of increased and unjustifiable wage demands. Because they are doing this they are creating unemployment. The great social problem in this country is that union managements on the whole do not give a damn about the unemployed. If they can get more for their members, the fact that they are going to be unemployed as a consequence of their action's does not seem to concern them at all. This is not the case with all union leaders, but too many of them take that attitude.

Let us come back to the problem of what we must do to achieve growth. If we are going to have economic growth, we must have more investment, because it is from investment that economic growth comes. Where does investment come from? The great proportion of it comes from profits. If the Labor Party is serious about encouraging economic growth it should be encouraging profits and not discouraging, criticising and ridiculing profits. From profits comes investment and from investment comes increased economic growth.

The other area where investment for economic growth comes from is from savings and overseas investment. In the area of overseas investment, members of the Labor Party take the most negative attitude-criticising, denigrating and opposing it. If they really believe the thrust of the matter of public importance brought forward today by Senator Walsh, they should be encouraging it . I do not believe they do believe it. Even if we do have investment-just investment is enough-it must be directed in the areas which will be most productive for the Australian economy. There is no doubt at all that the market- place-what people want-is the right place to decide investment. Government intervention is nearly always harmful. Can one imagine a more interventionist government than the previous Labor government or what would happen if Labor were ever trusted with power again? We must look to ways to reduce government intervention in investment. The key area in this is a reduction in protection. Protection is a means by which governments direct investment into particular areas. I think we can see from the record that this has not been a very successful intervention. The Government's White Paper on the Manufacturing Industry of 1977 stated:

There is now a growing recognition in Australia of the adverse effects on economic growth that can result from pressing import-substitution beyond levels justified in changing economic circumstances. An important adverse consequence of pursuing import-substitution is that it can result in the foregoing of opportunities for specialisation in areas in which Australia has the greatest advantages. Tariff reductions to induce changes in industry structure and encourage greater specialisation in industry therefore have a role to play in the process of encouraging a more efficient manufacturing industry in Australia.

All those remarks are true. When we attempt, as we are doing, to reduce protection on a predictable basis years ahead-to reduce protection slowly and predictably-the Labor Party is most strident in its opposition. The most outspoken troglodyte in the protection area is undoubtedly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the other place, Mr Lionel Bowen. If members of the Labor Party are serious about their attempts to improve productivity, which is the thrust of this motion, they should be in favour of rationalising our protection system. They are not. They oppose every change in it, arguing, for instance, that any change at all, as far as I can gather, would create unemployment. This is complete nonsense. If we reduce protection we might reduce, and probably would reduce, employment in the particular industry concerned. But the increased spending of the community would create other demands and other employment. If anything, the evidence shows that a reduction in protection would increase employment. It most certainly would not reduce it. Yet, that is the sort of simple-minded argument that is always trotted out by the Labor Party every time there is any suggestion that there should be an organised, sustained, predictable reduction in the protection of industries in which we are not internationally very competitive.

We must also-this is where I take issue with Senator Mason-look to the tertiary sector as the place where new employment is being created. When we make a more efficient manufacturing industry, whether it is to produce steam engines as in the early years of the nineteenth century or robots now, we do not destroy employment overall. We just take away inefficiently done manual activities, make them more efficient and create a great deal of new employment in new areas. There, too, the Labor Party, if it were serious in its desire for increased growth, could help. The problem in the tertiary industry is that it is marred with a web of restrictive practices, restrictive wage scales, triple pay for work on public holidays and so on. One cannot easily increase on any economic basis employment in the tertiary sector because the people in it are protecting their own interests and are not interested in creating new jobs for others. That is an area, too, where the Labor Party could help us if it were serious in trying to increase growth. I hope, therefore, that in all this the Labor Party will help and reinforce what we are doing. I hope that members of the Labor Party will help us to hold down inflation; that they will help us to increase business profits and, therefore, investment; that they will help us to try to hold down excessive wage demands; and that they will help us towards a simplified and less interventionist system of protection. If they are sincere about their objective of increased growth they will help us in all these things. But I doubt that they will. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the time for the presentation of the report from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 be extended by providing that the Committee report to the Senate on or before Wednesday, 19 May 1982.
In moving that motion I read a statement made on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in explanation of the motion.

On 25 March 1982 the Senate referred the following Bill to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for report, namely, the Honey ( Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982. On 15 April 1982 the Committee held a public hearing in relation to the Bill. At that hearing the Committee received evidence from the Department of Primary Industry, the Australian Honey Board and members of the industry. The issue involved in the reference of this Bill to the Finance and Government Operations Committee concerned the rate of charge for the inspection of honey prior to export by the holders of export licences issued by the Australian Honey Board. The decision to apply the charge arose from a decision by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee in April 1981 that 50 per cent of inspection costs be recovered. Submissions received by the Committee did not question the principle of cost recovery, but rather the level at which it was set. It was pointed out that the rate of $6.75 per tonne which was proposed in the second reading speech was very much higher in relation to honey inspection than that for butter at $2.50 per tonne or margarine at $1 per tonne.

The submissions also mentioned the effect a charge levied at the rate of $6.75 per tonne would have on the industry. The Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations made the point in its submission that:

. . . the proposed charge comes at a time when industry viability is under severe assault in the market place, and would represent a further erosion of viability. Producer returns from the export market place, although there is a firming trend, are still at or below costs of production.

The amount to be recovered in a full year may be only $50,000. However, the submissions received by the Committee indicate that this is considered an extra burden which this small and troubled industry cannot afford. Further, the industry, in its submissions to the Committee, questioned the efficiency of the inspection service provided by the Department of Primary Industry. Specifically the submissions referred to the relatively short time involved in collecting samples compared with the high costs involved due to the charge being on a per tonne basis. As I stated earlier, the industry was not absolutely opposed to the charge, just to the level of the charge. Indeed, several of the submissions suggested alternative methods of recovering costs of inspecting honey for export .

The Committee wishes to seek an extension of time to report in relation to this Bill. Although the Bill was referred to the Committee on 25 March 1982, it was not possible to obtain a submission from the Department of Primary Industry in relation to the issues raised by the honey industry until the afternoon prior to the public hearing on 15 April 1982. This alone made it extremely difficult for the Committee to obtain at the hearing the necessary information upon which to form an opinion. Further, the Committee was unable to obtain a Hansard transcript of the hearing which took place on 15 April 1982 until yesterday afternoon, principally due to the Estimates committees extending the resources available to Hansard.

There is a further reason for the Committee proposing an extension of time to report on the Bill. Several submissions to the Committee actually questioned the need for the inspection service as at present provided. The point made was that certificates issued as a result of inspection were not utilised by honey exporters, nor were they required by the largest percentage of their customers. Alternatives have been discussed and some expressed the view that in any event the competitive world market was a more effective regulator. The Committee is currently seeking more information in regard to this issue. As Commonwealth taxpayers will be paying 50 per cent of the inspection charges levied under the Bill-the Bill provides for the levy to raise the other 50 per cent-the question of the necessity for the inspections becomes critical.

The Committee was also informed that the Australian Honey Board proposes the implementation of a stabilisation scheme. The Committee wishes to follow up on this proposal the potential cost to the industry and the taxpayer of maintaining the scheme. This is particularly important considering the problems the industry foresees in meeting the proposed charges under this Bill. As part of the Committee's inquiries into the level of the charge contained in the Bill and the industry's ability to meet that charge the Committee intends to take into account the cost to the industry of the Australian Honey Board. The Committee proposes to seek the information I have mentioned and to report back to the Senate on or before 19 May 1982. Accordingly, I seek the Senate's approval to extend the Committee's reporting time to that date.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The document read as follows-
1. Summary

This inquiry differed from most other Commission inquiries in that it covered the whole Tariff, and therefore all importable goods, but did not involve a review of assistance levels. In fact, the reference specifically excluded proposals that would substantially affect assistance.

The Customs Tariff Act is an extremely fragmented and complex document comprising 5 schedules, divided into 16 operative and 3 inoperative parts, together with covering provisions. In the main schedule alone, there are some 2, 500 classifications and, over all schedules, about 700 different duty rates. In addition, various sections of the Act vary, or allow the Minister to vary, scheduled duty rates. Even as interpreted and partly consolidated in what is known as the ''working'' or Annotated Tariff, its application to imports is difficult and costly for both government and industry.

The Commission's objective in this inquiry was to formulate proposals that would simplify the tasks of classifying imported goods and determining the duty correctly payable on those goods. To this end, the Commission proposes major revision of the Tariff and, except for the inclusion of unenacted amendments ( Tariff Proposals, etc.) in any working Tariff, the elimination of all differences between the working and the Legal Tariffs.
The report recommends that the Tariff comprise, in addition to the covering sections of the Act:
the existing Interpretative Rules;
a Principal Schedule; and
a Concessional Schedule.

The Principal Schedule is intended to be the main schedule covering classifications and normal duty rates (including all preferential rates) applicable to imported goods. The Concessional Schedule would incorporate all provisions for the entry of goods at concessional (as distinct from preferential ) rates of duty. It would thus incorporate the existing Schedule 2, tariff quota provisions and concessional treatment provided by a number of Ministerial measures.

The Commission proposes also that, to the maximum extent practicable, the exercise of executive discretions involving changes in applicable duties be by measures that result in the new rates being shown in the Tariff schedules rather than only in separate instruments. This would reduce confusion about the operation of Ministerial measures and the existing high level of misapplication.

The proposed Principal Schedule is contained in Volume 2 of this report. It contains about 2,000 classifications and about 250 different duty rates. For reasons stated in section 4.3, the Principal Schedule retains explanatory matter although the Commission recommends against continuation of this system.

Although the sections of the Customs Tariff Act were not directly under reference, acceptance of the Commission's recommendations would require changes to the Act. However, the Commission believes that the Act as a whole is very much in need of a complete overhaul and that the Government's stated objective of Tariff simplification requires its complete redrafting.

One significant cause of the existing Tariff complexity is trade commitments accepted by Australia in international negotiations. Significant simplification will not be possible without modification of some commitments and the Commission recommends that the Government undertake any necessary negotiations. However, the Commission recognises that it is for the Government to decide whether the potential benefits warrant re-negotiation of any particular commitment.

The report draws attention to some areas where the Commission's proposals would not achieve significant simplification and where satisfactory simplification proposals could only be developed in conjunction with a review of assistant issues. In one of these areas, a separate inquiry is formally recommended.

Finally, the report recommends that the simplification objective be given its due weight whenever changes or possible changes in the Tariff are under consideration and suggests other steps that might be taken with a view to keeping the Tariff reasonably simple.

TOBACCO CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1982
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Tobacco Charge Act (No. 1) 1955 for the following purposes:
(a) to increase the rate of charge payable on sales of Australian tobacco leaf on and after 1 March 1982 from 1.1 cents to 2.5 cents per kilogram
(b) to enable the rate of charge to be increased or decreased by regulation.

The Bill is closely linked with the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 3) which will apply the rate of charge set under this Bill to Australian tobacco leaf purchased by manufacturers or grown and used by manufacturers. It is proposed that the three Bills be treated as cognate legislation.
At present the rate of charge paid by manufacturers is 2.2 cents per kilogram.

The three principal Acts have, since 1955, established rates of charge to be paid by industry funds for research financed from the Tobacco Industry Trust Account established by the Tobacco Industry Act 1955. In 1965 the latter Act was amended so part of the charges paid by growers and manufacturers could be appropriated to meet the cost of operation of the Australian Tobacco Board which was then being established. The balance of the amount collected continues to be appropriated to the Tobacco Industry Trust Account.
The rates of charge were increased at the time from one half penny to three- fifths of a penny per pound. Since then there has been only a minor reduction effected in 1973 to 1.1 cents per kilogram.

The amount of money thus provided for research has been declining as the costs of operating the Australian Tobacco Board have risen in spite of substantial economies being effected. In more recent years there has been a further decline because it has been necessary for marketing quotas under the Tobacco Stabilisation Plan to be reduced.

An effect of this has been that research and extension programs in the three producing States have been pruned and rationalised over a period of several years. Even so the cost of basic programs has exceeded annual income and it has been necessary to draw on reserves accumulated in previous years and the proceeds of sales of real estate and assets which were no longer essential to the scaled down programs.
The stage has been reached where remaining reserves would quickly be depleted and the current programs could not be maintained unless there is an injection of additional funds.

With the new proposals and at present marketing quota levels the industry will contribute about $250,000 more than it has been doing. The Commonwealth is prepared to continue matching expenditure of industry funds and so will contribute a like amount.
Thus it will be possible to continue the current level of research for some years to come, drawing on reserves to some extent.

The question of whether the Commonwealth should contribute to tobacco research has been asked before and will no doubt arise again. One of the decisions announced on 19 December 1980 following the Government's consideration of Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare was that there would be discussions with the industry on redirection of funding for research into alternative varieties of tobacco leaf having a less detrimental effect on health . There has been increasing emphasis on plant breeding and on cultural practices which affect alkaloid levels in leaf. There is also some important work on resistance to insects and plant diseases to lessen dependence on the use of chemicals for control purposes.

It can be expected that there will be further emphasis on these essential aspects of research. With this in mind the Government has sought the agreement of the Australian Agricultural Council to add a representative of the Department of Health to membership of the Central Tobacco Advisory Committee. That is the Committee which has the responsibility of examining research programs and recommending to me the expenditure of moneys from the Tobacco Industry Trust Account.

Expenditure approved for this year, 1981-82, is $1,233,155 of which the Commonwealth is committed to contribute $348,000. The whole amount is made available to State Departments responsible for agriculture in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. Additional State expenditure on tobacco research in 1981-82 is estimated at $580,000.

All of the expenditure is concerned with production and curing of leaf on the farm, not with manufacturing. The increases in the charge rates from the start of the selling season have been sought by both the growing and manufacturing sectors. Both are in favour of the starting date of 1 March.
As far as any future changes in rates are concerned regulations will be introduced only if changes are sought by both sectors.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
TOBACCO CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1982
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Tobacco Charge Act (No. 2) 1955 to increase the amount of tobacco charge payable by manufacturers on their purchases of Australian tobacco leaf.

The Bill provides that as from 1 March 1982 the rate of charge paid by manufacturers on their purchases of Australian leaf, presently 2.2 per cent per kilogram, is to be the same as that applicable under the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1982.

TOBACCO CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1982

That states the purposes of the Bills that we are debating together this evening . I also note that the Minister stated:
The question of whether the Commonwealth should contribute to tobacco research has been asked before and will no doubt arise again.

The Bills were introduced into the Senate on 18 March. The Minister's hopes that the Government's role in tobacco research and purpose of tobacco research in Australia are again under attack. Only one week later, in a hearing conducted by the Industries Assistance Commission, the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria made submissions which were relative to the tobacco industry.

I have a very specific interest in these Bills, not because I happen to be a tobacco addict, but because about half of the tobacco farmers in Australia are in Queensland. I have visited the areas where tobacco is growing and have discussed with growers the matter of additives in the industry. They have expressed to me great concern about the attitude of certain anti-smoking groups in the community and some worries about the Government's attitude, not necessarily that they think that there should not be anti-smoking campaigns. I think the dangers that appear to be associated with tobacco smoking should be made clear. Anti-cancer councils are right in campaigning publicly about the effect that smoking could have on one's health. However, I cannot support a view that the industry should be deprived of access to research funds which has been an attitude put in this Parliament, put in a number of venues and, as I have said, put to the Industries Assistance Commission on 25 March 1982.
The statement made by the Council to the IAC included this remark:
Tobacco is a toxic product and should not receive assistance from the Government for its growing, manufacturing or marketing.
It is at direct variance with the Government's declared intention of reducing tobacco consumption . . .

I suggest that it is not at variance. The tobacco industry is an industry which exists in Australia. If the Government were to decide, because of its concern about the effect of tobacco on individuals' health, that the tobacco industry should be eliminated in Australia-it could do that by a number of measures-it would not of itself eliminate smoking tobacco. We all know that. We do import a large quantity of tobacco and manufacturers use imported tobacco, along with Australian tobacco in their industry. Therefore, tobacco and tobacco products would still be available for import unless the Government made the decision that it would ban tobacco and tobacco products which I think is entirely unlikely. So , if the Government were to take that decision, it would phase out an industry in the country and allow the products of the industry to come from other countries. It is entirely competent for the Government if it wishes to make that decision. What it must not do is send Australian tobacco farmers broke through depriving the industry of access to research money into disease. It is no cure for the tobacco smoking habit to prevent our farmers having access to research funds which will discover cures for diseases of crops.

Senator Walsh pointed out that the Government has stated that it is encouraging means of research which will lead to the development of a leaf which has lower levels of certain allegedly toxic qualities and also resistance to disease so that chemicals do not have to be used so much. So long as we have the industry, that research is important and it must be carried out. I contend that the view, as reported by the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria and other groups which have taken this line from time to time, is quite unreasonable.
Dr Sarfaty, head of the New South Wales Cancer Council, said to the IAC:
. . . that duty concessions to cigarette makers for buying Australian leaf, and their promotional tax deductions should also be ended.

If duty concessions were eliminated for buying Australian leaf the only effect would be to send Australian tobacco farmers broke and that will not achieve the end that any anti-cancer council might want to achieve. It will only affect the Australian industry's income, not the smoking habit. The effect of the tactics of these people would be only to beggar the farmer-and to what purpose? As I have said, if the Government decided that it did not want to support the tobacco industry, because of other forms of assistance, and it made a conscious decision that the tobacco industry in Australia was to be eliminated, given that it can only exist in a protected situation, that is a decision that the Government is competent to make and could make. However, if it makes that decision it must face the fact that tobacco growing is a highly specialised industry; that the types of soil used for growing tobacco are unlikely except in a couple of fairly rare instances to be suitable for growing other crops, except with the addition of large amounts of fertiliser; that the equipment used for tobacco farming is highly specialised, specific to the crop and not suitable for other crops; and that the farmers would have to be bailed out in a reasonable way and set up in other industries, or given the opportunity to set up in other industries, if that was what they want to do. If that is the Government's decision-good. But I urge the Government not to take any notice of people whose frustration at, frankly, their lack of success by and large with their anti-smoking campaigns leads them to advocate that the solution to the problem of tobacco addiction could be achieved in any way by hurting Australian farmers.

STATEMENT BY THE HON. N. A. BROWN MINISTER FOR BUSINESS AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
Review of Customs Administration

The Prime Minister informed the House on 20 April 1982 that there were matters which seemed to require examination within the administration of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in New South Wales. He indicated that consideration was being given to the appropriate form of the inquiry into those matters.
The circumstances associated with the importation last year of a television set by the former Minister for Health have attracted publicity and comment in this House and outside.
There has also been publicity and comment about wider difficulties in customs administration in New South Wales.

In tendering their resignations last week the Minister for Health and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs accepted responsibility for what happened in relation to the importation of the television set. They have paid a heavy price.
In addition the Government has tabled the relevant documents.

The Government does not believe that there is any good purpose to be served by further examination of those particular events with a view to reporting on the responsibility and conduct of those involved.
What is important, however, is to look to the future and to take whatever steps are necessary to ensure that any difficulties in Customs administration in New South Wales are put right.

In this respect I inform the House that a great deal of work has already been completed by the Department and the Public Service Board on a major restructuring of the Customs organisation throughout the Commonwealth. The proposed restructuring includes the introduction of a single work category of customs officer which should lead to the elimination of work demarcation tensions now present. The Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs recommended the early introduction of a single work category.

The implementation plans which will be made public very shortly include processes for consultations with the interested staff associations. The Government believes that the reorganisation will do much to avoid a repetition of the difficulties that have been in evidence recently. It is the Government's wish that the reorganisation proceed expeditiously.

While it believes that this reorganisation will achieve a great deal, the Government has decided to establish a further review of Administration and procedures of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in regard to the control and clearance of imported goods under the customs Act in relation to New South Wales. The review will have particular regard to:
(a) clearance of incoming passengers and of the unaccompanied baggage of incoming passengers and of incoming cargo at the Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport;
(b) the relations between management, staff and staff associations; and
(c) the need to ensure the efficient and impartial application of Customs procedures.

The review will report on any changes that may be necessary or desirable for more efficient and effective administration, including industrial relations, and to ensure observance of the instruction by the Prime Minister in 1976 that all Australians should receive equal treatment in respect of the enforcement of Customs regulations.

The review will be carried out by Mr F. J. Mahony, C.B., O.B.E. Mr Mahony is the President of the Repatriation Review Tribunal. He was formerly a deputy secretary in the Attorney-General's Department and acted for a period as Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.
Mr Mahony will be invited to take account of such reports, developments, events and other circumstances as he may consider necessary in order to report on necessary or desirable changes.
The Government does not propose to confer on Mr Mahony powers under the Royal Commissions Act.
The Government does not believe this is necessary for a review which is essentially forward looking and directed to setting the administration right for the future.

While Mr Mahony's attention will be directed to the Customs administration in New South Wales he will not, of course, be excluded from examining the relationship between the Department in Canberra and the administration in New South Wales.
The manner in which Mr Mahony conducts his review will be a matter for him including the extent to which he may decide to hold public hearings.
The Government will be asking Mr Mahony to present his report in a form that may be made public subject, of course, to any particular part that should be treated confidentially.
I table the terms of reference of the review and ask leave to incorporate them in Hansard.
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR REVIEW OF CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION

1. To review the administration and procedures of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in regard to the control and clearance of imported goods under the Customs Act in relation to New South Wales, with particular regard to:
(a) clearance of incoming passengers and of the unaccompanied baggage of incoming passengers and of incoming cargo at the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport;
(b) the relations between management, staff and staff associations; and
(c) the need to ensure the efficient and impartial application of Customs procedures;

and to report on any changes that may be necessary or desirable for more efficient and effective administration, including industrial relations, and to ensure observance of the instruction by the Prime Minister in 1976 that all Australians should receive equal treatment in respect of the enforcement of Customs regulations.

2. Without limiting the generality of the above, account may be taken in the review of such reports, developments, events and other circumstances as may be considered necessary in order to report on necessary or desirable changes as required above.

TALK.START.PARA: —I revert for a moment to the previous matter of the documents. Last week Senator Grimes asked a question of Senator Messner regarding a second document that I understand he felt was in existence, originating from Mr Kennedy who, I think, is the Director of the Internal Affairs Unit. I am advised that all inquiries have failed to identify the existence ever of such a document. I understand that the questioning of Mr Kennedy has indicated that he knows of no such documents. Perhaps there is some misunderstanding about the nature of the document on this matter. The reference may be to a document that was tabled previously. The Government, from the outset , recognised that there were obviously serious difficulties within the Customs section of the Department. There were quite serious allegations by certain Customs officers of practices that, if true, could not be tolerated-allegations of standover tactics, overriding of valid actions and of patronage.

SPEECH.PARA: Arising out of these matters some people have felt that some of the officers have suffered victimisation. I refer, for example, to the comment made by Senator Macklin earlier today in the Senate. There was a serious allegation of victimisation of a public servant who is engaged in carrying out his duties to the best of his intentions. The Government shares entirely the views of all honourable senators who would want to pursue to the ultimate this question of justice, fair play and sound working conditions for the officers engaged in the Customs area. Accordingly, the terms of reference have been so designed that they cover explicitly all such matters. I give an assurance to the Senate that the terms of reference-I have legal advice on this matter-are such that they enable the fullest investigation of all the practices and alleged malpractices within the Customs section, whether they be alleged industrial practices, allegations of overriding of orders, allegations of patronage or, indeed-and more seriously-allegations of corruption.

The Government has made no reflection at all on any officer and certainly not on any officer carrying out his duty in this matter. In 1976 the Government set out, through the then Mr Carmody, who was the Secretary of the Department of Customs and Excise, clear instructions that there should be absolute equality of treatment for everybody who comes on to the Customs floor and that nobody-be it members of parliament or overseas dignataries-should receive any different treatment. It is the Government's emphatic desire that this should be so. The terms of reference have been designed taking into consideration the intensions behind the suggestions of the union representative indeed, the Customs officers themselves, that an investigation was necessary. The terms of reference have been so designed because the Government believes that there should be the fullest understanding on this matter. Honourable senators from both sides of the chamber have stressed that it is not the desire of this inquiry to proceed with any further witch hunt in regard to two people concerned. TALK.START.PARA: —A penalty but not the duty.

—They have paid the duty, plus the penalty on the duty. As honourable senators will recall, Mr MacKellar had written to the former Minister for Business and Consurmer Affairs, and offered to pay. That ought to be said. His letter is available and has been circulated to all honourable senators. He was not asked to pay. In his letter he asked if the set was dutiable, and, if so, the amount involved, because he wanted to pay it. When he discovered it was dutiable he paid both the duty and the penalty.
—I am indebted to you; that is new information.

—That is my understanding. My understanding is that he had offered to pay. The procedures were put into practice. In case there is any doubt about that I will get the matter checked, but he made those payments. As I understand it--
—When did he pay? That is what we want to know. That is something that he didn't tell the House of Representatives last night. He said he did but he didn't say when.

—I will be very happy to find that out. I will let the Senate know following the suspension of the sitting. —I don't think that is going to stand up either, and I will explain that in a moment.

—The honourable senator's colleagues have indicated that it is not their intention in this inquiry to pursue a witch hunt against those Ministers. SPEECH.PARA: A chairman has been selected for the inquiry. He is Mr Frank Mahony. He is a man of unquestioned integrity and ability, a man whose knowledge both of the law and of the procedures of the Public Service would be second to none. Honourable senators will be aware that Mr Mahony has had a distinguished service in the Attorney-General's Department. He was recognised for his great skills, integrity and dedication. He was, in fact, in charge of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. He is a man whose ability and objectivity has been recognised on both sides of the Parliament. My understanding is that he had the full support of the Whitlam Government during its term. I think he was appointed by it to ASIO. His background in the Attorney-General's Department, in ASIO, and now in the Repatriation Review Tribunal makes him eminently suitable. No one would question his ability to undertake this inquiry. Under the terms of reference he has the ability to inquire into the whole field of the activities of the Customs area of the Department, relations between management, staff and staff associations-if there is any victimisation it can come out quite clearly- and the need to ensure the efficient and impartial application of Customs procedures. I put it to the Senate that the matters that have been sought by the officers concerned, by the Government itself and by requests made from both sides of the Parliament are well met in these terms of reference and by the nature of the person conducting the inquiry. TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was dealing with the MacKellar-Moore black and white television set issue. We were trying to get some resolution of the proper nature of an inquiry which should be conducted into this whole affair. As Senator Sir John Carrick properly pointed out, we have made it quite clear right from the beginning that we are not interested in pursuing a witch hunt against particular Ministers. But if the circumstances are such that an inquiry is felt to be necessary, the Opposition has maintained from the beginning of this matter that the inquiry should be public, that it should be conducted by somebody outside the Public Service, that it should have much more explicit terms of reference than this proposed inquiry of the Government has and that it should report by a particular date. If the questions involved justify an inquiry, they justify a proper inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to indicate some of the dissatisfaction which the Opposition has with these proposed terms of reference. The first thing I should say is that the inquiry is directed to New South Wales only. It is not anything but a matter of common knowledge that for some time there has been dissatisfaction with the staffing levels of the Bureau of Customs, that there has been some dissatisfaction with procedures, that there has been some dissatisfaction with industrial relations within the Bureau of Customs and that that is not confined to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. We find it extraordinary that the inquiry should be so limited as to be directed to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport only.

We have no qualifications about the calibre of the man appointed to conduct the inquiry, Mr Mahony. We are not in any sense attacking his capacity. What we are saying is that this inquiry has all the flavour of a little sweeping under the rug operation conducted by one public servant into the activities of other public servants. It certainly does not have the quality of being an independent, outside inquiry. It is not seen by the public as having that character and it is certainly not seen by people in the Bureau of Customs as having that character.

I remind the Government that only a year ago or so there was an inquiry into the Bureau of Customs conducted by a Mr Willett, a senior public servant, and a Mr McGonical. That inquiry, which was instigated by the Government as a result of the publication of a document known as the McShane report dealing with the unsatisfactory situation of the bond stores administered by the Bureau of Customs and conducted by Mr Willett and Mr McGonical, investigated the Bureau and recommended very considerable changes, particularly to the industrial relations system of the Bureau. The consequence of that inquiry and its report was that really very little happened apart from the removal of a few people in the bureaucracy of the Customs Bureau from Sydney to Melbourne.

That inquiry had very similar terms of reference to those for the inquiry which is now proposed by the Government. If nothing was done as a result of that inquiry, what confidence have we that anything will be done as a result of this inquiry? If that inquiry was thorough and effective in terms of the administration of the Bureau of Customs, why have there been all the complaints since that inquiry reported? Indeed, why were Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore caught up in this incident which has led to the suggestion of a new inquiry by the Government? If that inquiry had been successful in the report and recommendations which it made, if it had been successful in the sense that those recommendations were carried out and the efficiency, effectiveness and morale of the Bureau of Customs were improved as a result, why did this whole shabby incident occur and why is there a need for yet another inquiry at this point? As I would put it, we have very grave reasons for concern about the proposal which has now been brought forward.

Two things have been associated with this debate since the issue was debated in the Senate a week ago. A week ago the Opposition was asking for the publication of all documents relating to this matter. We were given a green book of documents a week ago or so and we were told that they were the documents relevant to this matter. Since that time, as a result of information that has come to hand, further documents have been prised like limpets off the rocks from this most reluctant Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like oysters.

—Senator Martyr's preference is for oysters. They were prised like oysters off a rock from this most reluctant Government. It is reluctant to publish the documents. The situation was, of course, well illustrated by the cartoonists who saw this Government's attitude to full disclosure as a long saga of documents being produced one after the other, day by day, as they were pressed for and the result of that pressing was the presentation of various documents from time to time. Some more documents have now been made available to the Senate. In a minute I want to comment briefly about those documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I will digress for one minute to deal with an issue which came up before the suspension of the sitting for dinner in relation to the payment of duty on the television set which Mr MacKellar brought into this country in October last year. There was an exchange in the Senate between me and Senator Sir John Carrick relating to this matter. By way of interjection the question was asked whether Mr MacKellar, having paid the penalty over this matter, had also paid the duty. We were informed that he had paid the duty. I do not know whether that is correct. I understand from a consideration of the Customs Act and regulations that duty is payable on goods only at the point of entry and that a penalty is payable in respect of non-payment of duty only at the point of entry. If an offence is detected subsequent to the point of entry, I understand that ordinary procedures apply under the Act and the regulations and the offending person is proceeded against by way of summons. I raise that question only in the context of asking whether the procedures have been applied properly in this case. That is an important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very doubtful.
—Does the honourable senator regard it as doubtful?
—Very doubtful indeed.

—I am glad that Senator Siddons shares my interpretation of what the correct position is. It is important in the context of this issue as it has been raised in the Parliament to consider whether the proper procedures have now been applied or whether there has been again an attempt to sweep that issue under the carpet and evade the proper procedures. I want to make some brief comment about the tabling of the documents. As I said earlier, we were assured on two occasions last week that all the material relating to this matter had been tabled. An unusual incident took place earlier. It involved the Parliamentary Liaison Officer rushing busily into the office of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, Mr Hayden, and taking back a file which he had given to Mr Hayden's private secretary. It was returned to the Leader of the Opposition some time later.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been asserted by Opposition spokesmen that there are more documents-and there are. It is interesting to note that, even at this stage, there are no copies of the important memorandum from Mr Besley, the former director, to Mr Cunningham, but only a transcript of the shorthand notes taken by Mr Besley's secretary. This transcript in itself raises further issues because it simply records what was said by the former Minister to Mr Besley. Many questions arise in relation to that matter. They are questions which, I might add, could lead to the conclusion that Mr Moore, the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, was perhaps wrongly pressed into a resignation which would not have occurred if those questions had been properly revealed. Those matters ought to be known because, if the former Minister was wrongly pressed into resignation, it is the task of this sort of inquiry to exonerate him, if 'exonerate' is the appropriate word to use. That is why, as I said earlier, the Opposition has always called for a full judicial public inquiry in which all the facts will be revealed.

The questions arising from the television incident which remain unanswered are as follows: What is the meaning of the memorandum in relation to the former Minister, Mr Moore? Was there a conspiracy in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to cover up the whole matter? If so, did that conspiracy involve senior officers of the Department or was it encouraged by other Ministers? Further, what other documents are yet to be brought to light? The Opposition argues that only a judicial inquiry or a royal commision can bring out the truth in relation to these matters to the satisfaction of the public. A departmental inquiry or an inquiry involving public servants is no guarantee of satisfaction. The failure of the Department is evidenced by the fact that this is the third set of documents to be tabled. On each of the occasions when documents have been tabled in relation to this matter, they have been accompanied by an assurance that there are no more relevant documents and on each of those three ocasions there have turned out to be more relevant documents .

That serious situation, involving as it has the resignations of two Ministers over what in itself was a trivial issue, more importantly involves a question which goes to the entire integrity of the Public Service and of the Bureau of Customs. I refer to the allegation that a relatively junior officer in the Bureau was stood over by a senior officer for doing his duty and carrying out the instructions which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said would be applicable to every citizen, including himself I presume. An officer who was responsible for carrying out those instructions was told, effectively-if I may lapse into a colloquialism-to pull his head in, because what he was doing was not the way to get on in the Australian Public Service. That is the most serious allegation of all, because it goes to the question of the integrity of the Public Service, the integrity of government and the confidence which a member of the Public Service can have in the notion-sadly, it is perhaps becoming old- fashioned-that people should do a good job according to the standards which are appropriate and which should apply to the concept of Public Service. It is in that context that the issue is immensely serious. How does the Government respond to all of this a week later, after the MacKellar-Moore affair has perhaps retreated somewhat from the highly political psyches of the senior Ministers in this Government and has become less colourful and perhaps more black and white? It sets up this Mickey Mouse inquiry into the Bureau of Customs .

Let me refer briefly to the terms of reference. These are the matters to which, according to the Fraser Government, the inquiry is to have particular regard, arising from this most serious incident which involves the fate of two Ministers and the morale of an important section of the Public Service and which may or ought to involve the fate of some very senior officers in the bureaucracy. The Government's response is that the particular matters to be considered are as follows:
(a) clearance of incoming passengers and of the unaccompanied baggage of incoming passengers and of incoming cargo at the Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport;
(b) the relations between management, staff and staff associations; and
(c) the need to ensure the efficient and impartial application of Customs procedures.

The inquiry is confined to New South Wales. It is directed specifically to the area of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The inquiry is not bound to report to this Parliament or anywhere else by any particular date. It is to be conducted by a public servant inquiring into the activities of other public servants.

It is not an inquiry which, like Caesar's wife, is above suspicion or ought to be above suspicion. The very strong suspicion is that all this inquiry involves- having regard to the sad history of the Customs Bureau and the numerous inquiries which have apparently not been successful-is a Mickey Mouse exercise to sweep this issue under the carpet until the next election. I suppose that no date has been set by which the inquiry must report because it has not yet been decided when the next election will be held. That is the obvious reason for not setting a date by which the inquiry has to report so that this Parliament can debate this issue again with the advantage of the recommendations of the inquiry .

As I have said, it is in that context that the Opposition has insisted from the beginning and insisted again that this inquiry have a judicial quality about it, a quite independent quality from that which it will have under the chairmanship of Mr Mahony, a public servant, however worthy a gentleman he may be. It is for that reason that before the suspension of the sitting I moved an amendment insisting that the terms of reference of any such inquiry embrace the effectiveness of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, which escapes unscathed from this proposed inquiry. I moved that the inquiry should examine:
(a) The effectiveness of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in the performance of its functions under the Customs Act 1901;
