(b) the handling of complaints within the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and in particular the Bureau of Customs;
(c) industrial relations between the management, staff and staff associations, and
(d) any changes necessary in arrangements or procedures within the Department and the Customs Act 1901.

We seek to give that review-that inquiry-the status, powers and privileges of a royal commission and to require it to report by November 1982. In a Parliament where we are still talking about freedom of information-nothing much is happening, I might say-what is wrong with that? What is wrong with having an inquiry of that kind? Why should those issues not be examined? I tell the Senate now that officers of the Bureau of Customs and some members of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs will have no confidence in this internal inquiry which the Government proposes. They will have no confidence in it because the certain promise for them is that if and when this inquiry reports-they have given evidence to it and have been involved in its deliberations-the experience of Mr Mayhew, called 'Mr Mayhem' by the cartoonists because of his allegations, might well be repeated. What confidence can they have that officers who allegedly disciplined Mr Mayhew for doing his duty will not in turn discipline them for giving evidence to this inquiry or for being involved in it and making recommendations regarding the procedures and work of the Bureau of Customs? What confidence can they have in view of the record of the Bureau of Customs, having regard to the numerous inquiries to which it has been subject? They can have no confidence at all.

The result is, as I said, a Mickey Mouse thing which is designed to sweep this important issue under the table, get rid of it all for the next election, make sure any inquiry does not report until after the next election, not put any deadline on it so that the whole issue will be dead and buried and the Ministers in question will be able to be returned happily to the Government in due course, if that be the case. The whole thing will be forgotten as other incidents in the shoddy record of this Government have been allowed to be forgotten, and about which we will consistently be reminding the Australian people in order that right from the top of the administration in this country, through bodies such as the Bureau of Customs and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, people can have confidence in the procedures which are being adopted and in the standards which are applicable and certainty that in the future the recommendations of any inquiry will be adopted and will be for the benefit of all those involved in this important area of public service. I commend the amendment to the Senate. I think it is most important that the Senate, as a House of review, adopt a proper and responsible approach on this issue and not be subject to the whims of an Executive concerned only to sweep this matter under the carpet and escape the justice of the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button, the Leader of the Opposition, has made a speech that was truly remarkable for its blatant political tone. The remarkable nature of it is that he started off by trying-
—Fancy a politician talking politics!

—I welcome politicians being true to their colours but Senator Button started off by trying to present himself in a statesmanlike role and then spent most of his speech in presenting his true form. Senator Button was at great pains to inform the Senate and all those listening to this debate tonight that he did not want to conduct any witch hunt whatever into the role of the Ministers who have resigned. He had to do that because he realises that there is a very wide sense of fair play in the Australian electorate and the Australian character. It is recognised widely in this community that the two Ministers, Messrs MacKellar and Moore, have paid a heavy price, have accepted their responsibilities and have resigned. Senator Button knows perfectly well that there is no political mileage whatever in pursuing the matter in a direct way but he has sought in this debate to pursue it in an indirect way. That is why I say that he has engaged in a truly cynical political exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week Senator Button introduced terms of reference for an inquiry, most of which would have been, if adopted, clearly an inquisition into the role of the Ministers and the circumstances surrounding the importance of a colour television set by Mr MacKellar. This afternoon he withdrew that motion and introduced an amendment setting out the terms of reference for an inquiry which would be, if adopted-as is the inquiry under the Government's proposed terms of reference- an inquiry into the administration of the affairs of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. In the course of Senator Button's speech this evening he has not addressed himself to the details of his own proposal. Much less has he endeavoured to compare his proposal with that of the Government. He has processed with a speech about cover-ups, conspiracies, intimidation of public servants and sweeping matters under the carpet. None of the trigger and motor phrases that he has been using has relevance to the issues that are before the Senate in the debate this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are attacking me.

—Yes, I am. I do not mind admitting that I might be making a political speech in this chamber. I do not object to Senator Button's making one . It is when he tries to dress it up in another colour that I object. I will come back to what this debate ought to be about. The Government has not decided to set up an inquiry into the actual facts and circumstances of the importation of the now famous colour television set by Mr MacKellar. It has decided, as has the Opposition, although one would not believe it from Senator Button's speech, that no useful purpose whatever would be served by pursuing the facts and circumstances of the MacKellar importation. The Ministers concerned have accepted their responsibilities and have paid the heavy price of resignation. The Government has decided to set up an inquiry into certain administrative aspects of the Customs Bureau and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs with a view to investigating the administration and procedures of industrial relations in that Department and recommending whether any changes should be effected.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment that the Opposition has moved proposes an inquiry into the effectiveness of the Department in its performance under the Customs Act, the handling of complaints within the Department, in particular the Bureau of Customs, and any questions affecting relations between management and staff. In the broad approach to the inquiry which is to be undertaken there is no difference in principle whatever between the terms of reference which the Government has announced and the approach that is recommended in the amendment by the Opposition. There is some difference in detail which I will deal with in a minute but there is no difference in principle between the approaches despite the speech by Senator Button to which honourable senators have just listened. I think it would be as well if honourable senators, in considering this amendment this evening, discounted almost the whole of what Senator Button has been saying because it has been directed to a different sort of inquiry altogether which the opposition proposed a week ago, which proposal it withdrew earlier today substituting the amendment which is at present before us in this debate. So much for the bona fides of the Opposition in this matter.

There are really only two significant differences between the proposal of the Opposition and that of the Government. Firstly, the Opposition has suggested this evening in its amendment that the inquiry should be concerned with the effectiveness of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, operating under the Customs Act, in a general way, that is, throughout the whole of the Customs administration in Australia; whereas the Government's terms of reference for the inquiry which it set up are in regard to the control and clearance of goods under the Customs Act in New South Wales with particular regard to the clearance of passengers, goods and cargo at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. It is not limited by any means simply to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, as one might understand had one been listening carefully to Senator Button. It is not confined to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport at all, as he said.

It is certainly confined to the role of the Customs Bureau in New South Wales. The reason for that is that the Government is anxious that this problem, which has existed in the administration in New South Wales for a very long time, should be the focus of this inquiry. The problems that have been of concern for some time have been centred in New South Wales and, in particular, at Sydney ( Kingsford-Smith) Airport. They have not been in other parts of Australia. They have been centred there, and that is why this inquiry is focused on that subject . Senator Button says that he does not want an inquiry that will be swept under the carpet-I think that was his phrase-until after the next election. He wants an inquiry which will be able to report in a reasonable time. So does the Government. That is why the Government is trying to give the inquiry a reasonable area of investigation, an area where there are and have been problems for a long time, so that it will be a manageable inquiry which will be able to report in a reasonable time. That is one difference between the proposal of the Opposition and that of the Government.

Other aspects that the Opposition suggests should be dealt with, such as the handling of complaints and industrial relations, are all matters that are clearly comprehended within the terms of reference of the Government's inquiry. The question of reporting, the proposing of changes and so on are clearly dealt with in the Government's proposals. In fact, the Opposition's amendment adopts exactly the same phraseology as that of the Government, which asks the inquiry to take account of such reports, developments, events and other circumstances as may be considered necessary and relevant to the inquiry and to make its report. Senator Button's speech was about conspiracies and about a specific investigation of alleged interference with a public servant. Those matters are not specifically dealt with in the Opposition's proposed terms of reference.

The other difference between the Government's form of inquiry and that of the Opposition is that the Opposition wants the inquiry to have the powers, status and privileges of a royal commission. The Opposition does not criticise-indeed, it would not in any way reflect upon-the integrity, the status and the ability of Mr Frank Mahony, who has been selected by the Government to undertake the inquiry. The inquiry is into administration, into procedures and into general matters of that kind. It is designed to have a different approach altogether from that of a normal judicial inquiry, which would be normal in the case of a royal commission set up with the full powers and privileges referred to by the Opposition. It would be conducted in a remote judicial manner assisted by counsel. People who appeared before it would want to be represented by counsel. It would be conducted with the full and formal forms of a judicial inquiry. That is not what the Government sees as necessary here at all.

What the Government sees as necessary here is a review by a man of independence and integrity, which everybody agrees Mr Mahony is; a man of experience with the Public Service but independent of the Public Service, which Mr Mahony is; and a man who has the ability to act as a trouble shooter, to get down to the work place at the shop floor level, to talk to people and to find out what the problems are. That is the sort of inquiry that the Government wants. It does not want a remote judicial exercise with lawyers having a field day, which is what the Opposition wants. It wants an inquiry that will be conducted efficiently, informally and with expedition. That is a role that we believe Mr Mahony can perform perfectly well. We have every confidence that he can perform without being given, as the Opposition says, status, powers and privileges. Privileges- that is what the Opposition wants; it wants the inquiry to have the privileges of some sort of royal commission. There will be no lack of people who want to come before Mr Mahony and tell him what the problems are as they see them. Mr Mahony is a man perfectly capable of lending a very sympathetic and understanding ear to people with complaints; and that is what is required. It is not necessary to haul people up before him and have them cross-examined. It is an inquiry into administration, procedures and industrial relations. A great, formal judicial inquiry is not the way in which an investigation of that kind is desirably conducted. Those are the only differences between the Opposition and the Government in this matter.

The Senate can discount, as I have said, almost every point of criticism that Senator Button made on the Government's inquiry because they were made in relation to a proposal that the Opposition made a week ago and has now withdrawn . Senator Button did not address himself in any way at all to his own amendment and to the terms for the alternative inquiry proposed by the Opposition in this amendment. For all those reasons I believe that the Government's inquiry will be effective and efficient. It will have the opportunity of reporting at a reasonably early date. In fact, we do not want Mr Mahony to prolong the inquiry unduly but hope that he will be able to report within a reasonable time. The amendment proposes alternative terms of reference which, as I have said, are not really different in any substance from the terms of reference of the Government' s inquiry. Nevertheless, there would be differences which I do not think are justified, which the Government does not believe are necessary and which, I trust, the Senate will reject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) used a tactic frequently used by people in this place when trying to justify an unjustifiable case; that of setting up straw men and then knocking them down. He made a particular play during his speech of the fact that Mr Frank Mahony is an honourable man and that therefore no one here should criticise him. We in the Opposition agree that Mr Mahony is an honourable and skilful man. We do not criticise him; we criticise the Government for setting up this sort of inquiry. Senator Durack made the point towards the end of his speech that the Government sees as necessary a manageable inquiry which reports in a reasonable time. He objects to the motion put forward by Senator Button tonight because, amongst other reasons, the motion would provide for an inquiry to have the status, power and-he emphasised it-privileges of a royal commission. I will deal with those matters first.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, it is quite clear that the Government wants a manageable inquiry. Senator Durack, in criticising the Opposition's motion, made a great point of the fact that Senator Button and the Opposition changed the terms of reference for the inquiry that we asked to be established a week ago. We did change the terms of reference, and we did so for the simple reason that the whole ball game changed in the last week. A week ago, when we sought an inquiry, the main difficulty seen in this Parliament was the attempt to cover up what happened to two Ministers. As Senator Sir John Carrick quite rightly points out, those two Ministers resigned, but arising out of those two Ministers' resignations we have the papers which were produced in this green folder, papers which were produced a day later and the papers which were produced after that, despite, as Senator Button said, each time there being protestations that there were no more papers to be brought out. These documents that have been tabled have demonstrated an attempt at cover-up in the Bureau of Customs in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. There was an attempt to stand over and suppress an officer of that Department, Mr Mayhew, who insisted on performing his duty as he saw that duty should be performed. Obviously, things were not well in the Department, and they were not well in the Department as far as Customs were concerned.

An inquiry into what happens at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in regard to incoming passengers and incoming cargo is certainly a manageable inquiry. It is a manageable inquiry as far as the Government is concerned; it is not a manageable inquiry as far as this country is concerned and as far as the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs is concerned in relation to its administration of the Customs Act because what happens at Sydney may well happen at Melbourne, Hobart, Perth, Darwin and every other port through which international traffic flows. To try to focus this inquiry on what happens at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, because the original embarrassing incident happened at Kingsford-Smith Airport, is not satisfactory to the people of this country, to the officers who have to deal with the Customs Act in this country, or, I believe, to this Parliament. Senator Durack said that the inquiry should be not only a manageable inquiry but also should report in a reasonable time. Yet nothing in his terms of reference suggests when that report should come forward or what is a reasonable time.

We asked for a judicial inquiry with the powers of a royal commission and, as Senator Button's amendment states, with the privileges of a royal commission, not to give the royal commissioner privileges but to give those people who may give evidence to this inquiry the protection they need. Who can deny that they need that protection when one reads the documents tabled in this place on 20 April, which give a clear documentation of what happened to Mr Tony Mayhew, who tried to pursue his duties, who tried to carry through the duties given to him as a Customs officer and who was obstructed at every stage by senior officers of the Department and, I suggest, at one stage by the Minister? We then had the allegation in this place that there were in fact further documents, and we asked that those documents be produced. The only document of significance which was produced was a report by a senior officer of the Bureau of Customs. Almost the whole of the page and a half of that report denigrates Mr Bennett and Mr Spanswick, who were Customs employees and officers of their staff association and who were attempting to represent Mr Mayhew and their association's members in that Department.

The whole of that document, without any supporting evidence, was an attempt to denigrate those two officers. If Mr Mayhew, who tried to carry out his duty, and if the officers of the Customs Officers Association of Australia, who tried to put his case, were subject to that sort of obstruction and that sort of denigration, what else can happen in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs as far as it affects its administration of the Customs Act? What else, we may ask, can be happening throughout the rest of Australia, not only at Kingsford-Smith Airport? If we establish an inquiry by a senior public servant- no matter what Senator Durack may call him-and an honourable man, which inquiry does not have the status, the powers and the privileges of a royal commission, what confidence can people such as Mr Mayhew, Mr Spanswick and Mr Bennett have if they come to give evidence to it? What protection do they have now or will they have in the future if they come along and tell what is going on in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs?

Why should we set up this second rate inquiry which provides no protection for witnesses and which has very limited terms of reference? Why should we as a Parliament be satisfied with that sort of inquiry when obviously what has gone on has been a serious attempt to cover up what initially may have been considered by some people to be a fairly trivial incident? I suggest that what is wrong with the inquiry which the Government is attempting to set up is in fact that it is not seen to be sufficiently independent. Despite what Senator Durack says, that is not a reflection on Mr Mahony. It is not seen to be sufficiently independent, first of all, because of Mr Mahony's history in the Public Service and, secondly, because of the obvious limitations on the nature of the inquiry he can conduct because he and witnesses do not have the protection that they would have in a judicial inquiry. We believe the inquiry is too narrow in its application because it deals specifically with the clearance of incoming passengers, the unaccompanied baggage of incoming passengers and incoming cargo at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. If Senator Durack means that the inquiry should be Australia-wide, why the particular reference to Sydney ( Kingsford-Smith) Airport?

It deals specifically with the relations between management, staff and staff associations. We know the management is not good at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Why should that not be extended to other areas? It refers to the need to ensure the efficient and impartial application of Customs procedures. We know quite clearly from the evidence contained in the green document tabled on 20 April that there was not an efficient and impartial application of Customs procedures at Sydney. Why should not we look at the situation in the whole of the country? Why should not we do so with the protection that is normally afforded to a judicial inquiry?

We suggest that the inquiry cannot and will not get at the deep sense of dissatisfaction which is apparent in the Department as far as the Bureau of Customs is concerned and which is apparent in the documents which were tabled on 20 April and in the document which was produced by Mr Kennedy and tabled. The inquiry cannot get at that deep dissatisfaction which obviously exists, for the people who give evidence to that inquiry cannot consider that they are protected when they give that evidence. There is no quarantee that they will be given that protection in the sort of inquiry that the Government suggests.

We suggest that the inquiry is not fair and cannot be seen to to be fair to Customs officers such as Mr Mayhew who quite clearly are under threat, as Mr Mayhew was under threat, if they insist on carrying out their duties and if part of those duties involves the giving of evidence to this inquiry and, again, they do not have the normal protection that people have in giving evidence to inquiries of this type. It is very hard to see how union representatives such as Mr Bennett and Mr Spanswick should have confidence in such an inquiry if they are not protected from being publicly maligned-as they were in a document before this Senate; a document which became privileged-if they give evidence to this inquiry.

Senator Button has moved an amendment tonight to the terms of reference of the inquiry into Customs administration. He has moved it specifically because there needs to be an inquiry which is independent and is seen to be independent. There are serious questions as to what is happening in the whole of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, particularly as it affects the administration of the Customs Act. If the inquiry that the Government proposes goes forward it needs to look particularly at the changes which are necessary and which, of necessity, will affect a senior officer of the Department who can have a severe effect on the careers of junior officers in the Department. We suggest that the only way to do this is to set up a judicial inquiry with, as Senator Button suggested, the status, powers and privileges of a royal commission.

This affair has gone far beyond the problems which were faced by two Ministers who have lost their portfolios. This affair goes to the very real conditions of work of members of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs who are administering Customs matters in this country. It goes to the very real conduct of industrial relations in this Department. It goes also to the relationships between senior and junior officers in this Department. I submit that one cannot do this in a fair way without setting up the sort of independent inquiry that Senator Button has suggested. It is no good saying that the inquiry that he has suggested tonight is different from the one that he suggested a week ago. Of course it is different from the one that he suggested a week ago. It is different because in that week we have had tabled in this place papers which have demonstrated that there is deep malaise in that Department. It is a terribly important Department. It is a Department which protects the frontiers of this country. It is a Department which is involved not only in the importation of colour television sets and black and white television sets but also in the importation of drugs and all sorts of other materials which could be of great detriment to the well-being of citizens of this country. For that reason we, as a Parliament, must make sure that that Department is working efficiently and that officers can carry out their duties without fear of the sorts of problems which faced Mr Mayhew, without fear of being stood over if they insist that what they saw and what they did was right. We can do this only through a judicial inquiry. Therefore, I firmly support the amendment moved by Senator Button and urge every other honourable senator to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating some statements relating to the so-called colour television set affair and papers about it tabled in the Senate by the Leader of the Government, Senator Sir John Carrick. I do not intend to debate the amendment moved by the Opposition for a very particular type of inquiry. My concern in entering this debate is that I believe, in view of papers tabled yesterday in the House of Representatives and today in the Senate, it appears in retrospect that a manifest injustice may have been done to Mr Moore, the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. My concern in this matter is heightened by a debate which took place yesterday in the House of Representatives and which was widely reported in the Press-a debate on a motion by the honourable member for Port Adelaide, Mr Mick Young. I quote just briefly from that debate. Mr Young said:

SPEECH.PARA: But what happened to Mr Garland?
He was referring to Mr Vic Garland, as he then was-
We are all aware of his appearance in the court and of the findings against him .

I remind the Senate that Mr Garland had some charges laid against him, appeared in court and was found innocent. It appears that, in matters relating to allegations against Ministers or members of parliament, it is not a case of innocent until proven guilty; it is a case of guilty even after being found innocent in the courts. There is no doubt at all that the request to resign that was made to Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore will have an abiding effect on their reputations and careers. I emphasise at this stage that because I will basically confine my comments to Mr Moore and the position that he appears to be in does not mean that I think Mr MacKellar deserves condemnation. But the papers tabled today in the Senate and yesterday in the House of Representatives cast a very particularly light on the position of Mr Moore as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and actions that he took or did not take and why he took them or did not take them.

The first lot of documents is contained in a little green covered booklet. If one wades through them one will see many things have been repeated. I want to pass through these documents just to show the sort of confusion that apparently existed in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs about the matter of Mr MacKellar's television set. I think there is nothing in the documents to suggest that there was a cover-up within the Department. I think a journalist from the Brisbane Courier-Mail, Mr Wallace Brown, phrased it better in an article that he wrote on the documents last Saturday when he referred to 'a bureaucratic gap'. There is a gap in the documents. That does not mean that documents are missing. I think the gap is that certain statements were made and assumptions followed from them, people acted in good faith in the belief that they were acting on good advice and the situation was compounded over and again, particularly as it related to Mr Mayhew and his allegations that the Minister had brought in a colour television set and had not paid duty on it.

The first document to which I wish to refer is a minute paper dated 5 October 1981-the day that Mr MacKellar arrived back in this country, from overseas. The minute was written by Mr Pattison, the officer who shepherded Mr MacKellar through Customs. I refer to the last paragraph of his report where he says:

After making an endorsement on the Customs and Quarantine Passenger statement, I ascertained that the Marshal involved was Senior Preventive Officer T. Mayhew who told me that the Minister was in possession of an undeclared colour T.V. set .

Mayhew was the officer who made a notation to the effect that some examination ought to be made of Mr MacKellar's baggage and who subsequently became upset because Mr MacKellar had passed through Customs with a colour television set. It appears that the report made on the first day of the offence is the first information that came to Mr Pattison that the Minister was carrying a colour television set. In a minute of 13 October 1981, Mr Kelly, who I assume is a Collector of Customs, makes a report headed 'Clearance of Mr M. J. R. MacKellar, Minister for Health' to the Assistant Collector. He states:
2. It is noted that Senior Preventive Officer A. Mayhew is of the view that Mr. MacKellar was in possesion of an undeclared colour television set.

3. Preventive Officer Woodley, a South Australian officer who was on attachment to Sydney Airport at the time, has been contacted about his recall of the matter . He advised that he commenced to process Mr. MacKellar's baggage prior to the Supervising Preventive Officer's intervention-
That is Pattison-
and noticed that Mr. MacKellar was in possession of an unboxed combination unit which included a television screen. On the basis of similar units that he had encountered in the past, he-
That is, Mr Woodley-
presumed the television to be a black and white one. The examination did not proceed to finality on account of the Supervising Preventive Officer's instructions.

4. Checks have also been made with Mr. MacKellar, and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has confirmed that Mr. MacKellar was in possession of a radio/cassette/black and white television combination unit when he arrived on 5 October.

That is the first statement in writing in which Mr Moore suggested that the television set was black and white. I will return to where that suggestion appears to have originated but I mention it now because I am attempting to trace through the attempts Mr Mayhew and later, I think, Mr Bennett made to bring to the attention of officers the fact that Mr MacKellar had carried a colour television set and the basis on which those officers looked at those claims and apparently disputed or rejected them. They believed, as stated in Mr Kelly's letter of 13 October, that Mr Moore had confirmed that the television set was black and white. Subsequently it appears that Mr Moore did nothing of the sort; that there was a misunderstanding.

The next document-closest in date to this, on the same date-is one which was tabled in this chamber yesterday. I think it is a document that makes a critical difference to the case that can be made or was made against Mr Moore. It was a minute from Mr Besley, the then Secretary of the Department, to Deputy Secretary Mr Montgomery-two gentlemen who seem to have had all the conversations with one another on the subject-Headed 'Mr MacKellar's Recent Arrival in Sydney'. The letter states:
The Minister-
That is Mr Moore-
phoned me-
Mr Besley-
last night. I told him that we had checked it out and that the equipment brought in by his Ministerial colleague was not dutiable.

On 12 October, according to Mr Besley, Mr Moore was told 'per telephone' that the matter had been checked out and the equipment brought in by Mr MacKellar was not dutiable. That is specific advice that was given to the Minister and that is advice that he apparently acted on from there on. I will return to that matter later.

The next document that mentions any of these matters is a minute of 19 October to the Collector of Customs from Mr Drury, Senior Assistant Collector, in which he refers to an approach from a Mr Bennett, who I understand is an executive officer with the Customs Officers Association. Mr Bennett attempted to pursue Mayhew's allegations regarding the television set and is mentioned frequently in the minutes. Converservations with him are mentioned frequently by various officers. The minute states that Mr Bennett was attempting to establish what progress had been made in respect of the importation of what Bennett described as 'an undeclared colour TV set'. Mr Bennett was then asked for an explanation of what he thought the offence was and part of that explanation, according to this summary, apparently was that Mr M. J. MacKellar, Minister for Health had imported a colour TV set which he had not declared.
Further on it is stated:

3. I told Mr Bennett that both you and I were aware of certain matters involving the clearance of Mr MacKellar through Customs on 5 October 1981. On that basis I could neither agree with his assertion that Internal Affairs should have been asked to enquire, nor did I accept his claim that the Minister had in fact imported an undeclared colour T.V. set.

4. Bennett argued that in his opinion the latter point was not in dispute. I asked him to elaborate and he said that the Minister had told an officer that he had in his possession a colour T.V. set and that the Minister had informed the same officer that he had paid in excess of $350 for it.
There is no further evidence to suggest that Mr MacKellar made the statement about the value of the set being $350 and the matter is not pursued in any way.
The minute continues:

5. Bennett then said that he wished to lay a formal complaint in his capacity as a Senior Preventive Officer, Grade I, in the following terms:-in clearing the effects of Mr M. J. MacKellar through Sydney ''an officer had not conducted himself correctly''. Bennett added that he expected feedback in respect of his complaint.
I hasten to add that that was not a complaint against Mr MacKellar but against the Customs officer who intervened and passed Mr MacKellar through Customs. The minute continues:

I informed Bennet that without acknowledging in any way the accuracy of his assertions I would report the complaint to you but whether an internal inquiry followed was not an immediate consequence. I asked Bennett if he agreed that the essential point in his complaint was whether the TV set in question was either colour or black and white. He said that he did and explained that he was anxious only that officers were left in no doubt as to whether V.I.P.'s were to receive special treatment or were to be dealt with equally under the law.
Following this information, Mr Drury interviewed Mr Mayhew. The minute goes on:
Mayhew told Drury this morning the following:
when he intercepted the Minister on 5 October he asked what he had under his arm to which the Minister is alleged to have replied ''a colour TV set'';
he then asked the Minister had he read the declaration and claims the Minister said, ''No'';
at this point he directed the Minister to P. O. Woodley for examination which was soon after aborted by the intervention of Pattison;
he advised Woodley to make an entry in his official notebook;
That is Mayhew-
at no point did Mayhew discuss values with the Minister.
on account of the Mayhew/Woodley conversation, I phoned Woodley again-
Drury is continuing-

You will recall that I spoke to him last Monday, 12 October, at his home. Woodley agreed that Mayhew had suggested he make a notebook entry of the MacKellar incident. I asked Woodley to read it to me and the following is a fairly good paraphrase of what is recorded:

'At 0730 hours I was handed a declaration from Mr Mackellar, Minister for Health. All boxes ticked ''No.'' Minister in possession of one combination colour T.V. set. Examination not proceeded with following instruction from Sup. P.O.

10. Woodley-perhaps recalling his earlier conversation with me-made the comment immediately he had read the notebook entry that the reference to ''colour'' was incorrect. He agreed that a week ago he had told me that he thought it had been a black and white unit. I then asked why he had written ''colour''. He claimed that he had been somewhat carried away with the events as they happened and probably had been swayed by Mayhew's claim that the unit had included a colour T .V.

11. I then read to Woodley the third paragraph of your minute of 13 October and asked him to comment. Woodley described the account of events as you have outlined them as ''exactly correct''. He then repeated to me that his notebook entry was wrong and that he wished to change it. I told him that he should not alter his notebook and should not construe any conversation which I had held with him as suggesting such action. I added that I would report what he had told me.

There starts another area of confusion within the bureaucracy as to whether Woodley actually had a recollection at the time that the television set was colour or whether he had assumed it to be black and white.

The next document which is of some interest, is dated 23 October 1981. I am afraid that I will have to skip through some of these documents but I do want to show how I think there was a misunderstanding and how Mr Moore's views were incorrectly portrayed within the Bureau of Customs, which led to certain Customs officers believing that there might have been a cover up. I have here a minute to the Senior Assistant Collector (Services) from Mr Kelly regarding clearance of Mr M. J. R. MacKellar, Minister for Health. It states:

When the question of Mr MacKellar's clearance first came to attention, steps were taken to ascertain what he had imported. Mr MacKellar subsequently confirmed to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs that he was in possession of a radio/cassette/black and white television unit upon his arrival on 5 October.

In fact, there is no evidence and the indications are that Mr MacKellar did not confirm that it was black and white, nor did he state it was colour. At that point, whether the television set was black and white or colour does not seem to have been the subject of much discussion between anyone. But an assumption was made that Mr Moore had inquired of Mr MacKellar; Mr MacKellar had confirmed. It was that assumption, that belief, that gets repeated over and over again in the minute papers, I believe, in totally good faith by the officers concerned that appears to condemn Mr Moore. The minute continues:

Against the background of Mr Bennett's complaint it could still be argued that there is a conflict between S. P. O. Mayhew's recollection of what Mr MacKellar apparently said to him and what Mr MacKellar subsequently advised to the Minister.
The doubt is whether he did advise any such thing to the Minister. The minute continues:

Resolution of this situation could be achieved by seeking to have an officer view the unit which Mr MacKellar imported and any accompanying documentation to establish whether a black and white or colour television was involved.

I am not satisfied that action along these lines is required. Mr MacKellar as a Minister of the Crown, in response to a specific question put to him, has advised the Minister that the unit he imported included a black and white television set. There the matter should rest.

There was no specific question. There is no indication that there was a specific question. But senior Customs officers believed it and the belief grew. That is the bureaucratic gap that was referred to earlier. Other documents repeat and repeat these items: The matter of Mayhew and Bennett repeating the allegation, pressing for an inquiry as to whether the television set was black and white or colour; senior Customs officers repeating the statement that Mr MacKellar had assured Mr Moore that it was a black and white set and not a colour one; and so it goes on. There is a minute paper of 8 January to the Collector of Customs from Mr Williams, Acting Senior Assistant Collector, which contains that view. There is a minute from Mr Tuite of 25 January 1982, which states that an inquiry had been conducted at Ministerial level and that it had been conclusively established that the imported article was free of duty. There is a minute to the Senior Assistant Collector (Services) from Mr Kelly, again indicating that Bennett was pursuing his complaint. There is a minute paper from Mr Woodley in which he explains why he changed his notebook entry. He said:

At the completion of my shift I finished the entry in the notebook and found that I had included the word colour, as this was not correct and I do not know if the set was colour or black and white I lined out the word colour.

Clearly, from all these papers, Mr Woodley became confused about whether it was a black and white or a colour television set and decided that he could not state one way or the other on the subject. There is another statement from Mr Woodley which is a minute paper to the Senior Assistant Collector (Services) giving a full outline of his version of the event. The next minute paper is one coming close to the time when the matter became a large public issue and the two Ministers in question had to resign. On 16 April 1982 a minute went to Mr Moore from the then and present Secretary to his Department, Mr Hayes, in which, in summarising the documents, he drew attention to paragraph 4 of the minute of 13 October 1981 from the Collector of Customs, New South Wales. Mr Hayes says:

Checks have also been made with Mr MacKellar, and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has confirmed that Mr MacKellar was in possession of a radio/ cassette black and white television combination unit when he arrived on 5 October. Such units are admissable under Bylaw free of duty as general concessions to arriving passengers.
He continues:

I have inquired of the Collector of Customs New South Wales as to the source of this advice. He has informed me today that the material quoted above was based on advice provided to him verbally by a previous Deputy Secretary of this Department (Mr Montgomery). Mr Montgomery has advised me that his information came from the then Secretary (Mr Besley). Mr Besley, in turn, has advised me that his advice had come from you.
That is, Mr Moore. Mr Hayes continues:

The remaining folios concern themselves mainly with expressions of dissatisfaction by the Customs Officers' Association about what had happened. Central to the Department's insistence that the case was closed was the advice that you had confirmed with Mr MacKellar that the television unit was a black and white unit and as such was admissable free of duty.

So it appears that the line of communication was from Mr Montgomery to Mr Besley to Mr Moore and then back down again and that all that communication was verbal. It was on the basis of those verbal communications on which we have now had a little more light shed that it was believed, in the lower ranks, that Mr Moore had investigated the matter. The next document of interest is one from Mr Besley , who is no longer Secretary to the Department, but who was at the time the incident happened. It is a letter to Mr Hayes, the current Secretary, in which he outlines the facts as he recalls them, of the incident involving Mr MacKellar 's arrival on 5 October 1981. I quote from parts of the letter. It states:

I was informed that Mr MacKellar had arrived that morning, that he had been delayed because of arrangements connected with the arrival that day of HRH the Duke of Edinburgh, that his Customs declaration had been filled in on his behalf and was not accurate in that it did not disclose that he was carrying a combination radio/cassette/television set. I was also informed that Mr MacKellar had been selected for baggage examination and that while this was in course a more senior Customs Officer had recognised Mr MacKellar and had directed that the examination cease and that he be passed through Customs. All of this information was conveyed to me by Deputy Secretary Montgomery.

I rang the Minister for BACA and said that I was concerned at the inadequate or possibly false declaration on a passenger statement by Mr MacKellar. I urged the Minister to ring Mr MacKellar and point out the problems which could be caused by such action.
That is, the false declaration by Mr MacKellar. The letter continues:

I suggested to the Minister that he might ask his colleague what kind of TV it was. At that stage I was not aware of a conversation which apparently took place between Mr MacKellar and a Customs Officer in which Mr MacKellar was said to have stated that the television part of the combination set was a colour television.

Subsequently, the Minister called me back. He said he had stressed to Mr MacKellar the seriousness of making an inaccurate Passenger Statement and that Mr MacKellar had assured him that it would not occur again. The Minister then said he wished to regard that as the end of the matter.

I then told Deputy Secretary Montgomery that I had spoken to the Minister who had in turn spoken to Mr MacKellar and then spoken again to me. I referred briefly to the Minister's counselling of Mr MacKellar on the need to accurately complete Passenger Entry forms and said the Minister regarded the matter as closed. Accordingly the Minister must regard the television as black and white and no duty is chargeable.

There is no indication that the subject of whether it was a black and white or a colour television set was ever discussed by Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar. Certainly the indication is that it was not raised again with Mr Besley when Mr Moore called him back. But he did not query it. He made an assumption that Mr Moore had discussed it with Mr MacKellar. It appears to be a false assumption. Mr Moore's Press statement of 17 April makes some reference to the fact that in his conversation with MacKellar he had emphasised his concern about the false declaration. Again, there is no indication of any pursuit of the fact of whether the television set was black and white or colour by Mr Moore. Apparently he did not, and Mr MacKellar did not raise the subject with him either. I quote briefly from that statement:
Mr Moore said that subsequently he had decided that that should be the end of the matter.
That was after admonishing Mr MacKellar on the false declaration. The statement continued:
In coming to this decision Mr Moore said he had regard for the fact that Mr MacKellar had been cleared by the Supervising Preventive Officer exercising his judgement in the normal course of duty.

So Mr Moore made a judgment about whether the matter should be pursued on the basis of what apparently was the practice of a senior Customs officer. The next matter that happened after the conversation between Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar was, of course, Mr MacKellar's letter dated 13 October 1981. I do not know whether it is known when that letter was actually received by Mr Moore. It may have been on the same day. Again it just refers to a portable radio TV cassette appliance. Apparently neither Minister was aware that it was a matter of any significance, that there was a difference between a black and white set and a colour set. That really was the central issue.

Some criticism was made in the last few days of the fact that Mr Moore did not act on that letter. In fact we now have the information in papers tabled yesterday in the House of Representatives and in papers tabled today in the Senate that on the day before Mr MacKellar had written his letter, the Minister had been advised by Mr Besley that the matter had been checked out. The Department said, in effect: 'We have checked it out'. His Department had checked it out and the equipment brought in by his ministerial colleague was not dutiable. I suggest to the Senate that Mr Moore's behaviour was entirely reasonable. I was distressed today to hear Senator Tate, a Labor senator from Tasmania, in debate on some Customs legislation, refer to a hypocritical connivance by Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar. That just is not so. The facts do not bear out any such allegation. I interjected in Senator Tate's speech and asked on what he based his allegation of a connivance. He replied: 'The documents that have been tabled in the Senate'. I challenge any honourable senator to indicate that any such thing at all occurred. The documents do not prove anything of the sort. Unfortunately, it is possible for Senator Tate to say that sort of thing and almost make it stick because that was a general belief when the documents were incomplete.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly right. We got another set of documents today.

—I agree with that, Senator Georges. The new documents which were tabled in the House yesterday and here today indicate something very different. There are headlines and stories on the matter in the newspapers today. A story in the Australian carried the headline: 'Document suggests MacKellar did not have to pay duty.' There is a story in the Courier-Mail, under the headline: ' Office note may clear Moore'. The suggestion is that that statement by Besley turns it all around. I believe it does. I take the Government's word utterly that it has done an investigation and there are no indications of other documents. The Opposition makes an allegation that there are. If it can produce them, well and good but if it does not we have to assume there are no other documents that give any indication to the contrary. It is my firm belief that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) should reappoint Mr John Moore to the Ministry.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been much speculation on ministerial re-shuffles. I certainly do not have any inside information on that. I urge the Prime Minister, as strongly as I can, to make it clear that, on the basis of the evidence available, John Moore did nothing wrong. He was in fact a capable, intelligent Minister who has served the Government and this country well. As I said at the beginning of my speech, it would be a grave injustice if a slur was left against his name such as could be the case in this matter when the evidence does not suggest that it is justified.

I make one final appeal. At the beginning of last week some newspaper editorials, on the basis of information they had available, demanded that Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar should resign. I had my own feelings about whether they had enough information, but not all newspaper editorials-I hasten to add-went so far. The Courier-Mail noted that Mr Fraser faced a difficult decision in the matter and did not specifically urge that the Ministers should either be sacked or that they should resign. I now urge the same newspaper editors, who had judged Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar guilty at the beginning of last week, to look at fresh evidence and decide whether their editorials should not indicate something to that effect in the next few days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Martin is in fact supporting the amendment that the Opposition has moved. She has outlined a case which is based on the further documents which have been tabled in the Senate which strongly support the proposition that there should be a full judicial inquiry. The person who has been appointed the head the inquiry should have full powers to investigate, to call witnesses and to have those witnesses protected in order to seek the fullest information possible. The matter now is far more serious than some breakdown of efficiency in the procedures within the Bureau of Customs. It appears clear from the documents tabled today that at least one of the Ministers may have been unjustly dealt with. He may have been unjustly dealt with because he was misinformed, deliberately or otherwise, by his Department to the point that he made no disclosures to the Parliament. In my view, he was misinformed. Whether this was deliberate or not needs to be determined.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I have been a member of this Parliament I have witnessed another instance where a Minister was misinformed, in that case by the head of his Department. He was lied to by the head of his Department.I knew that the head of the Department had lied because he had also lied to me. In spite of that, the Minister lost his position. It was a most unjust action on the part of the Prime Minister at the time. In that case the Minister had to bear the full brunt of the error of his Department.

Let us put ministerial responsibility to one side for the moment. Ministerial responsibility surely does not mean that the Minister, no matter how well respected or how well he performs, should have to bear the brunt of misinformatiom from his Department. These documents which have suddenly appeared today seem to indicate that. I ask the Leader of the Government (Senator Sir John Carrick) who was party to that action which accepted the resignation of these Ministers whether he could explain to me how he came to the decision to accept those resignations when all the information was not before him. The information today negates much of the information given previously. It certainly puts Mr Moore in a better light, but it certainly does not put the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or the Cabinet in a very good light at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Cabinet.

—Or the Cabinet; it has now reached the stage where the Prime Minister may again be in error. He has made a decision against one of his Ministers to the extreme disadvantage of that Minister. This has happened before ; it happened with Eric Robinson. The environment created by the Prime Minister may have even accelerated Eric Robinson's death. Senator Reg Withers, who now sits abandoned on the Government back benches, is there because of a decision of the Prime Minister-a most unfair one if I might say so. I have no brief for the Ministers of the Government. On that occasion, we were at war with Reg Withers every day in this place, but the decision of the Prime Minister on that occasion was a most unjust one. I do not doubt that the reasons we have the Australian Democrats here is because of the same attitude of the same Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I am prepared to say that if the ballot of the parliamentary Liberal Party members were to have taken place after the resignations of these two Ministers were forced the result could have been quite different. It seems to me that the person who should resign, or should have resigned if ministerial responsibility is to be thrust home, is the Prime Minister himself. He ought to look very closely at these documents and at the position in which Mr Moore is now placed and should reconsider his decision. It seems to me that a grave injustice has been done here. If the Prime Minister had not been so precipitate Mr Moore might still be a Minister today. I outline another scenario: The whole thing is a hoax . The two resignations are a deliberate scheme. What will happen is that there will be a judicial inquiry and the Ministers will be exonerated because of some breakdown in communications within the Bureau of Customs. The Ministers possibly will be chastised as being bad boys and reappointed to the Minister and that is the reason why new Ministers have not been appointed. I do not think that is the case; possibly one could paint that scenario. It seems to me that somewhere the responsibility for the misleading of this Parliament should be sheeted home and it can only be sheeted home to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister should do the right thing; that is, he should reappoint Mr Moore as a Minister and resign himself. For too long we have had the intolerant and arrogant actions of this man imposed upon the Parliament.

Let me get back to discussing the need for the judicial inquiry. The inquiry should be, as the Opposition intends it to be, a full judicial inquiry if for no other reason than to clear the name of Mr Moore. As far as Mr MacKellar is concerned I think he was trapped by the circumstances. I think that when Mr MacKellar was directed to an assessment point, if the supervisor had not interfered at that time and given that Customs clearance Mr MacKellar would have paid whatever penalty might have been imposed or he might even have surrendered the television set at that point. My belief is that that would have happened. But the supervisor on his own responsibility intervened and cleared Mr MacKellar through Customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there was a false document.

—Yes, there was that document too. But even if the document were false there is time for recovery when a person gets to the point of the Customs check. The officer says: 'You go there for an assessment'. The person goes. Up to that point a person is still in a position of recovery-if I can put it that way. I think Mr MacKellar was at the point of recovery when the supervisor intervened and cleared him. He should have stood his ground at that stage. This is like someone giving one a right of way when it is not one's right of way. One has to jump up and down to force the person giving the right of way to take the right of way. What Mr MacKellar should have done at that stage was insist on not being cleared through Customs. But the supervisor cleared him. From that point a whole series of events and conversations occurred and a whole series of messages were exchanged which misled one Minister. That is why this inquiry is very important. It should be a judicial inquiry that gives Mr Mahony the powers that are necessary to bring before him whoever he wants brought before him. Those people should be able to speak clearly and fearlessly about what happened. The whole mess would then sort itself out.

SPEECH.PARA: This should have been sorted out in the first place by the Prime Minister. He is too busy establishing his own credibility to the disadvantage of others. What occurred in this case does not happen in the National Party. Of course, the other extreme occurs in the National Party. We have a Prime Minister who will discard Minister after Minister in order to establish some false credibility. In this case, because of the documents that were tabled today, he again is at a loss. The Senate should insist that the Prime Minister and the Cabinet who imposed these penalties upon these two Ministers should reflect. I do not doubt that Mr MacKellar's position is as a result of an error. He was entrapped in a position which perhaps could justifiably lead to a resignation with that resignation being accepted. The same thing does not hold for Mr Moore. That should have been apparent some time ago. This situation should not have been suddenly made apparent as a result of these two extraordinary documents that we have before us today. One struggles through them wondering what sort of an organisation this is, what sort of place this Parliament is, what sort of a Ministry we have and what sort of a government we have, that dribble forth information in this way. Suddenly we find that the Parliament may have been at fault. The only way to recover from this fault is to support the amendment calling for a full judicial inquiry and to give to Mr Mahony the power that he needs to unravel this sorry mess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) to the motion that the Senate take note of the papers and the statement. The point that I made on 21 April was that the most serious aspect of what has been going on in the so-called colour television set affair was the possible victimisation of a public servant who was engaged in carrying out his duties. The point of that allegation, of course, is that the law as set down by the Parliament must be observed by all citizens. The document put down yesterday by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) in the House of Representatives did not seem, upon reading it, to deal specifically with this issue. However, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) tonight in his speech made specific reference to that problem.
—Order! Senator Macklin, you have already spoken to the motion. You should confine your remarks entirely to the amendment, not to the motion.

—I am speaking to the amendment. Senator Button also made reference in support of his amendment to that particular element, that is, the possible victimisation of a public servant and stated that it was the central and gravest issue of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The choice is between supporting either the position taken by the Government in terms of the review of administration and procedures of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs or the proposal by Senator Button for a royal commission into the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. In order for us to be able to choose between those proposals I think we really rely very heavily on a speech that was made tonight by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Senator Sir John Carrick made specific reference to that particular item and gave unequivocal assurances that the terms of reference as set down in the Government's inquiry would be able to take that into account. Since the Senate does not have the power to establish a royal commission and since the only inquiry will be that which the Government has proposed, it would seem acceptable that the Government's proposition be supported, particularly in view of the very strong assurances given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate tonight.

Two other items that Senator Button raised in support of his amendment, I think , have bearing and are of concern; that is, the lack of a closing date in the terms of reference provided by the Government for the review of Customs administration and also-although this is referred to in the speech by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs which was incorporated-the lack of a reporting mechanism to this Parliament. I quote from the statement which was incorporated. The report of the inquiry will be:
. . . in a form that may be made public subject, of course, to any particular part that should be treated confidently.

I think that is a drawback to the Government's proposition. Nevertheless, four Australian Democrats will be supporting the Government's position. This is based on the assurances given in the Senate tonight by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Senator Siddons will be taking a different view and will be speaking later in the debate in relation to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved so ably by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). From the debate that has ensued on this matter one can see how correct the Opposition is in suggesting that there needs to be a full and public judicial inquiry into the Bureau of Customs and all of the circumstances that surrounded the crisis which hit the Government just 10 days ago. I remind the Senate that the reluctance of the Government to extend the terms of reference and to accept that there is a need for a thorough review of the activities of the Bureau of Customs is in line with the Government's attitude with respect to previous inquiries and royal commissions. The Fraser Government's attitude now is synonymous with the attitude it has had since it came to office in 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of royal commissions and public inquiries have been conducted. With only one or two exceptions, they have shown that there has been a reluctance on the part of the Government to have a full and proper inquiry into the matters that required the establishment of either a royal commission or a public inquiry . There is no exception in respect of this matter, as this debate this evening has shown. I am not as generous with respect to Mr Moore as the honourable senators from Queensland-Senators Martin and Georges -were in their contributions. The terms of reference state:

To review the administration and procedures of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in regard to the control and clearance of imported goods under the Customs Act in relation to New South Wales . . .

I think the very fact that the Government has seen fit to make that part of the terms of reference is in itself an indictment of the way in which the operations of that Department were being conducted. Having regard to all that has been said about the Customs Bureau in the Parliament in recent years and to all the public statements that have been made by Customs officers and officials of their association, one would have thought that the Government would have been alerted to the sort of problem that obviously exists in the day to day administration. While there may have been some merit in the contributions of those two Queensland senators specifically about Mr Moore, the fact is that I see a dereliction of duty in respect of Mr Moore's inability to get his Department functioning properly, having regard to the published statements and comments that have been made in the Parliament since 1977 about the problems in the Customs area.

To endorse what I have to say I would have only to remind honourable senators about the establishment of the McGregor royal commission and the reluctance of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to extend properly the terms of reference in respect of that matter. I remind the Senate that the Prime Minister criticised the McGregor royal commission and refused to provide it with adequate terms of reference to inquire into the matter which is now known as the Withers affair. Because of the determination of the Opposition, two members of the Government in the other House and Mr Justice McGregor's own contribution in his letter of 12 May 1978 in which he said that if the Government wanted a more extensive inquiry it would have to extend the terms of reference, the Prime Minister was forced to extend those terms of reference.

Originally it appeared that Mr Eric Robinson was to be the casualty in that inquiry whereas, of course, when the terms of reference were extended and the inquiry carried out its task it was found that there had been an improper influence by Senator Withers in that matter which caused his removal from the office of Leader of the Government in the Senate. There were also, of course, the nefarious activities of Mr Coleman, the electoral officer in Queensland. Following the establishment of that commission there was the establishment of Mr Justice Williams's Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs in Australia.

Arising from that was the establishment of the inquiry by Sir Robert Mark into the activities of the Australian Federal Police. Again there was the necessity for two inquiries to carry out the job that could have been done effectively by one inquiry if, in fact, there had been adequate and extensive terms of reference in relation to that issue, which brought about the amalgamation of the Australian Capital Territory Police and the Federal Police and a transfer of the activites of the Narcotics Bureau from the Customs Bureau to the jurisdiction of the Australian Federal Police. We have seen in more recent times, as a result again of public pressure both in the Parliament and outside it, the establishment of Mr Justice Stewart's royal commission into specific questions about the operations of Mr Asia and the drug scene in Australia. As a result of the determination of the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Hayden, and to a minor extent of myself, in the matter of the inability of Mr Justice Stewart's royal commission to carry out its proper function, the Government last week was forced to agree to extend the terms of reference to look into all the factors relating to Nugan Hand Ltd and the other matters related to drug running in this country.

Today we have had the spectacle of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator John Carrick, making an admission that, in fact, there has been extensive currency manipulation, laundering of money and criminality at the highest level in this country that require a further extension, I submit to the Senate, of the terms of reference so that a proper inquiry can be carried out. Again the Opposition finds itself unable to accept the Government's limitations in respect of the operations of the Customs Bureau and all the facts that relate to the resignations of Ministers Moore and MacKellar. We had the spectacle of an all-day meeting of the Cabinet last Monday week and the persuasiveness of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in convincing the Cabinet of the need for some propriety to be established in respect of the activities of those two Ministers.

As a consequence of that, documents were tabled and debated in the Senate a week ago. Since then we have had two subsequent tablings of documents. That shows how incompetent this Government is and how incompetent its adviers are in respect of this whole sorry eopisode. One can only say that anything short of a judicial inquiry will fail to overcome the malaise that exists in the Customs Bureau. In the document that has been made available to us today we have a suggestion by the new Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr N. A. Brown , that Mr Mahony, the person proposed to conduct the inquiry, be given the responsibility to conduct public hearings in his own right. The document states that Mr Mahony may decide to hold public hearings.

The work of the Government has been disrupted for a quite considerable period. We have had the resignations of two Ministers of the Crown. We have had public criticism by Customs officers. We have had an attempt to intimidate officers whose public responsibility it was to provide properly for the accountability of dutiable goods in this country. In the wake of all that the Government has placed restrictions upon the ablity of the inquiry to carry out its work. What comes clearly out of all of this is that we have one law for the privileged-for the rich-and one law for the poor.

A sort of cover up and conspiracy clearly exists in this area. An attempt was made to keep from either the Minister or top officials in the Department certain basic information which affected the effective functioning of the Bureau of Customs.

I find it inconceivable that two Ministers of the Crown would not know what their responsibilities were on this question of duty with respect to imported goods. I find it impossible to accept that the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs would not have asked the obvious question as to whether the television set was black and white or colour. I cannot accept, therefore, the view that has been expressed that in some way or other he has been done an injustice. I believe that, in the context of ministerial responsibility, the former Minister failed to carry out his accepted role of leadership of his Department. Of course, if there was a conspiracy of the top brass in the Bureau of Customs I am not so sure, having regard to the obvious attempts that were made, to imtimidate Mr Mayhew and to denigrate Mr Spanswick and Mr Bennett-they are clearly evidenced in the documents-that we can get any sort of justice from the sort of limited inquiry that suggests itself in the documents that are now available to us.

The view held by Senators Martin and Georges about Mr Moore may well be justified, but are we to establish those sorts of facts? Are we going to establish whether the Bureau of Customs operates in accordance with its obligations to the Parliament and to the Australian people? I wonder why it is that, when the Government is forced to establish royal commissions or inquiries, they are always given very restrictive terms of reference which means that they do not get to the heart of the problem and do not have the sort of investigative role to produce findings that establish the truth beyond all reasonable doubt. Why is it that we are forced constantly into the position of elucidating from the Government the reasons for its reluctance to extend these terms of reference ?

No explanation is given by the Ministers as to why, for the third time within a week, we have been given extra documents. It is all right for Senator Sir John Carrick to say that the Government is convinced that no further documents will be forthcoming. That is what we expected after the original tabling of documents . They were tabled in the belief that they comprised all the available documentation. We were then given another set of documents. Now we have a third, and we cannot be sure that it is the final set. A great deal of empirical evidence is available and much criticism has been raised publicly in this place over the last three or four years since 1977. We have asked questions about the malfunction of the Bureau of Customs in New South Wales. We have asked why this inquiry is to be restricted to New South Wales. Is it suggested that in every other State the effective functioning of the Bureau is an accepted fact? That was the Government's view until this blow-up occurred.

We are not opposing the Government's propositions just for the sake of opposing them; we are opposing them because we do not think they go far enough. We do not believe that the restrictions that are placed upon the terms of reference can in any way establish once and for all the effectiveness of this inquiry. One is therefore entitled to say that the Opposition is acting responsibly in this matter by moving an amendment. I remind the Senate that there is no doubt that had it not been for the persistence of the Press and the media over the weekend before Parliament resumed, the persistence of the Opposition and the knowledge that Parliament would be sitting and making judgments about these matters, no doubt it was in the minds of the Ministers that they could ride out the storm. That was their view. They were forced into a position based on the determination of public opinion that they had a price to pay.

I find it incomprehensible that it has been suggested in the statement of the current Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) that the two former Ministers involved have paid a heavy price. I think those words were used today by Senator Durack. When I asked a question yesterday about the procedures that operate at an international terminal he gave me a very unsatisfactory answer. I wanted to know whether, for example, it was not a fact that at a person's point of entry into this country, when he hands over his passport, he is asked by a Customs official whether the signature appearing on the form is his and whether he has any goods to declare. There is no evidence in the written reports of those questions having been asked. That is the procedeur that is applied to Mr and Mrs John Citizen in our country. Those questions are posed to each one of us when we come into this country. Yet there is no suggestion that they were asked or answered in this case. Does it mean that only certain classes of people are asked those sorts of questions, that in the case of the privileged few, the questions are not asked and therefore no answers are given; or is it a fact that Mr MacKellar orally answered those questions in the negative? That would mean that the position that he took on this matter was of even greater culpability than that which has been suggested. There is nothing in the documents to say that those procedures were carried out.

We find that an absurd position exists in that there is absolutely no obligation on citizens coming into this country personally to sign the form. That is certainly not the general view. I have never filled out my wife's form when we have returned from overseas. I think all citizens of our country believe that they have an obligation to do that for themselves; yet we are told that the regulations do not require it to be done by the individual. That is a most alarming state of affairs. Does that suggest that the procedures ought to be tighteded up? Does it mean that in future I can just fill out the form on behalf of my wife and let her carry in dutiable goods for which she is in no way likely to be penalised and about which she is not likely to be asked a question because somebody else filled in her form?

These matters ought to be included in the terms of reference. There ought to be some explanation about these sorts of matters. The terms of reference are so restrictive as to be totally unsatisfactory. As Senator Grimes suggested, there is a breakdown in industrial relations in this Department. That is what the Customs Officers Association of Australia has been saying in public statements. That is what I have been saying on the odd occasions when such matters have been raised in this place. That is what has been said repeatedly and consistently. But what was the action of Ministers for Business and Consumer Affairs both prior to Mr Moore's appointment and in the period in which he was the Minister? What steps did he take to have these matters remedied? Responsible officers at senior levels within the Department do not make these statements just for the sake of them; yet on the record are at least a dozen statements made over the last three or four years suggesting that there was something rotten in the state of the Bureau of Customs.

The Government was forced to take steps to remove the Narcotics Bureau from the Customs areas and transfer it to the Australian Federal Police. An adequate explanation was never given. The Parliament is treated with disrespect by the Executive and the Prime Minister. As I indicated earlier, the Government has been forced ultimately to extend the terms of reference of all its Public Service inquiries and royal commissions to get to the truth of the matter. We are determined as far as is possible in this case to press on until we get to the crux of the problem that exists in the Customs Bureau to see that body properly carry out its function, to see that ministerial propriety and responsibility are accepted by this Government and to see that the revenue provided for in the Budget Papers is properly and adequately collected by Customs officers. I am not talking only of what happens at Sydney Airport. The biggest proportion of funds that come from excise and dutiable goods does not come purely from the international airport at Sydney. Obviously major problems exist in the Department.
