Sooner or later it will be shown to the satisfaction of the Parliament and the Australian people that this Government is shirking its responsibility by not accepting the amendment which has been moved by Senator Button and which is supported by members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Button on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. In doing so I will be voting differently from my four colleagues on this occasion. I wish briefly to explain my reasons. Firstly, it is a basic tenet of the Australian Democrats' policy that our parliamentarians are able to express an independent point of view. I exercise that right on this occasion for two very basic reasons which I consider are important. The Government has initiated an inquiry into this matter on the basis that there will be no fixed date for the inquiry to terminate. As Senator Button pointed out, this means that the inquiry can be delayed until after an election has been held. Secondly, and perhaps more importantly, I fail to see how a Public Service inquiry can inquire into the Public Service and be a fair, reasonable and independent inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this whole matter started in the manner of comic opera. I could not believe my eyes when I saw in the Press that the resignations of two Ministers were likely over what seemed to me a comparatively trivial matter. 'Let the punishment fit the crime' started ringing in my ears. But information has come to light that there was victimisation in a very important department. That is serious. What is also very serious is the fact that two very important Ministers of this Government have seen fit to tender their resignations over the incident. We can no longer treat the incident as trivial. There are some very unusual aspects to it. I believe the only way the good names and reputations of the two Ministers can be cleared is by a genuine independent judicial inquiry. Then there could be no doubt about its findings. As the inquiry is currently constituted there can be all the doubts in the world. For these reasons, essentially in the interests of justice on this occasion, I find it necessary to vote other than with my colleagues. I support the motion moved by Senator Button .

Item 3. Petitions
Consideration resumed from 27 April 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is dealing with the report of the Senate Standing Orders Committee. I begin by recording my view that the Committee of the Whole should not debate the Standing Orders of the Senate when its proceedings are being broadcast. I do not regard them as matters of such significance and importance for listeners outside the chamber that we should be debating them on air. I think there are far more important topics of general concern to people in this country than the Standing Orders of the Senate which are really only the rules which govern debate in this place. However, there is involved in the Standing Orders an important issue-not sufficiently important to be dealt with when the proceedings of this chamber are being broadcast-which relates to the petitions which are presented by various constituents to members of parliament for presentation in the Senate. The present practice is that petitions are collected by various people in what I regard as a most worthwhile activity as part of the democratic process. The presentation of petitions to Parliament is a very ancient custom. Those petitions are collected, as Senator Mason pointed out with great gusto in a contribution yesterday, and are sent to this Parliament. The present situation is that they are read by members of parliament and then they disappear from view .
—They are inwardly digested.

—Senator Rae interjects that they are inwardly digested. Certainly whatever happens to them is inward because nothing outward happens to them after they have been read in this chamber. They are put away, as it were. I do not think there is any real indication for those people who have sent petitions to the Parliament of what has happened to them except that they have been read here by honourable senators. I want again to put to the Committee that it is in a sense a waste of time for honourable senators to read petitions in the Senate when its proceedings are being broadcast. Of course, petitions are presented on both Tuesdays and Wednesdays. Some petitions are read on air and others are read when the Senate proceedings are not on air on Tuesdays. There is no reason, in my view, why this practice should continue. The important thing about petitions is the involvement of citizens and electors in expressing their concern about and interest in topics being discussed by the national Parliament and in involving their fellow citizens in that process.

SPEECH.PARA: The procedure recommended for the future by the Standing Orders Committee, of which I am a member, is that petitions should not be read by senators because that adds nothing to the democratic process. All it means is that time is spent in that exercise. The important thing is that it is suggested by the Standing Orders Committee that in future petitions in summary form should be read by the Clerk of the Senate, taking much less time and allowing the Senate to proceed with Question Time, another traditional and important aspect of parliamentary democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh yes! I start to laugh about Question Time being more important than petitions.

—I am glad that I have the support of Senator Georges on this issue. If only he were on the Standing Orders Committee he would be able to make some very intelligent suggestions, I am sure, about what ought to be done with Question Time. The important point which I wish to make is that the proposal is not only that petitions which have been collected by citizens and electors and sent to this Parliament should be read by the Clerk in summary form but also that from now on petitions should be referred to standing committees of the Senate for consideration. I think that is a very important recommendation. It means that petitions, when read in this place, have not reached, in a sense, the end of their lives but are to be referred to standing committees which will consider them.
—What will the standing committees do with them?

—Senator Mason asks what the standing committee will do with them . That is not for me to say. I assume that he is a member of a standing committee and that he will make it his business to see that something very worthwhile is done with them. But of course standing committees can make recommendations to the Senate about the contents of petitions. I think that at least the democratic process which is started in the electorates when petitions are collected by citizens is kept alive and before the Senate, which is not the situation at present. I hope that the procedure which is designed to improve the proceedings of the Senate would have appeal to the Committee as a whole because I think it is an important initiative which represents a break with the past and it is a better system for dealing with the matter than is available to us now. I have frequently expressed the view that the reading of petitions in this Parliament on broadcast day can do nothing for the ratings of this place-I talk in broadcast terms.
—Why are you repeating yourself? Because you are on the air?

—I am getting a lot of support from my colleagues here, but I want to make it quite clear as to where the Standing Orders Committee stands on this matter and why it arrived at this conclusion about the future of petitions. I think we have to do everything we can to make this Parliament more relevant in all its activities, and the reading of petitions is not a relevant activity. It is not one which will encourage people to listen to Parliament. People want to listen to Parliament to hear debates, and that is the important issue. Finally, let me make the point that governments have to make decisions and parliaments have to approve or disapprove all decisions made by governments. One of the unfortunate things about petitions, of course, is that petitions present all points of view-for example, the plant variety rights legislation. It is important that people are involved in that issue, but ultimately the Government has to make a decision about the issues involved. If we were to decide issues on the basis of petitions we would not decide anything because all points of view are expressed. I commend the views of the Standing Orders Committee to honourable senators and I hope it will have the support of all honourable senators in streamlining and improving the procedures of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been sitting here listening to the diatribe from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). A number of petitions have been submitted to me to put before the Parliament. I think it is the right of every citizen in the Australian community to present a petition.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—We can understand the nonsense from across the chamber. When people go to the extent of gathering signatures from a number of people to put a petition to this Parliament, I believe they have the right to be heard. That is the democratic right of every Australian. If we take away the democratic right for people to be heard in the Parliament I believe we will do a grave injustice to the people of this country. The leader of the Opposition said that it is not necessary for those petitions to be heard or read. The ordinary, average Australian citizen has a right for his petition to heard in the Australian Parliament. I think we are taking a retrograde step when we say that people do not have a right to be heard. They have a right to be heard. They have a right to send a petition to me as a senator representing Queensland to say that they are not happy with certain things that the Government is doing or to state certain things that are right according to their points of view. If I am denied the right to come into the Senate on a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday- whatever day it might be-to present a petiton and to read it in this chamber, I think we are denying the fundamental right--

SPEECH.PARA: Sentor Grimes-You do not read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the people of this nation to be heard in the Commonwealth Parliament. I believe we are taking a retrograde step when we say that they cannot be heard. We are denying them their right. I think it is time we started to look at ourselves and asked: 'Whom do we represent in this Parliament? Do we represent the people?' If we represent the people they have a right to be heard. They have a right for me to stand up in this chamber and read their petition.
—You do not read it, the Clerk reads it.

—The Clerk does not read them all. What I am talking about is the right for me and the Clerk to read them. Many people send in petitions. They listen to the broadcast from this chamber on a Wednesday to hear their petitions read. They think: 'My God, no matter how humble I may be, whatever humble circumstances I may live in, I am being heard in the Parliament of this nation'. If we take away that right we are taking a retrograde step. Every Australian has that right and if we deny him that right we are not doing our duty as representatives of the people. If we deny people that right we have no right to claim to represent people. That is what this Parliament is all about- representing people. We do not represent other things; we represent people. If we do not give people that right, why are we here? Whom do you represent, Senator Grimes?
—The Country Party represents sheep, goats and so on. I represent people.
—Whom do I represent? Do you not represent people?
—Yes, but I am not in the Country Party.
—If you represent people why do you deny them their right?
—I am not denying them.
—It is their right to be heard in this Parliament and to have their petitions read in this Parliament.
—If you give me a chance I will tell you.
—Order! We will have a little semblance of order while I am in charge of the proceedings. Senator Bonner has the floor; it is not a time for questions and answers.

—It should be enlightening to the people listening to this broadcast tonight to know that there are people in this chamber who would deny them their fundamental right to have their petitions heard in this chamber and on broadcast day over the airwaves of the nation so that they think: 'My God, as humble as I may be and whatever humble circumstances I may live in, I can send a petition to that Parliament and it will be heard'. That is something which I believe is right and proper. I stand for that right and I defend that right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button said in his opening remarks tonight that this chamber should not be debating its own Standing Orders while its proceedings are being broadcast. He then spent five minutes elaborating on why we should adopt the recommendations of the Senate Standing Orders Committee, a committee of which he said he was proud to be a member. He killed his own argument by saying that. He went on to say that if the recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee is adopted petitions will be sent automatically to Senate standing committees. As I read the report of this Committee, no such recommendation has been made. I will read the recommendation of that Committee.
—It is on page 3.
—For the information of the honourable senator. I will read it. The recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the new sessional order is adopted, Mr President will, as a matter of practice, have a list of all petitions circulated to honourable Senators, and the texts of petitions referred to the relevant Standing Committees, so that, should those Committees wish to inquire into any particular petition, they may seek a reference from the Senate to do so.
It is then up to the Senate standing committee concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens now?

—Petitions do not go to a Senate standing committee now. At least the text of a petition is read out in this Parliament. It will not be read out in future. The Senate Standing Orders Committee is trying to ape the practice which is adopted on the other side of King's Hall. Many honourable senators will argue that we should not copy the House of Representatives. That is the very thing this chamber will be doing if it adopts this recommendation. It will have no mind of its own. No definite recommendation is to be found in this report which says that the Senate standing committee to which a petition is referred shall do anything at all with the petition. The recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . should those Committees wish to inquire . . .
They may not wish to inquire as they may have a lot of other work to do. The recommendation continues:
. . . they may seek a reference from the Senate to do so.

Ever since we dealt in the Committee of the Whole with the privileged Ministers who have very cheap home loans, I have been presenting petitions here dealing with that subject. The committee to which those petitions would have to go would be the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations of which Senator Peter Rae is the Chairman. Let us look at how many references that Committee has before it in its current inquiries. The Committee has 16 references before it at present. How long would it be before that Committee got round to looking at whether that is fair to all the young couples who are paying exorbitant interest on home loans? How long would it be before Senator Peter Rae got around to looking at that matter and came back to the Senate with a recommendation?

I doubt whether his Committee would be game to come back and say that it agrees that Mr Anthony should not have such a loan. He is the only one who is now getting a home loan so cheaply. In view of the political climate, I doubt whether the Committee would come back with a recommendation that he should not continue to receive that loan. The National Country Party is breathing down the neck of the Government, so that Committee would not be game to come into this place and recommend that Mr Anthony should pay the same rate of interest as every other young married couple in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is he paying now?

—Mr Anthony is paying about 4 1/4 per cent on a 45-year loan. That is the text of the petitions which I have been presenting in this regard. But that is not the point. Senator Button said that we should not be debating the recommendations of our Standing Orders Committee tonight. It is very important that we debate them tonight while our proceedings are being broadcast because the Standing Orders Committee is recommending-it is supported by Senator Button-the taking away of the rights of Australian citizens to have their petitions read.
—Nonsense.

—It is not nonsense at all. If people go to the trouble of drawing up and signing petitions and of giving them to members of parliament to present in this place they should at least be able to hear them being read. Let us look at the first part of the recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee on page 3 of its report. Under the heading 'Petitions'. it states:

SPEECH.PARA: In considering the more effective use of the time available to the Senate . . .

Nine petitions were presented today in the Senate. Nine petitions had to be read . How long did that take? It took exactly 15 minutes to read those nine petitions. That is not taking away any of the time of the Senate. I doubt whether more than nine petitions would ever be required to be read on a Wednesday. We are going to deprive the people who sign petitions of the right to have those petitions read because we want to save 15 minutes. What will we do with that time? If honourable senators go back through Hansard they will see that hour after hour has been wasted on useless debate in this place, yet honourable senators want to take away the rights of citizens to have their petitions read in this Parliament.

What else is contained in the recommendation? It states that the Clerk shall read a summary of the contents of petitions. Who will determine this summary? I just want to remind the Senate of the summary of the petitions that I have presented in this place. I am not blaming whoever is responsible for it. I have the right as a senator to alter the wording of a petition. But if we are to be bound, as we will be if this recommendation is adopted, by the summary determined by the Clerk the summaries will read something like the summary of the Clerk of the petitions I have been presenting from people who object to Mr Anthony getting a very cheap loan. The wording I am given every day, which, of course, I change, is:

Mr President, I present a petition from citizens praying that the Government extend the generous terms of Commonwealth home loans granted to two Ministers to the thousands of young couples suffering undue hardship because of high interest rates.

The petitions presented had in them the names of Mr Nixon and Mr Anthony but because such petitions have been presented by me so religiously in the Senate, Mr Nixon has bailed out. It embarrassed him, so he paid off his cheap home loan. But Mr Anthony has not yet paid off his home loan. If we prevent the people of Australia from petitioning this Parliament and complaining about the fact that a Liberal-National Country Party government treats its Ministers so generously, we will not embarrass Mr Anthony; he will be happy. I am wondering what sort of input he has had with regard to this recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. In view of the fact that the allegation made is that Mr Anthony had a loan during the period of the Labor Government, I object to the suggestion that it is only on the basis of something done by a Liberal-National Country Party government that the situation referred to by Senator McLaren exists. I believe that Senator McLaren should be brought back to the subject matter of the debate, which is the report of the Standing Orders Committee, rather than range far and wide in an effort to regurgitate some of the matters that people have heard ad nauseam, to the degree where I cannot imagine that anyone in Australia would ever wish to hear any reference to those matters by him again. I suggest that he be brought back to the subject matter of the debate.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I wish to speak briefly to the point of order. I disagree with Senator Peter Rae. I would have thought that what Senator McLaren is doing is making a point for those of us who disagree with the dispensing of petitions. He could not have made that point better. In other words, he is giving a clear example of an important area. If the Deputy Prime Minister gets a cheap home loan and if the citizens of this country bring forward that matter the broadcast audience has a right to hear about it. I would not have thought that he could have made his point better. I suggest that there is no point of order.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I wish also to speak to the point of order. I agree with my colleague Senator Peter Rae. We are talking about the right of citizens to have their petitions read in this place. I do not think honourable senators should stand up and make cheap political points on this matter.

—Order! I will rule firstly on the point of order. There is no point of order as laid down by the Standing Orders. However, when honourable senators are debating the items under consideration by the chamber they should endeavour not to range far and wide and should contain their remarks to the section to which they are referring. I call Senator McLaren .

—I thought that was exactly what I was doing. I was talking to the part of the recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee report which states that the Clerk shall read a summary of the content of petitions. I was quoting the Clerk's summary of petitions that I have presented from people complaining about these cheap home loans. In what way could I do so other than that? Of course, I am very pleased that I have hit a raw nerve as far as Senator Peter Rae and Senator Bonner are concerned. By their interjections and their points of order, they are saying that they agree that Mr Anthony should have a cheap home loan and they do not want the people of Australia to be advised about it. I am pleased that they have admitted that by their points of order.
—It is for cheap publicity.

—I am not seeking cheap publicity. I am concerned, as are hundreds of thousands of other people who are paying high interest rates today on a home in which to live, that the Deputy Prime Minister of this country, one of the highest paid men in the Commonwealth, can get away with a loan of 4 1/2 per cent.
—I raise a point of order. The honourable senator is totally misquoting what I said. I am not--
—Order! Senator Bonner, that is not a point of order. If the honourable senator wishes to make a personal explanation- -
—My point of order is that the honourable senator said that I agreed with certain things that he claims. I do not agree with one of things that he says. But the fundamental right of citizens is--
—Order! There is no point of order. We will resume the debate on item 3. I call Senator Georges.
—I still have five minutes left--
—I am sorry. I understood--
—And I am not going to have it taken away.
—Order! Now, just a moment, Senator McLaren. I understood that you had already taken your seat.
—I took it because Senator Bonner raised a point of order.
—I see. Fine. I will give you the call.
—Surely we can get a bit of order in this place.
—Senator McLaren--

—I do not expect the Temporary Chairman to side with honourable senators who are trying to sidetrack me because I get 15 minutes to speak in a debate and I will speak for that length of time. The other matter I want to refer to--

—Order! Senator McLaren, let me point out that one of the important Standing Orders of this chamber is that honourable senators will not cast a reflection on the Chair. I will decide on the manner in which the debate in this chamber is conducted. I am giving you now the call and the opportunity to complete your contribution to the debate.
—I thought that I was entitled to that, Madam Chair. However, I will abide by your ruling. What I further want to refer to in the recommendation is this. The recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: The adoption of this sessional order would allow consideration in the future of any further changes to the procedure for the presentation of petitions after the recommended procedures has been tried for a time.

If one looks at the Appendix, one will see that there is no mention that this will be a temporary measure on a trial basis. Once it is adopted tonight, it will go into the Standing Orders and the only way we will be able to remove it is for the Standing Orders Committee to make another recommendation that it be altered. What is in this document stands. What is in the report of the Standing Orders Committee is completely misleading as is one of the other recommendations which I have already pointed out. That is the matter that we are concerned about .

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the sessional order on page 8, Appendix D.
—The proposed sessional order relating to petitions?
—It is a sessional order.

—As I have just said, what I am concerned about is that, once this policy is adopted here tonight, it will go on forever and a day. I am one who, as a good trade unionist, believes that when one gets anything one does not idly give it away. One sticks to it, with all the possible power that is available to one. I cannot understand why honourable senators, particularly in my party which believes in open government-that is part of our policy-are supporting tonight recommendations to take away the rights of citizens. I certainly will never agree to that.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was sidetracked by two Government senators I was talking about the fact that I am very concerned that petitions will be abbreviated. I seek some clarification from the responsible Minister as to the type of summary that the Clerks will come up with. Who will determine it? Can we be given some example of what the summary will be when petitions are lodged? Will this matter be left to the sole prerogative of the Clerk without any direction as to which standing committee each petition will be sent to? We have quite a few standing committees . We have the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Afaairs, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources , the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare and the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce. Who will be judge and jury to determine which standing committee should look at a particular petition? Of course when a petition reaches a standing committee, it is up to that committee to decide whether it wishes to look at the petition or refer it back to the Senate and seek a reference so that it can examine it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring the debate back to the subject . We are dealing with a recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee concerning how we will handle petitions. On page 8 of the report of the Committee, we have a proposed sessional order, not a standing order, which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A Senator wishing to present a petition shall lodge it with the Clerk.
(2) The Clerk shall make an announcement in respect of petitions lodged with him, . . .
(3) Every petition . . . shall be deemed to have been received by the Senate unless a motion, . . . that a particular petition be not received, be agreed to.
(4) The terms of the petition presented shall be printed in Hansard.

The explanatory notes point out that the Committee recommends that the reading of the full text of petitions be abandoned, that all petitions be lodged with the Clerk and that the Clerk shall read a summary. I presume that, if the honourable senator presenting the petition objects to that summary he can do so and have that summary changed. What is more important is this: If the new sessional order is adopted, Mr President, not the Clerk, will as a matter of practice, have a list of all petitions circulated to honourable senators and the text of petitions will be referred to the relevant standing committees so that those committees which wish to inquire into a particular petition may do so. I ask the Senate to consider what happens now. What happens now is that--

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the petition read?

—People in this community take the trouble to sign a petition in which they have an interest. As Senator Button said-on this occasion I agree with him, which is unusual regarding matters of Standing Orders-that is the important thing. People become active and take an interest in the subject. They sign a petition. The petition is then brought to this place. Quite contrary to what our friend Senator Bonner said, the petition is not read by the senator. He announces his petition and it is read by the Clerk.
—It is read.
—It is read by the Clerk.
—In full.

—Maybe. It is read by the Clerk perhaps because people consider that we are not capable of reading a petition properly. However, it is read by the Clerk. From then on that petition goes who knows where? Maybe it goes into the archives. Maybe it is burnt. I do not know where it goes. Obviously Senator Georges does not know where it goes.
—It goes nowhere. Let us correct that.

—The petition is sent somewhere. I point out that what is happening-I believe that Senator Georges ought to consider this-is that we as a Parliament are kidding the people who sign petitions that something relevant is happening to them. In fact what happens, particularly on a Wednesday, is that they are brought into this place and read out. If honourable senators look around this chamber at that time there is hardly anyone here who listens to what is read out.
—There is hardly anyone here at any time.
—There are plenty here tonight.
—There is not a quorum. If I called a quorum, would we get one?

—We have a quorum present. If the honourable senator calls a quorum he is likely to end up out of the chamber because I think a quorum is present. The petition is then consigned somewhere and nobody knows anything about it. Under this sessional order we will all get a list of the petitions. The details of the petitions will be printed in Hansard and will be referred to a committee where something may-I repeat, may-happen to them. At the moment nothing happens to them. People believe that there is something significant about the ritual we go through here on a Wednesday when not honourable senators but the Clerk reads out the text of petitions. But nothing happens to them. We are kidding those people who bring those petitions to us for presentation.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator McLaren. I believe very strongly in the right of citizens of this country to petition this Parliament. I believe it is very important that that petition should appear in Hansard and the records of this Parliament. The fact that a petition has been presented to this chamber should be announced to this chamber. What has happened is that petitions have become less significant because of the procedure we use and because of the nature of debate in this place. Recently a petition was presented in this chamber which had, I think, 25, 000 signatures on it. I believe it was said at the time that the number of signatures on the petition presented in this place was a record. Last century, when the population of Victoria was less than one million and Ned Kelly was going to be hanged, parliamentarians managed to get a petition which had 75,000 signatures on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They still hanged him.

—And they still hanged him. As a result of that petition containing 25,000 signatures, nothing happened. We must have a situation in which people who present petitions to this place know that something of some relevance will be done to those petitions. Nothing of any relevance is done to them now.
—Why don't we do both-have them read and have them referred?

—That would be lovely, but I believe we mislead those people who honestly believe that on Wednesday afternoons when petitions are read certain things happen. The names of the people on the petitions are not read. I can tell honourable senators that if they read some of the names of the people who signed the petition they would not want to read them. I suggest that some of those signatures are false and some of them are extraordinary. I am saying that those people who genuinely sign petitions for presentation to this place have a right to know that they will be printed in the Journals of this place, that they will be considered and referred to places where they can be considered. At the moment they are confined to the dungeons or the archives or God knows where, and we do not know what happens to them. Nothing happens after that. This is all because some people believe that those who are listening to Parliament are interested in listening to the endless repetition of petitions which goes on here every Wednesday.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that petitions should be read in the detail in which they are read on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday. I say to Senator Georges that I believe that if the text of those petitions is to be read it should be read by the senators who present them. I believe if we were to introduce that Standing Order , that senators themselves had to read the petitions they present, the number of petitions read would drop considerably except, as Senator Georges said, at preselection time. I believe this is a sensible reform. I believe that as it is a sessional order we can see what happens at the end of the session. If Senator Georges, Senator McLaren and Senator Bonner find that there are thousands of people out there who are protesting that the petitions are not being read, they can come here and convince us and change the sessional order. Let us have this sensible reform and realise that we are in the 1980s and not in a time when that sort of procedure was first developed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the views which have been expressed by Senator Button and Senator Grimes on the issue which is before the Senate. I think it is a fact that there is a limited amount of time in this chamber to do an unlimited amount of work. One of the problems which we have is making a sensible allocation of time. Some senators have the view, for example, that we should do more in committees. Other senators say that we should spend more time debating committee business that is the Senate's own business and so on. The fact is that the system of petitions can be endlessly used and it can be endlessly abused. In fact, a petition was put down by, I think, Senator Harradine which contained 25,000 signatures. He could, if he had wished, have presented each page of that petition day after day or he could have had different senators present separate pages of that petition and had us sitting here for endless hours while we processed the very many pages of that single petition. We all know that some senators use that technique to ensure that a petition of which they are particularly fond takes up a great deal of time and creates the impression that there is some great mass of feeling out there. I congratulate Senator Harradine for his self-control on the occasion of presenting a petition which I know was dear to his heart.

SPEECH.PARA: But there are a lot of mechanisms which are available to senators in this place to air the grievances of their electors. There is the Adjournment Debate; there is the giving of notices of motion which is, again, a popular technique which can be used or abused according to which end one is on, the giving or the receiving end; and so on. With great respect to this Committee I put the view that, in the hours which we spend here, the sometimes quite long periods where we sit listening to the present procedure of dealing with petitions are not the most productive hours spent in this chamber. I believe there is a situation whereby a small number of senators are able to monopolise a quite large part of the time of this place. I believe if senators careful consider the use of time in this place they will adopt the recommendation of the Senate Standing Orders Committee a committee of which I hasten to add I am not a member. I also tend to agree with Senator Button in that I very much doubt that this debate has particularly advanced the status of the Senate among the listening public, if there is any listening public. I do not believe that it is of particular interest to very many people outside how we order out domestic affairs. However, it is important that as much of the time which we have available to us as possible is seen by the public to involve senators directing their attention to matters of national concern. I believe that the safeguards which are contained in Appendix D ensure that the citizen is able to approach this place and is able to put on the permanent record of this place the view that he or she wishes to put before us. I believe it would amount to a more effective use of our time if we adopted Appendix D as a practice of this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point briefly with the proponents of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Orders Committee. I refer to current Standing Order No. 96 which states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The only Questions entertained by the Senate on the presentation of a Petition shall be:- I. ''That the Petition be received;'' II. ''That the Petition be read ;'' III. ''That the Petition be printed;'' IV. . . . ''That the Petition be referred at once to the Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications;'' or V . . . . ''That the Petition be referred to the Select Committee on-.''

That is, to the committee dealing with the subject matter the petition refers to . The proposal that is currently before us is to change the current sessional order. The current sessional order presumably has a preamble which states: ' Notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders of the Senate the following shall be the order in which the petition shall be dealt with'. Nevertheless, I would like to ask the proponents of the recommendation whether or not it is sought to supersede Standing Order No. 96.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is not.

—Under those circumstances I cannot see anything against the recommendation. All the recommendation does then is to streamline the presentation of petitions. The fact that the petition is then before the Senate is enshrined in this new sessional order. The fact that the subject matter of the petition is referred to and read out briefly-summarised-and that the full text of the petition is circulated to all senators does not then presumably preclude the right of any senator, including the senator who has been given by his constituents the responsibility of ensuring that the petition comes before the Parliament, to act in accordance with Standing Order No. 96 or to move any of those motions that are stated in that Standing Order. Under those circumstances and with that assurance I am happy to support the proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having given a kerb-side opinion that the position was that Standing Order No. 96 would apply, I want to explain to the Committee that I was not a member of the Standing Orders Committee and hence have not considered this in the depth that some other senators might have. The opening words of Appendix D state:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the procedure for the presentation of petitions is varied . . .

In other words there is no attempt for this to be a code which excludes the operation of other Standing Orders. Rather, it simply amounts to a variation on the totality of the procedures contained in the Standing Orders relating to petitions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Harradine that the point in Standing Order No. 96 is that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . (in the case of a Petition respecting any subject then under the consideration of a Select Committee) . . .

Then, indeed, it can be referred to a committee. I think that point is worth making. On the general subject I was rather attracted by the proposition put forward by Senator Grimes who proposed that, indeed, it would be a good idea if the petition were read by the senator. I have never been able to see any reason at all why a senator should read a summary and then the petition should be read by the Clerk. It seems to me to be a very unwieldy piece of procedure which we might well look at if indeed-and I am quite confident of this-the Committee decides not to adopt this procedure recommended by the Standing Orders Committee and that we will continue to present petitions in the usual way.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under the sessional order I put the question: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr R. J. L. Hawke, M.P.: Speech at Graduation Ceremony-Rice Growing Industry- Compensation for Former Commonwealth Employee

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 11 p.m. under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate for long. I wish to continue tonight a matter which was brought up in the Senate last night by Senator Watson and followed up, I suspect rather reluctantly, by Senator Rae. I wish to do so merely to bring a balance into the record of the Senate as to what happened in Launceston last Saturday evening at the presentation of the degrees at the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education. I was present, as were Senator Rae and Senator Watson, last Saturday evening at the graduation ceremony .
—And Senator Archer.

—Senator Archer was there too. I am aware of what happened. What happened was reported in the Press. I make a particular note that the only Press report which was brought into this place was brought in by Senator Watson. That was the report from the Hobart Mercury. I happen to know, as Senator Watson knows, the Launceston Examiner was available in this place yesterday, yet he chose not to take the report from the Launceston Examiner. I believe I can demonstrate quite clearly why, in fact, he chose just the report from the Hobart Mercury.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, I was present at the graduation ceremony. Mr Hawke gave the occasional address. Before he did so, he made inquiries about what sort of speech was expected, whether the contribution should be a substantial one and whether, in fact, anyone would worry if it was controversial. He made those inquiries of the Chairman of the Council of the College of Advanced Education. He was informed that both conditions-that the address be substantial and controversial-were acceptable to the Chairman and therefore he thought to the Council. The Chairman of the Council, I might add is, Mr Edmund Rouse. I do not believe either Senator Watson or Senator Rae could suggest that he is a Labor Party supporter in any way.

Mr Hawke observed before he started his address that he would be both political and controversial. He explained that he thought people would consider him to be less honest if he were otherwise. Quite clearly, what is appropriate or otherwise in such an address is a matter for judgment. I agree that many people present thought that Mr Hawke was too political-an extraordinary complaint for a political figure of his type. Neither Mr Hawke nor I would deny that he is a very political figure. Senator Watson and, I assume from his remarks, Senator Rae made that judgment. Quite clearly, I want to point out that not everyone present that night agreed. I was present later when members of the staff and students of the College apologised to Mr Hawke for what they considered to be the unfortunate manners, perhaps some of them considered ill manners, of students in the audience. Quite clearly on that occasion there were people who did not agree with the judgment that was made by Senator Rae, Senator Watson and many others present. In fact, I have a letter to Mr Hawke from the staff of the College expressing a view opposite to that expressed by Senator Watson. I point out that when Mr Hawke was interrupted by the graduate he said that he was sorry if his approach was not what she and her colleagues had expected or appreciated and from then on cut his speech short.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it a political speech?

—I am coming to that. The report given by Senator Watson last night suggested that he misjudged the appropriateness of the occasion and the response from the audience as to the form and the content of his address. Senator Watson then stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where Robert John Hawke-
He could not even get the name right--
abused the privilege which was granted to him in presenting a sound, reasoned, researched and academic address on a matter of substance.
He continued:
. . . I think this great Rhodes scholar has indeed suffered great deterioration of mind since his heyday.
He went on to say:
The approach was discourteous, not only to the chairman--
I will come to the Chairman later--
but also to the principal, the graduates, their families and the many guests.

He then made a remark which I think was incredible. He described Mr Hawke's speeches as 'a monotonous monologue on matters relating to unemployment, inflation and industrial relations'. I am not in a position to judge Mr Hawke's speeches. I am not going to judge Mr Hawke's speeches in comparison with Senator Watson's speeches. I merely make the remark that if Mr Hawke's speeches are considered monotonous monologues, honourable senators who have heard Senator Watson's speeches can make their own judgment as to how they describe them. Senator Watson had incorporated in Hansard the report from the Hobart Mercury. I would liked to quote from the report from the Launceston Examiner. The Launceston Examiner had the advantage of having a reporter there on the occasion . The Hobart Mercury, as I have found out, merely had a hearsay report from someone who was present. The Launceston Examiner quoted some people who had different views from those of Senator Watson and Senator Rae. I am not denying that they had their views and I am not denying that they have the right to express their views. The Examiner first of all reported the words of the Chairman of the Council of the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education, Mr Edmund Rouse, who:
Told the audience that he had requested Mr Hawke to treat the address with the utmost seriousness.
He took responsibility for what Mr Hawke had done and said and the manner in which he had said it. He stated:
'Therefore, if anyone feels there has been any discourtesy, I take the full responsibility . . .
I suggest that Mr Rouse was far more courteous than Senator Watson. The Examiner article continues:
Late on Saturday night a group of graduates dining at a Launceston restaurant rang The Examiner, asking to dissociate themselves from Miss Matthews'-
That was the young lady who interrupted Mr Hawke--
attitude.
Mrs Sharon Brooker said that Miss Matthews' stance was not representative of the student body as a whole.
'Despite the length of the address, as an educated person Miss Matthews should have realised that it was typical of graduation speeches.'

TALK.START.PARA: —How long was it?
—Fifty minutes.

—Senator Rae says it was 50 minutes; the Examiner says it was 40 minutes; the Mercury says it was 25 minutes. I suggest there were some difficulties with people's watches that night. I think that really is irrelevant , but I will come to it in a moment.
—As you said, the Mercury didn't have anyone there. Fifty minutes is correct.

—I am afraid that at times Senator Rae can be as horologically amoral as many other honourable senators. I will not argue on this matter. I accept that there were great differences in the estimate of the time. Senator Watson quoted the Mercury which said 25 minutes. I presume that he accepts that as an authoritative report. I am sorry that Senator Watson had incorporated in Hansard what he claimed was an accurate report of the evening's affairs. That report said that Mr Hawke had spoken for 25 minutes. The Examiner stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A percentage of the audience clapped Miss Matthews when she sat down after interjecting.
Senator Watson, who is not a journalist but who was an observer, described it as thunderous applause. Today Mr Hawke received a letter from the academic staff of the TCAE stating:

As a member of the Academic Staff of the TCAE I wish to express to you my regret that some misguided students chose to so discourteously interrupt your address. It is ironical, considering the substance of your address, that these students probably came from a section of the college community guaranteed permanent employment on graduation.

It is a pity that these students were unable to regard your address in the spirit in which you offered it, that is, as a responsible view of some of the problems facing the society into whose workforce they are about to proceed and about which they have a responsibility to formulate considered opinions. Personally, I wholeheartedly agree with the views you expressed despite my normal Liberal bias in political policy matters.
As I said, Mr Rouse apologised to the audience, accepted responsibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a single letter or on behalf of a group?

—That is a letter from a member of the staff of the TCAE. I am not saying that it is anything other than that but it was sent only a few days after the event. I suggest that Mr Hawke may have not been aware of what many people expected. He would not have expected fellow politicans like Senator Watson to expect him to behave like an apolitical eunuch. We have all made and will make speeches which are not very good. I, and other senators, have done that. We all can and we all will, I suggest, misjudge an audience. I have heard speeches containing tasteless remarks by politicans-that certainly cannot be said of Mr Hawke's speech the other night. I have heard speeches which could have been classed as inappropriate. But this is the first time that I have ever heard anyone come into this place and make a speech like Senator Watson's. I am sure he made that speech, in fact, to chase a headline. I suggest that he deliberately chose the report from the Hobart Mercury because it was more favourable to his case than the report in the Launceston Examiner. I do not believe that someone like Mr Hawke needs defending from attacks like this but I believe we should have a sort of balance in the reports that are made. I have tried to do that by reporting from another newspaper in Tasmania, a newspaper which did have a reporter at the ceremony and a newspaper which did give a report.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth while just pointing out that Mr Hawke was a distinguished Rhodes Scholar. He was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He is known by sight by almost every citizen in this land. I do not think we can say the same for either of the honourable senators who spoke last night on this matter. I do not think the name of Senator Watson would cause even a flicker of recognition in the minds of most people in this land any more than mine would. The thing is that Senator Watson and I will never be in Mr Hawke's position, probably, of being asked to give the sort of address that he was asked to give. Yet Senator Watson comes in here and denigrates a man of that stature for what may in Senator Watson's judgment have been a misjudged speech. I believe the crux of Senator Watson's complaint can be seen in his description of Mr Hawke's speech-a monotonous monologue on matters relating to unemployment, inflation and industrial relations. It is those three subjects of unemployment, inflation and industrial relations which, I suspect, upset people like Senator Watson. I can understand Senator Watson's sensitivity on this matter in view of his previous experiences in this area before becoming a senator. I can understand his difficulty in view of the things that he had to do in his occupation before he became a senator. I do not believe that the denigration of Mr Hawke which was indulged in last night advances the cause of politics or advances the career of Senator Watson or, for that matter, Senator Rae.

I point out that Senator Watson did not give the unanimous view of everyone present. The Launceston Examiner at least was willing to report both sides of the story. It at least was willing to report the views of those people present who disagreed with the judgment of Senator Rae and Senator Watson. I do not deny their right to make that judgment. I just question the fact that they came in here last night and brought up the subject in such a manner. I hope that in future they will be a little more tolerant. I hope that in the future they are not on the wrong end of such discussion as was Mr Hawke on Saturday night.

Mr Hawke made a speech on a very serious subject. It was certainly relevant to the people who were graduating. He made it in a manner which some people may have considered to be too political. He made it at a length which some people may have considered to be excessive. But he made that speech, as the Chairman of the College of Advanced Education said, in all seriousness and in a sincere manner, having in mind his record in this area and his conscientious belief that that was the sort of controversial matter which was appropriate to be raised at such a graduation ceremony.

I think if we look over the years at graduation ceremonies at the great universities of this country and at the great universities overseas we will find that through the decades, in fact through the centuries, such graduation ceremonies have been at times controversial. Controversial speeches have been made and controversial views have been put. I hope that that will continue in the future because our universities and our colleges of advanced education are places where, in fact, such subjects should be discussed and such subjects should be raised. I do not in any way-nor would Mr Hawke-denigrate the courage of the young lady who chose to interrupt Mr Hawke. He made that perfectly clear at the time he spoke and after he spoke. She did what she thought was right. That is what I think people at colleges of advanced education and universities should do. But that this matter should be dragged up in this Parliament in the selective way and in the manner in which it was dragged up last night, I think was most unfortunate. I merely wish to balance the picture this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Grimes has defended perfectly legitimately the matter in which a colleague of his was involved. He has done so to the best of his ability and certainly to the very best that the circumstances will permit. I congratulate him for the capacity that he showed to make the very best defence possible.
—Don't be patronising. It doesn't become you.

—I thank Senator Robertson for being patronising. I want to come to the main point. I do not think Senator Grimes's speech was a legitimate attack on Senator Watson. Senator Watson expressed his concern for what he saw was an affront to an institution with which he had been personally involved and for which he has a personal degree of concern.
—Did he talk to Rouse before he did it? No.
—I do not know.
—What about letting him speak for himself then?

—Senator Grimes has just had the opportunity to speak for 15 minutes in this chamber to defend his colleague; I would like equally to have an interuption-free period to defend my colleague. I believe that Senator Watson expressed his concern in relation to what he saw was an affront to an institution in which he had a very strong and legitimate interest, having had a close involvement with it for a considerable period and having been involved there in the teaching side as well as taking a very close interest in its development. I am not suggesting that that places him in an extraordinary or unique sitution. I believe and I think Senator Grimes would believe that it is an excellent institution which should be supported. But I feel that an honourable senator, in endeavouring to protect the interests of his constituents and the interests of an institution with which he was involved, should not be attacked in a way which could give the impression of sneering.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to draw out the matter any further than to say that, as Senator Grimes has indicated, there were many people-let us not argue about the exact number; no one will ever know-who felt concerned about what took place. That concern was expressed by Senator Watson last night. I indicated my concern and I believe that if Senator Grimes is not in a position to indicate tonight that Mr Hawke is prepared in any way at all to do as Senator Watson and I suggested last night-that is, tender some form of apology-the matter can be left there with that being noted.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did so in his speech and you know it.

—Senator Grimes says that he did so in his speech. If that is where the matter is to be left, again I suggest that it be left there. I think the people who were present can make their own judgments. People who have heard the expressions from both sides can make their judgments. I simply do not wish it to be thought that Senator Watson was alone and was to be sneered at or attacked for what was a perfectly legitimate expression of a view which I supported last evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to traverse the matters I raised last night, except to say that I did not claim at any point that I was putting forward a unanimous view. I tried to point out that had that address come from somebody who did not have the availability of a tertiary education such as that which Mr Hawke had-in other words, one who had come from the school of hard knocks-one could probably have well understood the content and form of such an address. But we have to recognise that Mr Hawke, in his own right, is an academic, having had a distinguished career with the University of Western Australia and in the United Kingdom. So he knew the unwritten rules which generally apply on such occasions. He knew and he was well aware of them, having been through that sort of thing. I tried to draw attention to the inappropriateness of those remarks, given that occasion and given the fact that an election campaign was forthcoming in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: It was really nothing more than politicking at the expense of an institution which is trying to find its identity. The tragedy of this situation is that it will scare off not only the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education but also a whole host of universities and similar colleges of advanced education from inviting politicians in the future. I think it is important that such colleges have an input. Some time prior to the event I was told that Mr Hawke was going to speak. I was asked whether I could see any objections arising. I said: 'No, he is an academic'. I believed that there would be the opportunity to provide what was required on such an occasion. Certainly I was let down and many others were let down as well. For that reason I took up the matter. I thought it was unfortunate behaviour for a man who should have known better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter on behalf of Mr Kerry Davis, a constituent of mine presently residing in Devonport. This young man, through occupational stress brought about while he was a member of the Australian Federal Police, has been required to relinquish his position, which had been well-earned and in which he was well regarded by that force. Although he was a Tasmanian, he moved to Queensland in July of 1980 to carry forward his duties within the force. In doing so, of course, he had to undertake such a move of household as required him to purchase a new residence for his family in Brisbane. This he did, but within five months of taking occupation of that family residence he was required by ill-health-his health having deteriorated rapidly due to occupational stress-to resign.

SPEECH.PARA: This young man has given very distinguished service to Australia not only in the Federal Police but also within the armed forces. In fact, during his period of service in the armed forces, which commenced at the age of 17 years upon voluntary enlistment in the Australian Regular Army, he served for some time in the infantry in South Vietnam and was engaged in combat on several occasions. As I have said, after only five months residence in the family home in Brisbane, this young man was required to resign from the force and he returned to Tasmania . Presently he is living with his wife's family in Devonport. The expenses involved for a young family man in such a situation can well be imagined.

What he has asked of the Federal Government is some aid in meeting the reimbursement of legal and other costs associated with the sale of that home in Brisbane. He hoped that section 23 of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act might provide some avenue for him to make such a claim. But he has been informed by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Kevin Newman, and indeed by his own Commonwealth Police Officers Association that his claim does not fall within the purview of that statute. It seems to me that that view is the correct one. What this man is seeking-given his long period of service with the Commonwealth in capacities, as I have said, within the armed forces and within the Federal Police during which time he performed his duties diligently and well and rose to the rank of detective-sergeant-in the absence of a statutory entitlement is an ex gratia payment to help alleviate the financial stress in which his family has found itself because of the forced sale of the family residence in Brisbane prior to his return to Tasmania. I commend the case to the attention of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise-I apologise to the Senate because I have only just found this correspondence on my desk-is a matter of very great urgency to the Ricegrowers Co-operative Mills Ltd at Leeton in NSW. I will read the first part of the telex and seek leave to have the other part of it incorporated in Hansard. I do this in the hope that the Minister for Health (Senator Peter Baume), who is now in the Senate, will look at it tomorrow and see whether some urgent action can be taken to protect local rice growers. The telex which I have just opened is addressed to Senator G. T. McLaren, South Australian, Parliament House, Canberra. It is from the Ricegrowers Co-operative Mills Ltd, Leeton. The telex reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Most concerned at sudden increase in importations of rice into Australia which do not meet high Australian standards and are threat under quarantine system to Australian ricegrowing industry. Western Australian industry supports our view. As member of committee of inquiry into quarantine safeguards, your support sought urgently for investigation into way that quarantine barrier around NSW ricegrowing area was broken and rice from China was put on sale. Further seek your support for declaration from quarantine service that in view of contaminated samples which have been identified by this co-operative and reported to quarantine service stringent controls should be placed on imported rice so that it meets the high standards of our export quality products. Understand ship due to leave Bangkok which may carry rice for Australia. Ship due to call at several southern ports and Fremantle.
That is followed by a six-paragraph media release. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to have that portion of the telegram incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The sudden increase in the number of importers of foreign rice for Australia poses a grave threat to the disease-free Australian rice industry, an industry leader said today.

Mr L. C. Davidge, the Chairman of the Ricegrowers' Co-operative Mills Limited said that he was deeply concerned that tests carried out in Sydney had revealed that samples of imported rice had contained wheat seed, dead insects and unmilled rice grains.
He said that advanced milling and hygiene techniques in the huge N.S.W. rice industry ensured that unmilled paddy was virtually eliminated from rice produced locally.

However, he said samples of foreign rice had up to 6 grains of unmilled rice per kilogram. Mr Davidge said that this unmilled grain could carry diseases, such as blast, and viruses which could destroy the $150 million N.S.W. rice industry.

This foreign rice had already been detected by the State Department of Agriculture within the quarantine area. The varieties developed by the N.S.W. rice industry have no resistance to diseases and relied entirely on quarantine protection.
He said, quick buck entrepreneurs bringing in cheap parcels of sub-standard rice must be made to conform with the strict controls which protect Australia's high standard of food quality and hygiene.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In conclusion I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney)-I will give him a copy of the telex-to draw the matter to the attention of Senator Peter Baume in his capacity as Minister for Health and to the attention of other relevant Ministers who might be able to take some action to see that the livelihood of rice growers in the New South Wales Murray irrigation area, in response to their requests, is given some protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator McLaren, as he has just suggested, gives me a copy of that telex, I will ensure that it is in the hands of the Minister for Health (Senator Peter Baume) very shortly and will seek an early response from the Minister for the rice growers referred to by Senator McLaren.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the matter raised by Senator Tate, the honourable senator will be aware of the difficulty in opening up areas of the sort that he has mentioned to ex gratia payments and the difficulty in going beyond the statutory compensation rules which are provided for Commonwealth employees. I will, however, refer the case to the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, and ask him to consider the possibility of a recommendation for ex gratia payment, which would have to be made to the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I am not in a position to make any positive response except to say that these matters obviously have to be treated with considerable care because of the difficulty of definition once we get into this area. I will refer the two matters raised to the appropriate Ministers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.32 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1090) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is a normal requirement of TEAS that students should lodge their applications by 31 March each year if they are to receive benefits with retrospective effect to 1 January of that year. Where an application is received after 31 March, benefits will apply only from the date of application.

Final enrolment data in relation to universities, colleges and technical and further education institutions does not become available until mid-year. On past experience the figure quoted by the honourable senator of 38 per cent of tertiary students being eligible for TEAS at that stage would appear to be reasonably correct.
The proportion of full time students enrolled in approved courses at universities, CAE's and TAFE institutions who were in receipt of TEAS at 30 June each year from 1976 to 1981 was as follows:
1976-38.4 per cent
1977-40.3 per cent
1978-41.8 per cent
1979-39.5 per cent
1980-38.6 per cent
1981-37.5 (preliminary figure)

The level of benefits and conditions to apply for 1983 under all the student assistance schemes including TEAS are currently under review in the context of the 1982-83 Budget. It is therefore not possible to indicate at this stage the priorities which might be adopted in the allocation of funds which will be available to support the overall student assistance program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 645) Senator Mulvihill asked me the following question without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, is based on an answer I received on 8 December. It was a two-tiered response. In the first instance the Minister promised that there would be legislation early this year to provide for an end to discrimination in relation to migrant women and the limitation involved in having their children listed on the citizenship certificate. The second part of the answer concerned a consolidation of voting rights and equality of voting eligibility between Commonwealth nationals and other migrants coming into this country. I received the answer on 8 December and we were promised legislation early in 1982. Does the Minister contemplate introducing legislation to amend the Australian Citizenship Act in the former case and the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the latter case?
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As indicated in my previous response a review of the Australian Citizenship Act has been undertaken. The proposals are being finalised and it is likely that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will foreshadow the proposed legislative amendments in another place before the end of the current sittings.
Amendments to eliminate provisions which now discriminate on the grounds of sex are included in the proposals under consideration.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was amended by the Statute Law ( Miscellaneous Amendment) Act 1981 which was assented to by the Governor-General on 2 December 1981. The new provisions will come into operation on a date to be fixed by Proclamation.

The Proclamation has not been made because it is hoped to have a uniform Australia-wide commencement date. Consultations are continuing with State Governments with a view to complementary legislation being introduced by them as soon as possible to enable an early uniform Australia-wide commencement date of the electoral change.
