QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the exact wording of the recommendations made by the Committee consisting of Sir William Cole, Sir Geoffrey Yeend and Mr N. Currie to the Prime Minister concerning the resignation and future employment of Mr M. A. Besley?
(2) Did the advice of this Committee differ in any way from the decision made by the Prime Minister on Mr Besley's resignation and future employment?
(3) Were any conditions recommended by the Committee, which were not agreed to by the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) I wrote to Senator Walsh on 16 December, as follows:
Dear Senator Walsh,
You wrote to me about Mr Besley's resignation as Secretary, Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the announcement of his prospective appointment as Managing Director of Monier Ltd.

It is a great pity that the facts of the situation were not sought before you made, under the protection of Senate debate, the serious and totally unfounded imputations contained in your speech on 26 November. It is perfectly proper that a senior officer taking up a position in private industry should indicate his intention to do so immediately, and to disengage from his official duties promptly. Whether some period should elapse between resignation from the Service and engagement in private industry is a matter to be judged on the facts, and procedures have been laid down for this judgment to be made.

Mr Besley first approached the Chairman of the Public Service Board, Sir William Cole, on 6 October 1981. He indicated that he had been offered a position as Managing Director of a large public company and that he was proposing to resign in about March 1982 to take it up. He wished to follow the Bowen procedures properly.

Following the 6 October meeting the Chairman of the Public Service Board sought further information from Mr Besley concerning the proposed arrangement. Sir William was in Port Moresby in the week beginning 12 October and in that week Mr Besley spoke to Sir Geoffrey Yeend about the matter. In the following week Sir William appointed a Permanent Heads' Committee comprising Sir Geoffrey Yeend, Mr N. S. Currie and himself to report to me and this report was provided on 20 October.
The Committee did not consider that it needed to call Mr Besley before it, and did not do so; as indicated there were prior discussions between Mr Besley and two members of the Committee.

It is not appropriate to publish all the information obtained by the Committee, and contained in its recommendations to me. I am sure you will appreciate that there are privacy considerations in respect of individuals which should be taken into account in this respect. I can say, however, that the Government's decision was consistent with what was put to it by the Permanent Heads' Committee.

You ask if there will be ''monitoring'' to ensure that any ''conditions'' laid down are followed. The Bowen recommendations constitute a code of conduct. They are not enforceable in law and it is neither desirable nor practicable to contemplate some kind of monitoring of the activities of private citizens. Mr Besley has in fact assured the Government that, in his new position, he would act consistently with the Bowen report.

Mr Besley is currently on recreation leave/furlough and his resignation will be effective on 14 March 1982. Mr Besley, quite properly, immediately went on leave following the announcement of his intention to accept a position with Monier, pending his resignation from the Service.
The Government's decision was consistent in all respects with what was put to it by the Committee. There were no recommendations by the Committee which were not accepted by the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of National Development and Energy have an equal employment opportunities program.
(2) How long has the program been in existence.
(3) What are the aims of the program.
(4) What is the Department's assessment of the success of the program in achieving the aims.
(5) How have, or are, the aims of the program being met.
(6) Is the program aimed at covering the whole Department, or merely a section of it.
(7) What are the procedures for union consultation and involvement in the program.
(8) What involvement does the Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau of the Public Service Board have in the program.
(9) Has the program changed in its priority rating within the Department since its introduction.
(10) If there is no program, on what basis was this decision reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) and (3) The Department of National Development and Energy has always followed a policy of equal employment opportunity for women, the disabled and other minority groups consistent with their ability to perform the required duties. While not embodied in a formal program, the pursued objectives are to provide all employees with equal employment, career and development opportunities and to ensure that no group is improperly or unreasonably discriminated against.
(4) The objectives are generally being achieved.
(5) All applications and selection processes are closely scrutinised to ensure that all staff are treated equally and provided with the same opportunities for employment, promotion and development.
(6) These policies apply throughout the whole Department.
(7) Local representatives of staff associations are consulted as necessary on specific matters.
(8) The Department is represented at most seminars and workshops conducted by the Equal Employment Opportunity Bureau of the Public Service Board and receives all material issued by the Bureau.
(9) Generally no. Periods of special emphasis (for example the International Year of Disabled Persons) may bring some shift in focus within the policy.
(10) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Gold Coast City Council approved an 18 storey apartment tower on Currumbin Hill, in the flight path to Coolangatta Airport.
(2) Has the Department of Transport set a 75 metre maximum height to avoid danger to aircraft and that the proposed roof height for the building is 73 metres.
(3) Is such flight obstruction not an unacceptable risk, given the two metre difference in the recommended safety margin.
(4) What negotiations have been undertaken by the Department in relation to the safety aspects of the siting of this apartment tower.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Gold Coast City Council has approved an apartment tower on Currumbin Hill. However, the Department of Transport understands that the tower is fourteen storeys high.
(2) Yes. The Department has set a maximum height limit of seventy-five metres. It is also correct that the tower is to be seventy-three metres high.
(3) The building is not considered a risk as it does not intrude into the clearance surface of seventy-five metres which allows a margin of safety.

(4) The Department has negotiated with the Gold Coast City Council, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and technical representatives of Ansett and TAA in relation to the safety aspects of the siting of the apartment tower. On the basis of this consultation the Department indicated no objection to the Gold Coast City Council's proposal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister aware of the French manufactured Dagaie chaff launcher which is being marketed as the Squid and is intended for shipboard mounting as a 'soft' kill answer to the surface-to-surface guided missile threat; if so, are any such chaff launchers of the Dagaie or any other type mounted on Royal Australian Navy vessels, and is it intended such chaff launchers should be mounted on RAN ships.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The Dagaie launcher is not fitted though other decoy launching systems are currently fitted in some ships of the RAN and wider fitting in other ships is programmed.
